{{url|www.skardu.pk}} }} {{anchor|Popular culture references}} '''Baltistan''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|بلتستان}}}}, {{lang-bft|སྦལ་ཏི་སྟཱན|script=Tibt}} also known as '''Baltiyul''' or '''Little Tibet''' ({{lang-bft|སྦལ་ཏི་ཡུལ་།|script=Tibt}}), is a mountainous region on the border of Pakistan Controlled Kashmir and Indian Controlled Kashmir in the [[Karakoram]] mountains just south of [[K2]] (the world's second-highest mountain). Baltistan borders [[Gilgit]] to the west, [[Xinjiang]] ([[China]]) in the north, [[Ladakh]] on the southeast and the [[Kashmir Valley]] on the southwest.{{citation |first=Victoria |last=Schofield |authorlink=Victoria Schofield |title=Kashmir in Conflict |publisher=I. B. Taurus & Co |location=London and New York |year=2003 |origyear=First published in 2000 |ISBN=1860648983 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rkTetMfI6QkC&pg=PA8 |p=8}}{{citation |last=Cheema |first=Brig Amar, |title=The Crimson Chinar: The Kashmir Conflict: A Politico Military Perspective |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qc25BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA30 |date=2015 |publisher=Lancer Publishers |isbn=978-81-7062-301-4 |page=30}} Its average altitude is over {{convert|3,350|m}}. Prior to 1947, Baltistan was part of the princely state of [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|Jammu and Kashmir]], having been conquered by Raja [[Gulab Singh]]'s armies in 1840.{{cite book|title=Proceedings - Punjab History Conference|date=1968|publisher=Punjabi University|language=en}} Baltistan and Ladakh were administered jointly under one ''wazarat'' (district) of the state. Baltistan retained its identity in this set-up as the [[Skardu]] ''tehsil'', with Kargil and Leh being the other two ''tehsils'' of the district.{{citation |first=H. N. |last=Kaul |title=Rediscovery of Ladakh |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mg8My6WaWRcC&pg=PA88 |year=1998 |publisher=Indus Publishing |isbn=978-81-7387-086-6 |page=88}} After the [[Hari Singh|Maharaja]] of Jammu and Kashmir [[Instrument of Accession|acceded]] to India, [[Gilgit Scouts]] overthrew the Maharaja's governor in Gilgit and (with [[Azad Kashmir]]'s irregular forces) captured Baltistan. The [[Gilgit Agency]] and Baltistan have been governed by Pakistan ever since.{{citation |first=Victoria |last=Schofield |authorlink=Victoria Schofield |title=Kashmir in Conflict |publisher=I. B. Taurus & Co |location=London and New York |year=2003 |origyear=First published in 2000 |ISBN=1860648983 |pp=65–66 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rkTetMfI6QkC&pg66}} The [[Kashmir Valley]] and the [[Kargil district|Kargil]] and [[Leh district|Leh]] ''tehsils'' were retained by India. A small portion of Baltistan, including the village of [[Turtuk]] in the [[Nubra Valley]], was incorporated into Ladakh after the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]].Atul Aneja, [http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/2001/01/11/stories/0211000h.htm A 'battle' in the snowy heights], The Hindu, 11 January 2001.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-22690692|title=In pictures: Life in Baltistan|work=bbc.com|accessdate=13 May 2015}} The region is inhabited primarily by [[Balti people]] of [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]] descent. Millennia-old Tibetan culture, customs, norms, language and scripts still exist, although the vast majority of the population follows [[Islam]]. Baltistan is strategically significant to Pakistan and India; the [[Kargil War|Kargil]] and [[Siachen conflict|Siachen War]]s were fought there. The region is the setting for [[Greg Mortenson]]'s book, ''[[Three Cups of Tea]]''. == Geography == [[File:SkarduFromFort1175.JPG|thumbnail|alt=Valley town seen from above|[[Skardu]], capital of Baltistan]] The 1911 [[Encyclopaedia Britannica Eleventh Edition|Encyclopaedia Britannica]] characterises Baltistan as the western extremity of [[Tibet]], whose natural limits are the [[Indus river]] from its abrupt southward bend around the map point {{coord|35.86|N|74.72|E|name=Bend in the Indus course}} and the mountains to the north and west. These features separate a comparatively peaceful Tibetan population from the fiercer [[Indo-Aryan peoples|Indo-Aryan]] tribes to the west. [[Muslim]] writers around the 16th century speak of Baltistan as the "Little Tibet", and of [[Ladakh]] as the "Great Tibet", emphasising their [[ethnological]] similarity. {{Cite EB1911 |wstitle=Ladakh and Baltistan |volume=16 |pages=57–59 |ref=harv}} According to Ahmad Hassan Dani, Baltistan spreads upwards from the Indus river and is separated from Ladakh by the [[Siachen glacier]].{{sfn|Dani|1998|p=219}} It includes the Indus valley and the lower valley of the [[Shyok river]]{{coord|34.925|N|76.68|E|name=Shyok river|display=none}}.{{sfn|Pirumshoev|Dani|2003|p=243}} Baltistan is a rocky mass of lofty mountains, the prevailing formation being [[gneiss]]. In the north is the [[Baltoro Glacier]]{{coord|35|44|11|N|76|22|51|E|name=Baltoro glacier|display=none}}, the largest out of the [[arctic]] regions, {{convert|35|mi|km}} long, contained between two ridges whose highest peaks to the south are {{convert|25000|ft|m|abbr=on}} and to the north {{convert|28265|ft|m|abbr=on}}. The Indus river runs in a narrow [[Canyon|gorge]], widening after receiving the [[Shyok]] river at {{coord|35.23|N|75.92|E|name=Shyok joins Indus}}. It then forms a 20-mile crescent-shaped plain varying between 1 mile and 5 miles wide.{{sfn|Karim|2009|p=62}} The main inhabitable valleys of [[Kharmang]] [[Khaplu]], [[Skardu]] and [[Roundu]] are along the routes of these rivers. {{GeoGroup|section=Valleys_and_districts}} ===Valleys and districts=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Valley ! District ! Area (km2) ! Population (1998) ! Capital |- |[[Khaplu]]
{{coord|35|9|N|76|19|E|name=Khaplu valley|display=none}} ||[[Ghanche District|Ghanche]]||9,400||88,366||[[Khaplu]] |- |[[Skardu]]
{{coord|35|17|N|75|38|E|name=Skardu valley|display=none}} ||[[Skardu District|Skardu]]||18,000||219,209||[[Skardu]] |- |[[Shigar]]
{{coord|35|25|N|75|44|E|name=Shigar valley|display=none}} ||[[Shigar Valley|Shigar]]||6,450||60,295||Center Shigar |- |[[Kharmang]]
{{coord|34|44|N|76|10|E|name=Kharmang valley|display=none}} ||[[Kharmang]]||5,520||62,522||[[Tolti Kharmang|Tolti]] |- | [[Roundu Valley|Roundu]]
{{coord|35|35|N|75|13|E|name=Roundu valley|display=none}} ||[[Skardu District|Skardu]]||||80,000||[[Thowar]] |- | [[Gultari]]
{{coord|34|35|N|75|12|E|name=Gultari valley|display=none}} ||[[Skardu]] |||||| |- | [[Shyok]]°
{{coord|34|51|N|76|50|E|name=Shyok Valley|display=none}} ||[[Leh district|Leh, India]]||||4,000 (2011)||[[Turtuk]] |} °Although under Indian control since 1971, geographically, the Turtuk part of Shyok Valley, is part of Baltistan region. == History == [[File:Balti king ahmed shah.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Drawing of a bearded man holding a rifle|Ahmed Shah, the last [[Maqpon dynasty|Maqpon]] king before the 1840 Dogra invasion]] For centuries, Baltistan consisted of small, independent valley states connected by the blood relationships of its rulers (''[[raja]]s''), trade, common beliefs and cultural and linguistic bonds.{{cite journal|title=A Socio-Political Study of Gilgit Baltistan Province|url=http://www.bzu.edu.pk/PJSS/Vol30No12010/Final_PJSS-30-1-16.pdf}} The states were subjugated by the [[Dogra]] rulers of [[Kashmir]] during the 19th century.{{cite book|last=Gertel|first=Jörg|title=Economic Spaces of Pastoral Production and Commodity Systems|year=2011|publisher=Ashgate|isbn=978-1-4094-2531-1|pages=181|author2=Richard Le Heron}} On 29 August 2009 the government of [[Pakistan]] announced the creation of Gilgit–Baltistan, a provincial autonomous region with [[Gilgit]] as its capital and [[Skardu]] its largest city.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} Baltistan was known as Little Tibet, and the name was extended to include Ladakh. Ladakh later became known as Great Tibet. Locally, Baltistan is known as ''Baltiyul'' and Ladakh and Baltistan are known as Maryul ("red country").Yousaf Hussain Abadi, ''A view on Baltistan'' === {{anchor|Origin of Baltis and Baltistan}}Origins === {{quote|Tibetan [[Kham]]pa entered in [[Khaplu]] through [[Chorbat Valley]] and [[Dardic people|Dardic]] tribes came to Baltistan through [[Roundu Valley]] from [[Gilgit]] prior to civilization, and these groups eventually settled down, creating the Balti people.{{citation |first=Mustansar Hussain |last=Tarar |authorlink=Mustansar Hussain Tarar |title=Nanga Parbat |year=1991 |language=Urdu}}}} [[File:Old skardu.jpg|thumbnail|left|alt=Drawing of lakes surrounded by mountains|Skardu in 1800]] Today, the people of [[Kharmang]] and [[Chorbat Valley|Western Khaplu]] have Tibetan features and those in Skardu, [[Shigar]] and the eastern villages of Khaplu are [[Dard people|Dards]].''Where Indus is Young'' It was believed that the Balti people were in the sphere of influence of [[Zhangzhung]]. Baltistan was controlled by the Tibetan king [[Songtsen Gampo]] during the seventh century AD. Culturally influenced by Tibet, the [[Bon]] and [[Animism|animist]] Baltis began to adopt [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. Religious artifacts such as ''[[gompa]]s'' and ''[[stupa]]s'' were built, and [[lama]]s played an important role in Balti life.''Baltistan in History'' by Banat Gul Afridi 1986Tarekh e jammu, molvi hashmatullahHussainabadi, Muhammad Yousuf: ''Baltistan per Aik Nazar'' 1984 During the 14th century, Muslim scholars from Kashmir crossed Baltistan’s mountainous terrain to spread Islam.{{cite web|title=Baltistan - North Pakistan|url=http://www.marafiefoundation.org/Default.aspx?tabid=78|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615182719/http://www.marafiefoundation.org/Default.aspx?tabid=78|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-06-15}} [[File:Machulu baltistan.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Village nestled in a mountain valley|Typical Balti village]] The [[Kharmang]] came under the control of the [[Namgyal dynasty of Ladakh|Namgyal royal family]] and developed a close relationship with Ladakh when the ''raja'' of Ladakh, Jamyang Mangyal, attacked the principalities in Kargil. Mangyal annihilated the Skardu garrison at Kharbu and put to the sword a number of petty Muslim rulers in the principalities of Purik (Kargil). [[Ali Sher Khan Anchan]], ''raja'' of [[Khaplu]] and [[Shigar]], left with a strong army via [[Marol]]. Passing the Laddakhi army, he occupied [[Leh]] (the capital of Ladakh) and the ''raja'' of Ladakh was taken prisoner.Hussainabadi, Muhammad Yousuf: ''Tareekh-e-Baltistan'' 2003{{cite book|title=Kashmir: Its Aborigines and Their Exodus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kRFvWyqGNzEC&pg=PA109&dq=Ali+Sher+Khan+Anchan+ladakh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jftuUaSLKYnXrQeuo4DIBg&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Ali%20Sher%20Khan%20Anchan%20ladakh&f=false}}{{cite book|title=The last colony: Muzaffarabad-Gilgit-Baltistan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IngMAQAAMAAJ&q=Ali+Sher+Khan+Anchan+ladakh&dq=Ali+Sher+Khan+Anchan+ladakh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jftuUaSLKYnXrQeuo4DIBg&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBg}} Ali Sher Khan Anchan included Gilgit and [[Chitral]] in his kingdom of Baltistan,{{cite book|title=Proceedings of the International Seminar on the Anthropology of Tibet and the Himalaya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nCRuAAAAMAAJ&q=Ali+Sher+Khan+Anchan+ladakh&dq=Ali+Sher+Khan+Anchan+ladakh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jftuUaSLKYnXrQeuo4DIBg&ved=0CFgQ6AEwCQ}} reportedly a flourishing country. The valley from Khepchne to Kachura was flat and fertile, with abundant fruit trees; the sandy desert now extending from Sundus to [[Skardu Airport]] was a prosperous town. Skardu had hardly recovered from the shock of the death of Anchan when it was flooded. In 1845, the area was seized by the Dogras.Ali, Manzoom (2004, June 12). Archaeology of Dardistan. == Tourism == [[File:Baltoro glacier from air.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Glacier surrounded by mountains, seen from the air|Baltoro Glacier; at {{convert|62|km|mi|0}} in length, it is one of the longest Alpine glaciers on earth.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}]] Skardu has several tourist resorts and many natural features, including plains, mountains and mountain-valley lakes. The [[Deosai National Park|Deosai plain]], [[Satpara Lake]] and Basho also host tourists. North of Skardu, the Shigar Valley offers plains, hiking tracks, peaks and campsites. Other valleys in Baltistan region are [[Khaplu]], [[Roundu Baltistan|Rondu]], [[Kachura Lake]] and [[Kharmang]]. === {{anchor|Glaciers in Baltistan}}Glaciers === Baltistan is a rocky wilderness of around {{convert|27000|sqmi}},{{cite web|title=ABOUT GILGIT-BALTISTAN|url=http://www.mashabrum.com/gilgit_baltistan.html}} with the largest cluster of mountains in the world and the biggest [[glacier]]s outside the polar regions. The [[Himalayas]] advance into this region from India, Tibet and Nepal, and north of them are the Karakoram range. Both ranges run northwest, separated by the [[Indus River]]. Along the Indus and its tributaries are many valleys. Glaciers include [[Baltoro Glacier]], [[Biafo Glacier]], [[Siachen Glacier]], [[Trango Glacier]] and [[Godwin-Austen Glacier]]. === {{anchor|Panorama}}Mountaineering === [[File:Laila Peak.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Jagged peak|[[Laila Peak (Hushe Valley)|Laila Peak]], in the [[Hushe Valley]]]] Baltistan is home to more than 20 peaks of over {{convert|20000|ft|m}}, including [[K2]] (the second-highest mountain on earth.Baltistan in History, Banat Gul Afridi Other well-known peaks include [[Masherbrum]] (also known as K1), [[Broad Peak]], [[Hidden Peak]], [[Gasherbrum II]], [[Gasherbrum IV]] and [[Chogolisa]] (in the [[Khaplu Valley]]). The following peaks have been scaled: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Name !! !!Height !!Date climbed!!Location |- |[[K2|K-2]] || style="min-width:100px" | [[File:K2 2006b.jpg|100px]]||(28,250 Ft)|| 31 July 1954||[[Shigar Valley|Shigar District]] |- |[[Gasherbrum I]] || [[File:Gasherbrum2.jpg|100px]] || (26,360 Ft) || 7 July 1956||[[Ghanche District]] |- |[[Broad Peak]] || [[File:7 15 BroadPeak.jpg|100px]] || (26,550 Ft) || 9 June 1957|| Ghanche District |- |[[Muztagh Tower]] ||[[File:MuztaghTower.jpg|100px]] ||(23,800 Ft)|| 6 August 1956||Ghanche District |- |[[Gasherbrum II]] || [[File:Gasherbrum2.jpg|100px]] ||(26,120 Ft)|| 4 July 1958||Ghanche District |- | [[Hidden Peak]] || [[File:HiddenPeak.jpg|100px]] || (26,470 Ft)|| 4 July 1957||Ghanche District |- |[[Khunyang Chhish]] || [[File:Kunyang Pumari Chhish.JPG|100px]] || (25,761 Ft) || 4 July 1971 ||[[Skardu District]] |- |[[Masherbrum]] || [[File:Masherbrum.jpg|100px]] ||(25,659 Ft) || 4 August 1960|| Ghanche District |- |[[Saltoro Kangri]] || [[File:Saltoro Kangri.jpg|100px]] ||(25,400 Ft) || 4 June 1962 ||Ghanche District |- |[[Chogolisa]] || [[File:Chogolisa.jpg|100px]] ||(25,148 Ft) || 4 August 1963||Ghanche District |} {{wide image|Satpara lakejkhkjkhjk.jpg|1000px|alt=Lake with low mountains in the background|Panoramic view of [[Sheosar Lake]]}} == Demographics == The region has a population of about 322,000. It is a blend of ethnic groups, predominantly [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]], [[Balti people|Baltis]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gilgitbaltistanscouts.gov.pk/geodemo.htm|title=Geography and Dempgraphy of Gilgit Baltistan (GB Scouts)|first=Ejaz|last=Hussain|website=www.gilgitbaltistanscouts.gov.pk}} and [[Monpa people|Monpas]]. A few [[Kashmiris]] settled in Skardu, practicing agriculture and woodcraft. The Yabgo family of Khaplu{{cite web|title=Noorbakhsi Muslims |url=http://www.noorbakhshia.com/noorbaksh/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201091121/http://www.noorbakhshia.com/noorbaksh/ |archivedate=1 February 2015 }} were from [[Yarkant County]], China. == Religion == Before the arrival of Islam, Tibetan Buddhism and Bön (to a lesser extent) were the main religions in Baltistan. Buddhism can be traced back to before the formation of the [[Tibetan Empire]] in the region during the seventh century. The region has a number of surviving [[Buddhist art|Buddhist]] archaeological sites. These include the [[Manthal Buddha Rock]], a [[rock relief]] of the Buddha at the edge of the village (near [[Skardu]]) and the [[Sacred Rock of Hunza]]. Nearby are former sites of Buddhist shelters. Islam was brought to Baltistan by [[Sufism|Sufi]] missionaries during the 16th and 17th centuries, and most of the population converted to [[Noorbakshia Islam]]. The scholars were followers of the [[Kubrawiya]] Sufi order.{{cite web|title=NYF|url=http://nyfpk.org/Islam%20in%20Baltistan.php}} Most Noorbakhshi Muslims live in Ghanche and Shigar districts, and 30 percent live in the Skardu district.{{cite web|title=Sofia Imamia Noorbakhshia |url=http://noorbakhshia.com/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518103616/http://www.noorbakhshia.com/ |archivedate=18 May 2015 }} == {{anchor|Domesticated animals|Wild animals}}Fauna == [[File:Golden-Marmot.jpg|250px|thumb|alt=Two large, furry rodents resting on the ground|[[Long-tailed marmot|Golden marmots]] in Deosai National Park]] Baltistan has been called a living museum for wildlife.{{cite web|title=Beautiful Gilgit Baltistan |url=http://www.visitgilgitbaltistan.gov.pk/nature.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018131507/http://www.visitgilgitbaltistan.gov.pk/nature.html |archivedate=18 October 2012 }} [[Deosai National Park]], in the southern part of the region, is habitat for predators since it has an abundant prey population. Domestic animals include [[yak]]s (including [[Yak#Hybrid yak|hybrid yaks]]), [[cattle]], [[sheep]], [[goat]]s, [[horse]]s and [[donkey]]s. Wild animals include [[ibex]], [[markhor]], [[musk deer]], [[snow leopard]]s, [[brown bear|brown]] and [[Asian black bear|black bears]], [[jackal]]s, [[fox]]es, [[Gray wolf|wolves]] and [[marmot]]s. == Culture == === Balti music and art === [[File:Balti children.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Three smiling young boys, with trees and a mountain in the background|Balti children from the [[Shigar Valley]]]] According to Balti folklore, [[Mughal emperors|Mughal]] princess Gul Khatoon (known in Baltistan as Mindoq Gialmo—Flower Queen) brought musicians and artisans with her into the region and they propagated Mughal music and art under her patronage.{{cite web|title=BALTI MUSIC AND ART|url=http://www.mybaltistan.com/History/History%20of%20Baltistan/English/6.htm}} Musical instruments such as the ''[[Zurna|surnai]]'', ''karnai'', ''dhol'' and ''[[Fangxiang|chang]]'' were introduced into Baltistan. ==== Dance ==== Classical and other dances are classified as sword dances, ''broqchhos'' and [[Yakkha]] and ''[[ghazal]]'' dances.Hussainabadi, Muhammad Yousuf: ''Balti Zaban'' 1990 ''Chhogho Prasul'' commemorates a victory by the [[Maqpon dynasty|Maqpon ''rajas'']]. As a mark of respect, the musician who plays the drum (''dang'') plays for a long time. A Maqpon princess would occasionally dance to this tune. ''Gasho-Pa'', also known as ''Ghbus-La-Khorba'', is a sword dance associated with the Gasho Dynasty of Purik ([[Kargil]]). ''Sneopa'', the marriage-procession dance by ''pachones'' (twelve ''wazirs'' who accompany the bride), is performed at the marriage of a ''raja''. === Architecture === [[File:Chaqchan mosque khaplu.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Chinese-style mosque with enclosed porch and speakers|Chaqchan Mosque in Khaplu]] Balti architecture has Tibetan and MughulWallace, Paul (1996) . A History of Western Himalayas . Penguin Books, London. influences, and its monastic architecture reflects the Buddhist imprint left on the region. Buddhist-style [[wall painting]]s can be seen in forts and Noorbakhshi ''[[khanqah]]s'', including [[Chaqchan Mosque]] in [[Khaplu]], [[Amburik Mosque]] in Shigar, Khanqah e Muallah Shigar, [[Khaplu Fort]], [[Shigar Fort]] and [[Skardu Fort]]. === {{anchor|Sports}}Polo === [[File:Polo in old skardu.jpg|thumbnail|alt=Drawing of polo ponies galloping|Polo match in Skardu around 1820, from [[Godfrey Vigne]]'s ''Travels in Kashmir, Ladak, Iskardo, the countries adjoining the mountain-course of the Indus, and the Himalaya, north of the Panjab'']] [[Polo]] is popular in Baltistan, and is indigenous to the Karakoram. Maqpon ruler [[Ali Sher Khan Anchan]] introduced the game to other valleys during his conquests beyond Gilgit and Chitral.Dani, Ahmad Hassan: ''History of Northern Areas of Pakistan'', National Institute of Historical Research, Islamabad, 1991. ==Media== The [[Pakistan Broadcasting Corporation]]{{cite web|title=Radio Pakistan|url=http://www.radio.gov.pk/}} has radio and television stations in [[Khaplu]] that broadcast local programs, and there are a handful of private news outlets. The ''Daily K2''{{cite web|title=dailyk2|url=http://www.dailyk2.com/}} is an [[Urdu]] newspaper published in [[Skardu]] serving [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] for long time, and it is the pioneer of print media in Gilgit Baltisatn. ''Bad-e-Shimal'' claims the largest daily circulation in [[Gilgit]] and Baltistan.{{cite web|title=Daily Bad e Shimal|url=http://www.dailybaadeshimal.com/}} ''Nawa-e-Sufia'' is a monthly magazine covering Baltistan's Nurbakshi sect.{{cite web|title=Nuwa-e-Sufia|url=http://nyfpk.org/Nawa-i-Sufia.php}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * {{citation |last=Aggarwal |first=Ravina |title=Beyond Lines of Control: Performance and Politics on the Disputed Borders of Ladakh, India |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2k3mgWCitj0C&pg=PA199 |year=2004 |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=0-8223-3414-3 |pages=199–}} * {{citation |first=Ahmad Hasan |last=Dani |chapter=The Western Himalayan States |editor1=M. S. Asimov |editor2=C. E. Bosworth |title=History of Civilizations of Central Asia, Vol. IV, Part 1 — The age of achievement: A.D. 750 to the end of the fifteenth century — The historical, social and economic setting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=18eABeokpjEC&pg=PA221 |date=1998 |publisher=UNESCO |isbn=978-92-3-103467-1 |pages=215–225}} * {{citation |last=Karim |first=Afsir |chapter=Strategic dimensions of the trans-Himalayan frontiers |editor=K. Warikoo |title=Himalayan Frontiers of India: Historical, Geo-Political and Strategic Perspectives |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w_Z8AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA42 |date=2009 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-134-03294-5 |pages=56–66}} * {{citation |first1=H. S. |last1=Pirumshoev |first2=Ahmad Hasan |last2=Dani |chapter=The Pamirs, Badakhshan and the Trans-Pamir States |editor1=Chahryar Adle |editor2=Irfan Habib |title=History of Civilizations of Central Asia, Vol. V — Development in contrast: From the sixteenth to the mid-nineteenth century |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AzG5llo3YCMC&pg=PA244 |date=2003 |publisher=UNESCO |isbn=978-92-3-103876-1 |pages=225–246}} ==External links== {{NIE Poster|Baltistan}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/1491179.stm www.pakistantoursguide.pk] * [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/51055/Baltistan Britannica Baltistan]. {{Baltistan}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{coord|35|18|N|75|37|E|region:PK-NA_type:country_source:kolossus-dawiki|display=title}} [[Category:Baltistan| ]] [[Category:Regions of Gilgit-Baltistan]] [[Category:Divided regions]] [[Category:Regions of Pakistan]] {{portal|Gilgit-Baltistan}}

[[File:Brussels in Belgium and the European Union.svg|thumb|Location of Brussels in Belgium and the EU]] [[File:Arrondissement Brussels-Periphery Belgium Map.PNG|thumb|The former [[arrondissement of Brussels-Periphery]] within the province of [[Flemish Brabant]], corresponding to the six municipalities with language facilities.]] The '''Brussels Periphery''' ({{Lang-nl|Brusselse Rand}}, i.e. the "Brussels Rim", or ''Vlaamse Rand'', i.e. the "Flemish Rim", or just ''De Rand'', "the Rim"; {{Lang-fr|périphérie bruxelloise}}) refers to 19 [[List of municipalities of the Flemish Region|Flemish municipalities]] that encircle the [[Brussels-Capital Region]]. The Brussels Region is an [[enclave]] of the province of [[Flemish Brabant]].
Many of these municipalities are essentially [[Metropolitan areas in Belgium|suburbs of Brussels]]. Due to their proximity to Brussels, they have been [[urban sprawl|urbanised]] and their housing prices are high. As a consequence, a lot of well-paid people working in e.g. EU institutions reside here. Another issue, very sensitive in [[Belgian politics]], is the [[Francisation of Brussels|francisation of this area]]. These municipalities all have Dutch as their sole official language, although six municipalities also offer services (known as [[Municipalities with language facilities|language facilities]]) for French-speaking inhabitants, namely [[Drogenbos]], [[Kraainem]], [[Linkebeek]], [[Sint-Genesius-Rode]], [[Wemmel]] and [[Wezembeek-Oppem]]. Other municipalities include [[Asse]], [[Beersel]], [[Dilbeek]], [[Grimbergen]], [[Hoeilaart]], [[Machelen]], [[Meise]], [[Merchtem]], [[Overijse]], [[Sint-Pieters-Leeuw]], [[Tervuren]], [[Vilvoorde]] and [[Zaventem]].
Each year, ''[[De Gordel]]'' ("the belt"), a family walking and cycling event, is organised in this area as a symbolic affirmation that the municipalities involved are part of Flanders.
== See also == * [[Municipalities with language facilities]] * [[Francisation of Brussels]] * [[Arrondissement of Brussels-Periphery]]

{{About|the placename}} {{wiktionary}} '''Dera''', '''Dero''', '''Daro''', '''Dhoro''', '''Dahar''' or '''Dehra''' is a [[Pashto]], [[Balochi language|Balochi]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Kutchi language|Kutchi]], [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], and [[Dogri language|Dogri]]-language word meaning ''[[Campsite|camp]]'', mound or settlement. In [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], it is usually used as a place where men meet and socialize in the village.
==Geography== ===India=== * [[Dera Bassi]], [[Sahibzada Ajit Singh Nagar district|Mohali district]], Punjab * [[Dera Baba Nanak]], [[Gurdaspur district]], Punjab * [[Radha Soami Satsang Beas|Dera Baba Jaimal Singh, Beas, India]], [[Amritsar district]], Punjab * [[Dera Sach Khand]], [[Jalandhar district]], Punjab * [[Kanjli Wetland|Dera Kanjli]], [[Kapurthala district]], Punjab * [[Dera Gopipur]], [[Kangra district]], Himachal Pradesh * [[Dehra, Himachal]], [[Kangra district]], Himachal Pradesh * [[Gola Dhoro]], [[Kutch district]], Gujarat * [[Kerala-no-dhoro]], [[Saurashtra region|Saurashtra]], Gujarat * [[Savli|Damajino Dero]], [[Vadodara district]], Gujarat * [[Dehradun]], interim capital of [[Uttarakhand]] * [[Derasar]] a term for a [[Jain temple]]
===Iran=== * [[Dera, Iran]], a village in Kerman Province, Iran * [[Dera, Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad]], a village in Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad Province, Iran * [[Dehra, Iran]], a village in Kermanshah Province, Iran
===Pakistan=== * [[Dera Allah Yar]], [[Jaffarabad District]], Balochistan * [[Dera Bugti]], [[Dera Bugti District]], Balochistan * [[Dera Dildar]], [[Bahawalpur]], Punjab * [[Dera Ghazi Khan]], [[Dera Ghazi Khan District]], Punjab * [[Dera Ismail Khan]], [[Dera Ismail Khan District]], Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa * [[Frontier Region Dera Ismail Khan]] (FR DI Khan), Federally Administered Tribal Areas * [[Dera Murad Jamali]], [[Nasirabad District]], Balochistan * [[Saddar Dera Bugti]], [[Dera Bugti District]], Balochistan * [[Ratodero]], [[Larkana District]], Sindh * [[Chanhudaro]], [[Shaheed Benazirabad District|Nawabshah District]], Sindh * [[Lakhueen-jo-daro]], [[Sukkur District]], Sindh * [[Mohenjo-daro]], [[Larkana District]], Sindh * [[Dhoro Naro railway station|Dhoro Naro]], Sindh * [[Sobho Dero]], [[Khairpur District]], Sindh * [[Mohabat Dero Jatoi]], [[Naushahro Feroze District]], Sindh * [[Naudero]], [[Larkana District]], Sindh * [[Dera Alampur Gondlan]], [[Gujrat District]], Punjab
==See also== * [[-abad]] * [[-stan]] * [[-land]] * [[Khurd and Kalan]] * [[Pur (Vedic)#Pur and Pura|Pur and Pura]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{unreferenced|date=February 2009}} '''Dubrava''' is the district of [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]]. It is located in the northeastern part of the city and divided by the [[Dubrava Avenue]] into two administrative areas: * [[Gornja Dubrava]] (''Upper Dubrava'') * [[Donja Dubrava, Zagreb|Donja Dubrava]] (''Lower Dubrava'')
The name comes from a Slavic toponym for [[oak]] forests. The species of oak that grows in this area is ''[[Quercus robur]]'' L.
== History == === Until 1945 === In its earliest days Dubrava was no more than a village, consisting of a couple of houses and gardens. It slowly grew, mostly because of intensive settling of people from all over [[Croatia]] to the city of [[Zagreb]] and surrounding areas. By the 1930s Dubrava had over hundred inhabitants and was connected with Zagreb via road. When [[World War II]] began, Dubrava already had electrical power and 250 inhabitants. During the war it was a [[Yugoslav Partisans|partisan]] base due to its relative distance from other major cities and simultaneous closeness to Zagreb, making it an ideal place from which partisans could operate within Zagreb itself.
As the war progressed, the partisans intensified their activities in Dubrava. Due to the increasing successes of the resistance in Dubrava, the occupation forces were army to occupy Dubrava, where they murdered 13 partisan supporters in December 1944. Following the liberation of Yugoslavia, these people were declared national heroes and several monuments were built in their honor in the Park of December Victims and on the corner of the Konjščinska Street.
==External links== * [http://www.dubrava.hr/ Official web site of Dubrava]
