{{Infobox geopolitical organization |name =
{{collapsible list |titlestyle = background:transparent;text-align:center; |title = {{big|Latin Union}} |liststyle = text-align:center; ||{{larger|{{native name|ca|Unió Llatina}}}} |{{larger|{{native name|fr|Union Latine}}}} |{{larger|{{native name|it|Unione Latina}}}} |{{larger|{{native name|pt|União Latina}}}} |{{larger|{{native name|ro|Uniunea Latină}}}} |{{larger|{{native name|es|Unión Latina}}}} }}
|linking_name = the Latin Union |symbol_type = Logo |image_map = Union_Latine.svg |admin_center_type = Headquarters |admin_center = {{nowrap|[[Paris]], [[France]]}} |coordinates = {{Coord|48|46|N|2|11|E|type:city}} |languages_type = [[Romance language|Official language]]s |languages ={{flatlist| *[[Spanish language|Spanish]] *[[Catalan language|Catalan]] *[[French language|French]] *[[Italian language|Italian]] *[[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] *[[Romanian language|Romanian]] }} |membership_type = [[Member states of the Latin Union|Members]]{{cite web |url=http://www.unilat.org/SG/Etats_membres/fr |title=États membres |accessdate=2013-12-06 |publisher=Latin Union}} |membership = {{flatlist| *'''Spanish''': [[Bolivia]] · [[Chile]] · [[Colombia]] · [[Costa Rica]] · [[Cuba]] · [[Dominican Republic]] · [[Ecuador]] · [[El Salvador]] · [[Guatemala]] · [[Honduras]] · [[Nicaragua]] · [[Panama]] · [[Paraguay]] · [[Peru]] · [[Philippines]] · [[Spain]] · [[Uruguay]] · [[Venezuela]] *'''French''': [[Ivory Coast|Côte d'Ivoire]] · [[France]] · [[Haiti]] · [[Monaco]] · [[Senegal]] *'''Italian''': [[Italy]] · [[San Marino]] *'''Portuguese''': [[Angola]] · [[Brazil]] · [[Cape Verde]] · [[East Timor]] · [[Guinea-Bissau]] · [[Mozambique]] · [[Portugal]] · [[São Tomé and Príncipe]] *'''Romanian''': [[Moldova]] · [[Romania]] *'''Catalan''': [[Andorra]] *'''Observers''': [[Argentina]] · [[Holy See]] · [[Mexico]] · [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]]}} |ethnic_groups = |ethnic_groups_year = |leader_title1 = {{longitem|President of the Congress}} |leader_name1 = [[Oleg Serebrian]] |leader_title2 = {{nowrap|Secretary-General}} |leader_name2 = José Luis Dicenta Ballester |established = 15 May 1954 in [[Madrid]], Spain |official_website = {{URL|www.unilat.org}} }} The '''Latin Union''' was an [[international organization]] of nations that used [[Romance languages]] that existed as a functional institution from 1983 to 2012. Its aim was to protect, project, and promote the common cultural heritage of [[Italic peoples|Latin peoples]] and unifying identities of the [[Latin]], and Latin-influenced, world. It was created in 1954 in [[Madrid]], [[Spain]], and its membership rose from 12 to 36 states, including countries in [[North America]], [[South America]], [[Europe]], [[Africa]], and the [[Asia-Pacific]] region.{{cite web |url=http://www.unilat.org/SG/Organisation/Presentation/EtatsMembres/index.es.asp |title=Unión Latina; Estados miembros |accessdate=2009-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228203150/http://www.unilat.org/SG/Organisation/Presentation/EtatsMembres/index.es.asp |archivedate=2008-12-28 |df= }} The official names of the Latin Union were: '''{{lang|fr|Union Latine}}''' in [[French language|French]], '''{{lang|it|Unione Latina}}''' in [[Italian language|Italian]], '''{{lang|pt|União Latina}}''' in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], '''{{lang|ro|Uniunea Latină}}''' in [[Romanian language|Romanian]],'''{{lang|es|Unión Latina}}''' in [[Spanish language|Spanish]], and '''{{lang|ca|Unió Llatina}}''' in [[Catalan language|Catalan]]. [http://www.unilat.org/SG/index.es.asp Latin Union Official Site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090512163034/http://www.unilat.org/SG/index.es.asp |date=2009-05-12 }} Due to financial difficulties, the Latin Union announced on 26 January 2012 the suspension of its activities, the dissolution of its Secretariat General (effective July 31, 2012) and termination of employment for all the organization's personnel.[http://www.unilat.org/SG/2309 "Disolución de la Secretaría General de la Unión Latina"], ''Unión Latina'', accessed 2012-06-10. ==Membership== {{see also|Member states of the Latin Union}} According to the Latin Union's website, membership was open to any nation that met the following criteria: *[[Linguistics|Linguistic]] criteria : **Official language derived from Latin **Latin-derived language used in [[education]] **Latin-derived language commonly used in the [[mass media]] or in daily life *Linguistic/cultural criteria : **Existence of significant [[literature]] in a Latin-derived language **[[Mass media|Press]] and [[publishing|publication]] in Latin-derived language **[[Television]] with a strong proportion of the programming in a Latin-derived language **[[Radio]] widely broadcast in a Latin-derived language *Cultural criteria : **Direct or indirect inheritance of the legacy of [[Ancient Rome]], to which the state remains faithful and which it perpetuates mainly through the education of [[Latin]] **[[culture|Cultural]] education of Latin-derived foreign languages **Exchange programmes with other Latin countries **Societal organization, particularly in the [[law|legal]] plane, based on respect for fundamental [[liberty|liberties]], the general principles of [[human rights]] and [[democracy]], tolerance, and freedom of [[religion]] ==Official languages== The official languages of the Latin Union were [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]], and [[Catalan language|Catalan]]. Spanish, French, Italian and Portuguese were used as working languages. All the texts of general diffusion were translated into these four languages, with some also going into Romanian and Catalan. ==Organization== The Union was composed of three main bodies, namely, the Congress, the Executive Council, and the General Secretariat. ===Congress=== The Congress, which consisted of the representatives of all the Member States, met in ordinary assembly every two years. Its main functions were * to adopt the budget, * to define the general direction of the Union, * to receive the new Member States formally, and * to elect and appoint different Member States to be the Presidents, Vice-Presidents, and members of the sub-organisations of the Union. A President and two Vice-Presidents were also elected by the Congress. [[Oleg Serebrian]] from the [[Republic of Moldova]] was the last President. There were also two auxiliary bodies of the Congress, namely, the Commission of Adhesions and the Commission of Candidacies. * The Commission of Adhesions was composed of 10 Member States and was responsible for promoting the adherence of all the Member States of the Union. * The Commission of Candidacies was composed of 9 Member States and was responsible for examining the validity of the candidacies, taking account of the geographical and linguistic-cultural division. ===Executive Council=== The Executive Council was the executive branch of the Union. It consisted of 12 Member States, which were elected by the Congress every four years, and led by a President and two Vice-Presidents, which were also elected by the Congress. There were also two auxiliary commissions sub-ordinated to the Executive Council: * The Commission of Finance and Programmes * The Commission of Statues ===General Secretariat=== The Latin Union was directed by a Secretary-General appointed every four years by the Congress. The Secretary was in charge of the execution of the programmes and implemented the decisions made by the Congress and the Executive Council in the matter of budget and general direction. [[Jose Luis Dicenta Ballester]] was at one time Secretary-General of the Union. Subordinated to the Secretary-General, there were 4 directors: * Director of Administration and Finance * Director of Culture and Communication * Director of Promotion and Education of the Languages * Director of Terminology and Industry of the Language ===Finance=== The finance of the Union was mainly supported by the obligatory contributions from the Member States. For some activities, the Union may have collaborated with other public or private institutions. ==Map of Latin Union== [[File:Union_Latine.svg|thumb|750x533px|center|Member states of the Latin Union.]] ==See also== * [[Association of Spanish Language Academies]] * [[Community of Portuguese Language Countries]] * [[Francophonie]] * [[Hispanic]] * [[Hispanidad]] * [[Hispanoamérica]] * [[Iberoamérica]] * [[Latin America]] * [[Latin Europe (disambiguation)|Latin Europe]] * [[Latin Monetary Union]] * [[Italic peoples]] * [[Organization of Ibero-American States]] * [[Panhispanism]] * [[Pan-Latinism]] * [[Romance languages]] * [[United States of Latin Africa|Romance-speaking Africa]] * [[Romance-speaking Europe]] * [[Romance-speaking world]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{es icon}} {{fr icon}} {{it icon}} {{pt icon}} {{ro icon}} {{ca icon}} [http://www.unilat.org/ Official site] {{Countries and languages lists}} {{International organizations}} [[Category:Intergovernmental organizations]] [[Category:Latin America]] [[Category:Spanish language]] [[Category:French language]] [[Category:Italian language]] [[Category:Portuguese language]] [[Category:Romanian language]] [[Category:Country classifications]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1954]] [[Category:Romance countries and territories]] [[Category:Latin Union| ]] [[Category:Organizations based in Paris]] [[Category:1954 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Catalan language]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox fictional location | name = Terra Australis | colour = #C0C0C0 | image = Typus Orbis Terrarum drawn by Abraham Ortelius.jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = Terra Australis is the large continent on the bottom of this 1570 map. | source = | creator = | genre = | type = | locations = | people = }} This '''list of Antarctic expeditions''' is a [[chronological]] list of [[expeditions]] involving [[Antarctica]]. Although the existence of a [[Terra Australis|southern continent]] had been hypothesized as early as the writings of [[Ptolemy]] in the 1st century AD, the South Pole was not reached until 1911.
==Pre-exploration theories== *600 BC – 300 BC — [[Greek philosophy|Greek Philosophers]] theorize [[Spherical Earth]] with [[North Pole|North]] and [[South Pole|South]] [[Polar region]]s. *150 [[Anno Domini|AD]] — [[Ptolemy]] published [[Geographia (Ptolemy)|Geographia]], which notes [[Terra Australis|Terra Australis Incognita]]
==Pre-19th century== * 7th century — [[Ui-te-Rangiora]] claimed to have sighted southern ice fields. * 13th century — Polynesians settle [[Auckland Islands]] (50° S)<ref>O'Connor, Tom ''Polynesians in the Southern Ocean: Occupation of the Auckland Islands in Prehistory'' in New Zealand Geographic 69 (September–October 2004): 6–8</ref><ref>Anderson, Atholl J., & Gerard R. O'Regan ''To the Final Shore: Prehistoric Colonisation of the Subantarctic Islands in South Polynesia'' in ''Australian Archaeologist: Collected Papers in Honour of Jim Allen'' Canberra: Australian National University, 2000. 440–454.</ref><ref>Anderson, Atholl J., & Gerard R. O'Regan ''The Polynesian Archaeology of the Subantarctic Islands: An Initial Report on Enderby Island'' Southern Margins Project Report. Dunedin: Ngai Tahu Development Report, 1999</ref><ref>Anderson, Atholl J. ''Subpolar Settlement in South Polynesia'' Antiquity 79.306 (2005): 791–800</ref> * 1501–1502 — [[Gonçalo Coelho]] and [[Amerigo Vespucci]] potentially sail to (52° S) * 1522 — [[Ferdinand Magellan]] – first [[circumnavigation]] discovers [[Strait of Magellan]] (54° S) * 1578 — [[Francis Drake]] discovers [[Drake Passage]] * 1599 — [[Dirk Gerritsz]] – potentially sails to (64° S) * 1603 — [[Gabriel de Castilla]] – potentially sails to (64° S) * 1615 — [[Jacob le Maire]] and [[Willem Schouten]] first to sail around [[Cape Horn]] cross (56° S) * 1619 — [[Garcia de Nodal expedition]] – circumnavigate [[Tierra del Fuego]] and discover [[Diego Ramirez Islands]] ({{coord|56|30|S|68|43|W}}) * 1675 — [[Anthony de la Roché]] discovers [[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands|South Georgia]] ({{coord|54|15|00|S|36|45|00|W|}}), the first ever land discovered south of the [[Antarctic Convergence]] * 1698–1699 — [[Edmond Halley]] sails to (52° S) * 1720 — [[Captain George Shelvocke]] – sails to (61° 30′ S) * 1739 — [[Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier]] – discovers [[Bouvet Island]] ({{coord|54|26|S|3|24|E|}}) * 1771 — [[James Cook]] – [[HM Bark Endeavour]] expedition * 1771–1772 — [[French Antarctic Expedition|First French Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec]] discovers [[Kerguelen Islands]] ({{coord|49|15|S|69|35|E|}}) * 1772–1775 — [[James Cook]] – sails [[HMS Resolution (Cook)|HMS Resolution]] crossing [[Antarctic Circle]] in January 1773 and December 1773. On 30 January 1774 he reaches 71° 10′ S, his [[Farthest South]], coming within about 75 miles of the Antarctic mainland without seeing it.
==19th century== * 1780s to 1839 — American and British whalers and sealers make incidental discoveries * 1819 — [[William Smith (mariner)|William Smith]] discovers [[South Shetland Islands]] ({{coord|62|00|S|058|00|W|}}), the first land discovered south of 60° south latitude. * 1819 — [[San Telmo (ship)|San Telmo]] wrecks in the [[Drake Passage]] off [[Livingston Island]] * 1819–1821 — [[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen]] and [[Mikhail Lazarev]], Admirals of Russian Imperial Navy, during Russian circumnavigation expedition, on 27 January 1820, discovers an [[ice shelf]] at [[Princess Martha Coast]] that later became known as the [[Fimbul Ice Shelf]] ({{coord|69|21|28|S|2|14|50|W|}}). '''Bellingshausen and Lazarev became the first explorers to see and officially discover the land of Antarctica.''' * 1820 — [[Edward Bransfield]] with [[William Smith (mariner)|William Smith]] as his pilot – on 30 January 1820, sight [[Trinity Peninsula]] ({{coord|63|37|S|058|20|W|}}). * 1820 — [[Nathaniel Palmer]] sights Antarctica on 17 November 1820 * 1821 — [[George Powell (sealer)|George Powell]], a British sealer, and [[Nathaniel Palmer|Nathaniel B. Palmer]], an American sealer, discover the [[South Orkney Islands]]. Powell annexes them for the British. * 1821 — [[John Davis (sealer)|John Davis]] – on 7 February 1821 disputed claim of setting foot on Antarctica at [[Hughes Bay]] ({{coord|64|13|S|61|20|W|}}) * 1823–1824 — [[James Weddell]] discovers the [[Weddell Sea]]; – on 20 February 1823 his ship ''Jane'' (160 tons) reached a new [[Farthest South]] of 74° 15′ S ({{coord|74|15|S|30|12|W|}}) * 1830–1833 — [[Southern Ocean Expedition]] led by [[John Biscoe]], an English sealer; circumnavigates the continent, sets foot on [[Anvers Island]], names and annexes [[Graham Land]], discovers [[Biscoe Islands]], [[Adelaide Island|Queen Adelaide Island]] ({{coord|67.25|S|68.5|W|}}) and sights [[Enderby Land]] ({{coord|67|30|S|53|0|E|}}) * 1837–1840 — [[French Antarctic Expedition|Second French Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Jules Dumont d'Urville]]; discovers [[Adelie Land]] and sets foot on an [[Débarquement Rock|islet]] of [[Geologie Archipelago]] ({{coord|66|36|19|S|140|4|0|E|source:GNIS}}) 4 km from the mainland to take mineral and animal samples (66° S) * 1838–1839 — [[John Balleny]] discovers [[Balleny Islands]] ({{coord|66|55|S|163|45|E|}}) * 1838–1842 — [[United States Exploring Expedition]] – led by [[Charles Wilkes]] to [[Antarctic Peninsula]] ({{coord|69|30|S|065|00|W|}}) and eastern Antarctica; discovers "Termination Barrier" ("Shackleton Ice Shelf") * 1839–1843 — [[James Clark Ross]]'s [[Ross expedition|expedition of 1839 to 1843]] discovered the [[Ross Ice Shelf]], [[Ross Sea]], [[Mount Erebus]], [[Mount Terror (Antarctica)|Mount Terror]] and [[Victoria Land]]; extended his [[Farthest South]] to 78° 10′ S on 23 January 1842 * 1851–1853 — [[Mercator Cooper]] landed on what is now known as [[Oates Coast]] in what is probably the first adequately-documented landing on the mainland of Antarctica. * 1872–1876 — {{HMS|Challenger|1858|6}} under Capt. George S. Nares, becomes the first steamship to cross the Antarctic Circle; reopens the study of oceanography in the region after a 30-year gap.<ref>David McGonigalm ''Antarctica: Secrets of the Southern Continent'' Frances Lincoln Ltd., 2009 {{ISBN|0-7112-2980-5}} page 288-289</ref> * 1892–1893 — [[Carl Anton Larsen]] led the first [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] expedition to [[Antarctica]] aboard the ship [[Jason (ship)|Jason]]. Larsen became the first person to [[ski]] in Antarctica where the [[Larsen Ice Shelf]] was named after him. * 1892–1893 — [[Dundee Whaling Expedition]] discover [[Dundee Island]] ({{coord|63|30|S|055|55|W|}}) * 1893–1894 — [[Carl Anton Larsen]] led the second [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] expedition to [[Antarctica]] * 1893–1895 — [[Henryk Bull]], [[Carstens Borchgrevink]] and [[Alexander von Tunzelmann]] – set foot on Antarctica at [[Cape Adare]] * 1897–1899 — [[Belgian Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Adrien de Gerlache]]; first to winter in Antarctica * 1898–1900 — [[Southern Cross Expedition]], [[Carsten Borchgrevink]] – sails to [[Cape Adare]], winters on Antarctica and takes [[Farthest South]] on 16 February 1900 at 78° 50′ S
==20th century== * 1901–1904 — [[Discovery Expedition]] – led by [[Robert Falcon Scott]], on 30 December 1903, reached (82° 17′S) * 1901–1903 — [[Gauss expedition]] (or [[Gauss expedition|First German Antarctic Expedition]]) – led by [[Erich von Drygalski]] * 1901–1903 — [[Swedish Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Otto Nordenskjöld]] with captain [[Carl Anton Larsen]] * 1902–1904 — [[Scottish National Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[William Speirs Bruce]] * 1903–1905 — [[French Antarctic Expedition|Third French Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Jean-Baptiste Charcot]] * 1907–1909 — [[Nimrod Expedition]] – On 9 January 1909, [[Ernest Shackleton]] reached 88° 23 ′S ([[Farthest South]]), and on 16 January 1909, Professor [[Edgeworth David]] reached the [[South Magnetic Pole]] at ({{coord|72|25|S|155|16|E}}) (mean position) * 1908–1910 — [[French Antarctic Expedition|Fourth French Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Jean-Baptiste Charcot]] * 1910–1912 — [[Japanese Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Nobu Shirase]] * 1910–1912 — '''[[Amundsen's South Pole expedition|Roald Amundsen's South Pole expedition]]''' – On 14 December 1911, reached the [[South Pole]] (90° S) * 1910–1913 — [[Terra Nova Expedition]] – On 17 January 1912, [[Robert Falcon Scott]], reached the [[South Pole]] (90° S) * 1911–1913 — [[Second German Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Wilhelm Filchner]] * 1911–1914 — [[Australasian Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Douglas Mawson]] * 1914–1916 — [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] – led by [[Ernest Shackleton]] * 1914–1917 — [[Ross Sea Party]] – led by [[Aeneas Mackintosh]] * 1920–1922 — British Graham Land Expedition - a British expedition to [[Graham Land]] led by John Lachlan Cope * 1921–1922 — [[Shackleton-Rowett Expedition]] – led by [[Ernest Shackleton]] – the last expedition of the [[Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration]] * 1929–1931 — [[British Australian and New Zealand Antarctic Research Expedition]] (BANZARE) – led by [[Douglas Mawson]] * 1928–1930 — [[Richard Evelyn Byrd]] – First expedition * 1931 — [[H. Halvorsen]] – discovered [[Princess Astrid Coast]] * 1931 — [[Hjalmar Riiser-Larsen]] – flew over Antarctica, discovered [[Prince Olav Coast|Kronprins Olav Kyst]] * 1933–1935 — [[Richard Evelyn Byrd]] – Second expedition * 1933–1939 — [[Lincoln Ellsworth]] – Aircraft expedition * 1934–1937 — [[British Graham Land Expedition]] (BGLE) – led by [[John Riddoch Rymill]] * 1936 — [[Lars Christensen]] – dropped Norwegian flag over [[Prince Harald Coast]] * 1938 — [[Third German Antarctic Expedition]] ([[New Swabia]], or ''[[New Swabia|Neuschwabenland]]'', claimed for [[Nazi Germany]]) – led by Capt. [[Alfred Ritscher]] * 1939–1941 — [[United States Antarctic Service Expedition]] – led by [[Richard Evelyn Byrd]] (Byrd's third expedition) * 1943–1945 — [[Operation Tabarin]] – led by Lieutenant Dubovtsev * 1986–1988 — [[32nd Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] — led by V.Klokov, V.Vovk * 1987 — [[Iceberg B-9]] calves and carries away [[Little America (exploration base)|Little America]]s I – III * 1987–1989 — [[33rd Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] — led by N.A.Kornilov, Yu.A.Khabarov * 1987–1988 — [[First Bulgarian Antarctic Expedition]] — [[St. Kliment Ohridski Base]] established * 1988–1990 — [[34th Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] — led by S.M.Pryamikov, L.V.Bulatov * 1989–1990 — Antarctic crossing on foot by Reinhold Messner and Arved Fuchs.{{fact|date=February 2018}} * 1989–1990 — [[1990 International Trans-Antarctica Expedition]] — led by American [[Will Steger]] and Frenchman [[Jean-Louis Étienne]], first un-mechanized crossing * 1989–1991 — [[35th Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] — led by V.M.Piguzov * 1990 — [[1st North Korean Antarctic Expedition]]<ref name="Hoare2012">{{cite book|last=Hoare|first=James E.|title=Historical Dictionary of Democratic People's Republic of Korea|chapter=Antarctic Exploration|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rh5h4bZgkhEC&pg=PA44|date=2012|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Lanham|isbn=978-0-8108-7987-4|page=44}}</ref> * 1990–1991 — [[2nd North Korean Antarctic Expedition]]<ref name="Hoare2012"/> * 1991–1992 — [[36th Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] — led by [[Lev Savatyugin]] * 1992–1993 - American Women's Antarctic Expedition- AWE. First team of Women to ski to the South Pole: Ann Bancroft, Sunniva Sorby,Anne DalVera, Sue Giller- 67 days * 1992–1993 — [[British Polar Plod]] — led by [[Ranulph Fiennes]] with [[Mike Stroud (physician)]], first unassisted expedition crossing the continent by ski, (2,173 km in 95 days) * 1992–1993 — [[Erling Kagge]], first unassisted, and first solo expedition to the South Pole by ski, (1,310 km in 53 days) * 1992–1993 — [[Antarctic Environmental Research Expedition]] — led by [[Kenji Yoshikawa]] * 1994 — [[Liv Arnesen]], first unassisted woman to the South Pole by ski, (1,200 km in 50 days) * 1994 - Cato Zahl Pedersen (Norway) becomes the first person with no arms to ski to the South Pole (1400 km from Berkner Island), together with Lars Ebbesen and Odd Harald Hauge * 1995 — “A Pole at the Poles” – [[Marek Kamiński]] solo expedition to the South Pole from [[Berkner Island]] (1,400 km in 53 days); * 1995-1996 - Bernard Voyer and Thierry Pétry unassisted expedition to the South Pole by ski * 1996 — [[Lake Vostok]] discovered * 1996/97 — “Solo TransAntarctica” – [[Marek Kamiński]] attempted solo crossing of Antarctica (1,450 km);
==21st century== *2000-2001- Norwegian Liv Arnesen and the American Ann Bancroft crossed Antarctica on ski-sail from Blue 1 Runaway November 13th reaching after 94 days of expedition McMurdo, passing through the South Pole. <ref> No Horizon is so far. Two women and their historic journey across Antarctica. Liv Arnesen, Ann Bancroft & Cheryl Dahle. Penguin Books. </ref> * 2001/2 - First and longest sea kayak expedition by New Zealanders Graham Charles, Marcus Waters and Mark Jones paddle unsupported from Hope Bay to Adelaide Island in 35 days. * 2004 — Scot100 First ever Scottish Expedition to South Pole <ref>http://v1.explorapoles.org/UK/Whos/PT_M-N/Mathieson_Craig.htm</ref> began in October 2004 - a century after a historic expedition led by [[William Speirs Bruce]], Edinburgh's "unknown" explorer, who [[Craig Mathieson (polar explorer)|Craig Mathieson]] views as "truly the greatest polar explorer of all time". * 2004 — Together to the Pole - a Polish four-man expedition led by [[Marek Kamiński]], with [[Jan Mela]] (a teenage double [[amputation|amputee]], who in the same year reached also the [[North Pole]]) * 2004–2005 — [[Chilean South Pole Expedition]]. * 2004–2005 — [[Tangra 2004/05]] created [[Camp Academia]]. * 2005 — [[Ice Challenger Expedition]] travelled to the South Pole in a six-wheeled vehicle.<ref>[http://www.icechallenger.co.uk/ IceChallenger.co.uk<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008144519/http://www.icechallenger.co.uk/ |date= 8 October 2008 }}, 2005. Retrieved on 2008-10-14{{Self-published source|date=March 2013}}</ref> * 2005–2006 — [[Spanish Trans-Antarctic Expedition]], led by Ramon Larramendi, reached the [[Southern Pole of Inaccessibility]] using kite-sleds.<ref>[http://www.tierraspolares.es/transantartica_ing.php Tierraspolared.es], Transantarctica 2005–06 at Tierras Polares {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207072609/http://www.tierraspolares.es/transantartica_ing.php |date=7 February 2008 }}</ref> *2006 [[Hannah McKeand]] sets coast-to-pole solo/unsupported record of 39 days, 9 hours and 33 minutes<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/dec/30/uknews2.mainsection2|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 December 2006 |title=Woman treks alone to South Pole in 39 days|author= Aislinn Simpson|accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref> * 2006-2007 — Jenny and [[Ray Jardine]] 57-day ski trek to South Pole <ref>http://www.rayjardine.com/adventures/2006-SouthPole/index.htm</ref> * 2007 — [[Pat Falvey]] leads an Irish team to reach the South Pole, skiing 1140 km only weeks after completing an unsupported Ski traverse of the Greenland Ice Cap in August 2007 in honour of Irish Polar Explorers such as Shakelton and Tom Crean. Clare O'Leary becomes the first Irish female to reach the South Pole. * 2007–2008 — [[Norwegian-U.S. Scientific Traverse of East Antarctica]].<ref>[http://traverse.npolar.no/ Traverse.npolar.no]{{Self-published source|date=March 2013}}</ref> * 2007–2008 — British Army Antarctic Expedition 2007–2008 <ref>[http://elements.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/reprint/4/5/354.pdf Conor J. Ryan ''Joys and Hardships of Antarctic Fieldwork'', retrieved 2011 Aug 24]</ref> *2008 — [[Todd Carmichael]] sets coast-to-pole solo/unsupported record of 39 days, 7 hours and 49 minutes<ref>{{citation|title=Todd Carmichael, American|last=Martin|first=Peter|journal=Esquire|date=Dec 2011|page=202|url=http://www.esquire.com/features/americans-2011/todd-carmichael-1211|accessdate=2013-03-13}}</ref> * 2008 — [[First Venezuelan Scientific Expedition to Antarctica]]. * 2008–2009 — Impossible 2 Possible (i2P) unsupported South Pole quest by [[Ray Zahab]], [[Kevin Vallely]] and [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]].<ref>[http://www.southpolequest.com/ Southpolequest.com]{{Self-published source|date=March 2013}}</ref> * 2009 — [[Azerbaijan Scientific Expedition]] * 2009 — [[Kaspersky Commonwealth Antarctic Expedition]], largest and most international group of women to ski to South Pole. * 2009 — [[Second Venezuelan Scientific Expedition to Antarctica]]. * 2009−2010 — Unsupported/Unassisted Antarctica Ski Traverse from Berkner Island to South Pole to Ross Sea by [[Cecilie Skog]] and Ryan Waters. * 2010 — Moon Regan Transantarctic Crossing, first wheeled transantarctic crossing and first [[biofuel|bio-fuelled]] vehicle to travel to the South Pole.<ref>[http://www.transantarcticexpedition.com/ Moon Regan transantarctic crossing]{{Self-published source|date=March 2013}}</ref> * 2010 — [[Third Venezuelan Scientific Expedition to Antarctica]]. * 2011 — [[Fourth Venezuelan Scientific Expedition to Antarctica]]. * 2011−2012 — From Novolazarevskaya to Pole of Inaccessibility to South Pole to Hercules inlet by [[Sebastian Copeland]] and Eric McNair Landry by kites and skis.<ref>http://www.explorersweb.com/polar/news.php?id=20632</ref> * 2011−2012 — [[British Services Antarctic Expedition 2012]]<ref>[http://www.bsae2012.co.uk/ BSAE 2012 - Spirit of Scott{{Self-published source|date=March 2013}}</ref> * 2011-2012 – Expedition by [[Ramón Hernando de Larramendi|Ramon Hernando de Larramendi]], by [[Inuit WindSled]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://greenland.net/windsled/|title=Inuit WindSled|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * 2012 — [[Felicity Aston]] becomes the first person to ski alone across [[Antarctica]] using only personal muscle power, as well as the first woman to cross Antarctica alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rdasia.com/long-days-journey-into-white/ |title=Long Day's Journey into White | Adventure |publisher=Reader's Digest Asia |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Michael Warren |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/skier-felicity-aston-sets-antarctic-record-becomes-first-woman-to-cross-continent-alone/article2311401/ |title=First woman to cross Antarctica solo sets two records |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date= |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> Her journey began on 25 November 2011, at the [[Leverett Glacier]], and continued for 59 days and a distance of 1,084 miles (1,744 kilometers).<ref name=ESPN>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/olympics/crosscountry/story/_/id/7492378/british-adventurer-felicity-aston-caps-first-ski-crossing-antarctica-woman |title=British adventurer Felicity Aston caps first ski crossing of Antarctica by woman |publisher=ESPN |date=2012-01-23 |accessdate=2012-01-28}}</ref> * 2012 — [[Fifth Venezuelan Scientific Expedition to Antarctica]]. * 2012−2013 — Aaron Linsdau becomes the second American to ski solo from the Hercules Inlet to the South Pole. His original plan was to make a round trip but through a series of problems, like all other expeditions this year, was unable to make the return journey.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Antarctic-Tears-Determination-adversity-pursuit-ebook/dp/B00LLIQBRQ/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1413900625&sr=8-1&keywords=antarctic+tears Antarctic Tears, Sastrugi Press, 2014]</ref> * 2012 — [[Eric Larsen (Polar Explorer)|Eric Larsen]] attempts a bicycle ride from coast to South Pole. Completes a quarter of the distance. * 2012 — [[Grant Korgan (Extreme Athlete)|Grant Korgan]] becomes the first person with a spinal cord injury to literally "push" himself to the geographic South Pole!<ref>http://www.thepushison.com</ref><ref>http://xgames.espn.com/xgames/skiing/article/9926125/sit-skier-grant-korgan-pushed-way-antarctica</ref><ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/paralyzed-nevada-man-grant-korgan-reaches-south-pole-article-1.1008718</ref><ref>http://www.sfgate.com/outdoors/article/Paralyzed-athlete-Grant-Korgan-achieves-polar-goal-2803082.php</ref><ref>http://www.choosepositivitynow.com/</ref> * 2012−2013 — Shackleton's centenary re-enactment expedition of the journey of the ''James Caird'' aboard the replica ''Alexandra Shackleton''. Six British and Australian Explorers completed the "double journey" on 10 February 2013 after the 800-mile journey from Elephant Island to South Georgia and the mountain crossing.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.shackletonepic.com|title=Shackleton Epic}}{{Self-published source|date=March 2013}}</ref> * 2013 — [[Sixth Venezuelan Scientific Expedition to Antarctica]]. * 2013–2014 — [[Ben Saunders (explorer)|Ben Saunders]] and [[Tarka L'Herpiniere]] make the first ever completion of the [[Terra Nova Expedition]] first taken by [[Robert Falcon Scott]] in January 1912. Their 1,801-mile, 105-day return journey to the South Pole is the longest ever polar journey on foot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scottexpedition.com/ |title=The Scott Expedition}}</ref> * 2013 — [[Parker Liautaud]] and Douglas Stoup attempt in December 2013 the [[Willis Resilience Expedition]] <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.willis.com/Media_Room/Press_Releases_%28Browse_All%29/2013/20130819_Willis_Media_Pack/|title=Willis Resilience Expedition}}</ref> to set a "coast to Pole" speed record <ref>{{cite news|author=Explorersweb |url=http://www.explorersweb.com/polar/news.php?id=19887 |title=Breaking news: Christian Eide bags the South Pole solo speed ski world record |publisher=explorersweb.com |date=2011-01-13 |accessdate=2011-01-13}}</ref> by reaching the geographical [[South Pole]] on skis in the fastest miles per hour ever recorded from an interior of continent start while being followed by a support vehicle. * 2013 — [[Antony Jinman]] will walk to the South Pole solo for the 2013 ETE Teachers South Pole Mission, during which he will be in daily contact with schoolchildren from across the United Kingdom and will make films using the world's first drone flights at the South Pole. * 2013 — [http://www.marialeijerstam.com/ Maria Leijerstam] becomes the first person to cycle from the Antarctic coast to South Pole. She also set the human powered speed record in 10 days, 14 hours and 56 minutes. * 2013−14 — Lewis Clarke (aged 16 years and 61 days) guided by Carl Alvey (aged 30) became the youngest person to trek from the Antarctic coast at Hercules Inlet to the South Pole. His expedition was in support of the Prince's Trust and his achievement is recognised by Guinness World Records. *2013-14 — Married couple Christine (Chris) Fagan and Marty Fagan became the first American married couple (and second married couple in history) to complete a full unguided, unsupported, unassisted ski from the Antarctic coast to the South Pole. They join just over 100 people in history who have traveled to the South Pole in this manner. Their expedition took 48 days. Their achievement is recognized by Guinness World Records. Learn more at www.3belowzero.com and www.christinefagan.com. A book about the expedition is forthcoming. * 2013−14 — [[Daniel P. Burton]] completes the first bicycle ride from coast to the South Pole. * 2013−14 — [[Chris Turney]] led an expedition, entitled "[[Spirit of Mawson]]", aimed at highlighting the decline in sea ice due to [[climate change]]. The expedition was abandoned when its Russian ship became stuck in unusually large amounts of sea ice. * 2013 — In December 2013 the Expeditions 7 Team led by Scott Brady made a successful east-to-west crossing in four-wheel drive vehicles from Novolazarevskaya to the Ross Ice Shelf via the Scott-Amundsen South Pole Station. Expeditions 7’s logistic plan included providing assistance to the [[Walking With The Wounded]] expedition, which was required at latitude 88°S. From the Ross Ice Shelf the Expeditions 7 team returned to Novolazarevskaya via the same route. * 2015−16 — [[Henry Worsley (explorer)|Henry Worsley]] died while attempting to complete the first solo and unaided crossing of the Antarctic.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-35398552</ref> * 2016−17 — [[Spear17]], a six-man team from the British Army Reserves successfully completed a full traverse of Antarctica. They set off on 16 November from Hercules Inlet, arrived at the South Pole on Christmas Day, and completed a full traverse reaching Ross Ice Shelf on 20 January 2017. The aim of the expedition was to raise the profile of the army reservists, and to honour the memory of fellow explorer Henry Worsley. The team was led by Capt [http://www.lourudd.com Lou Rudd MBE] <ref>http://www.spear17.org</ref> * 2016−17 — February 7 [[Mike Horn]] completes first ever solo, unsupported north-to-south traverse of Antarctica from the Princess Astrid Coast (lat -70.1015 lon 9.8249) to the Dumont D'urville Station (lat -66.6833 lon 139.9167) via the South Pole. He arrived at the pole on February 7, 2017. A total distance of 5100 km was covered utilizing kites and skis in 57 days.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20170213205338/http://www.illustre.ch/news/mike-horn-dompte-lantarctique-en-solitaire</ref> * 2017-2018 - Astrid Forhold (Norway), supported by Jan Sverre Sivertsen, skies the longest part of the original [[Roald Amundsen]] route from Bay of Whales to the South Pole.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
==Agreements== * 1959 — [[Antarctic Treaty System]] * 1964 — [[Agreed Measures for the Conservation of Antarctic Fauna and Flora]] * 1978 — [[Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals]] * 1982 — [[Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources]] * 1988 — [[Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities]] * 1998 — [[Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty]]
==See also== {{portal|Antarctica}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Arctic exploration]] * [[European and American voyages of scientific exploration]] * [[Farthest South]] * [[Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration]] * [[History of Antarctica]] * [[History of research ships]] * [[List of Arctic expeditions]] * [[List of polar explorers]] * [[List of Russian explorers]] * [[Research stations in Antarctica]] {{div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==References== * {{cite book |last1=Savatyugin|first1= L. M. |last2=Preobrazhenskaya |first2=M. A. |script-title=ru:Российские исследования в Антарктике|language=Russian|trans-title= Russian Exploration of Antarctica|year=1999 |publisher=Gidrometeoizdat, Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute (AARI), Federal Service for Hydrometeorology and Environmental Monitoring of Russian Federation (Roshydromet) |location=Saint Petersburg |isbn=5-286-01265-5 }} * {{cite journal |year=1958–1974 |title=Soviet Antarctic Expedition |journal=Information Bulletin |location= Amsterdam|publisher=Elsevier Pub. Co |issn=0038-5271}}
==Further reading== * Headland, Robert K. (1990). ''Chronological List of Antarctic Expeditions and Related Historical Events''. [[Cambridge University Press]]. {{ISBN|0-521-30903-4}} * Landis, Marilyn J. (2003). ''Antarctica: Exploring the Extreme: 400 Years of Adventure''. Chicago Review Press. {{ISBN|1-55652-480-3}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070304180148/http://www.fram.museum.no/en/default.asp?page=159 Fram.museum.no], map of Antarctic Expeditions 1772 – 1931 at [[Fram Museum|The Fram Museum (Frammuseet)]] * [http://www.spri.cam.ac.uk/resources/expeditions/ SPRI.cam.ac.uk], index to Antarctic Expeditions at the Scott Polar Research Institute's website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080209004029/http://www.antarctica.ac.uk/bas_research/data/access/bedmap/database/bibliography.html Antarctic Expeditions], information about some of them from the British Antarctic Survey * [http://www.antarctic-circle.org/timeline.htm Antarctic-circle.org], Chronologies and Timelines of Antarctic Exploration * [http://www.thingsmadethinkable.com/item/antarctic_exploration_timeline.php Antarctic Exploration Timeline], animated map of Antarctic exploration and settlement * Listen to Ernest Shackleton describing his 1908 [http://aso.gov.au/titles/spoken-word/my-south-polar-expedition/ South Pole Expedition], and read more about the recording on [australianscreen online]. * The recording describing Shackleton's 1908 South Pole Expedition was added to the [[National Film and Sound Archive]]'s [https://www.webcitation.org/5yfQQLGOQ?url=http://nfsa.gov.au/collection/national-collection/sound/sounds-australia/complete-list/ Sounds of Australia Registry] in 2007 * [http://www.portlandmonthly.com/portmag/2012/10/working-class-hero/ Before she’s lost to decay on the West Coast, former Antarctica researchers in Maine want to save their storied 'Hero']. Portland Magazine. 8 November 2012
{{Portalbar|Antarctica}} {{Antarctica}} {{Polar exploration |state=uncollapsed}}

revision.comment: /* Search engine */ removed "myhubsarethebest" -> "Showing results for: ducksarethebest" unreferenced apparently normal spell checking behaviour
revision.text: {{active editnotice}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} The technology company '''Google''' "prides itself on being a playful company" and has added '''Easter eggs''' and [[List of Google April Fools' Day jokes|April Fools' Day jokes and hoaxes]] into many of [[List of Google products|its products and services]], such as [[Google Search]], [[YouTube]], and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] since at least 2000.{{Cite book|title=Being A Teen Hacker.: A Beginners Guide To Ethical Hacking & Computer Security Awareness. VOL-I|page=95|author=Hariom Choudhary|date=April 3, 2014}} [[Easter egg (media)|Easter eggs]] are hidden features or messages, [[inside jokes]], and cultural references inserted into media. They are often well hidden, so that users find it gratifying when they discover them, helping form bonds between [[Google]] and its users. The Easter eggs are sometimes created by employees during their [[20% time]]. Google avoids adding Easter eggs to popular search pages, as they do not want to negatively impact usability.{{cite web|last1=Mitchell|first1=Jon|title=How A Google Engineer Built A Universe In An Easter Egg - ReadWrite|url=https://readwrite.com/2012/10/05/how-a-google-engineer-built-a-universe-in-an-easter-egg/|website=ReadWrite|access-date=December 22, 2017|date=October 5, 2012}}{{cite web|last1=Wiley|first1=Jon|title=Hidden Meaning|url=https://www.thinkwithgoogle.com/intl/en-gb/articles/hidden-meaning.html|website=Think with Google|access-date=March 25, 2017|language=en-gb|date=July 2012}} [[File:Google Maps "Mordor" easter egg.png|thumb|An [[#Google Maps and Google Earth|Easter egg]] in [[Google Maps]] warned users asking for walking directions from "[[Shire (Middle-earth)|The Shire]]" to "[[Mordor]]" that they should "Use caution – [[One does not simply walk into Mordor]]."]] == Search engine == {{Further|Google Search}} {{A note}} As Google searches are [[case insensitive]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.labnol.org/internet/search/case-sensitive-google-search/6279/|website=labnol.org|title=Perform Case Sensitive Search with Google|first=Amit|last=Agarwal|date=July 15, 2012|access-date=October 21, 2018}} search terms are listed in [[lower case]] except where case sensitivity is explicitly referenced. A Google web search for: * "a long time ago in a galaxy far far away" resulted in the same tilted, scrolling style that the introductions to the original ''[[Star Wars]]'' movies were presented in.{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Chris|title=Spectacular Google easter egg pays homage to ''Star Wars'' opening crawl|website=Mashable|date=November 24, 2015|url=http://mashable.com/2015/11/23/google-long-time-ago/|access-date=December 29, 2015}} This included the music, which was muted but could be heard by clicking on or selecting the muted speaker icon on the page. However, this apparently no longer worked as of June 28, 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://productforums.google.com/forum/#!topic/websearch/y1UAq0p1Drs|title=Google Groups|website=productforums.google.com|access-date=June 27, 2017}} * "{{see it|anagram}}" shows "Did you mean: ''nag a ram''".{{Cite web|url=http://googlesystem.blogspot.ro/2010/07/googles-anagram-easter-egg.html|title=Google's Anagram Easter egg|website=googlesystem.blogspot.ro}} ** "{{see it|define anagram}}" shows "Did you mean: ''nerd fame again''".{{Cite web|url=http://www.makeuseof.com/tag/ten-google-easter-eggs-missed-somehow/|title=Ten Google Easter Eggs You Missed Somehow|access-date=August 19, 2016}} ** "anagram" and "define anagram" also work in other languages. For example, a Google ES search for "{{H:title|anagram|anagrama}}" shows {{H:title|Did you mean: frog range|Quizás quisiste decir: ''gama rana''}}".{{cite web|last1=Tejerina|first1=Laura|title=Los 10 trucos más divertidos que esconde el buscador de Google|url=https://www.tuexperto.com/2016/04/13/los-10-trucos-mas-divertidos-que-esconde-el-buscador-de-google/|website=tuexperto.com|language=Spanish|date=April 13, 2016|trans-title=The 10 funniest tricks that Google's search engine hides}} * "{{see it|askew}}" causes and "tilt" once caused the results page to be tilted, leaning down, left to right.{{cite news|last1=Granger|first1=Lauren|title=13 more of the coolest hidden Google tricks|url=http://memeburn.com/2012/05/13-more-of-the-coolest-hidden-google-tricks/|access-date=July 7, 2015|agency=Memeburn|date=May 24, 2012}}{{Cite web|url=http://feedsyouneed.com/google-easter-eggs-google-tricks/|title=15+ Best Google Easter Eggs & Google Tricks 2016|website=feedsyouneed.com|author=Azar Roshan|access-date=March 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170805055813/http://feedsyouneed.com/google-easter-eggs-google-tricks|archive-date=August 5, 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}} * "{{see it|bletchley park}}" shows the name of [[Bletchley Park|the attraction]] being decoded in the [[Knowledge Graph]].{{Cite web|website=Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/bletchley-park-google-easter-egg-wraps-enigma-site-s-search-results-up-in-code-9940769.html|title=Bletchley Park: Google easter egg wraps Enigma site’s search results up in code}} * "{{see it|}}", "blink tag", or "blink html" includes samples of the [[blink element]] in the results.{{cite web|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2226404/software/google-easter-egg-leads-to-story-behind--blink--tag.html|title=Google Easter Egg Leads to Story Behind 'Blink' Tag|last=McNamara|first=Paul|website=NetworkWorld.com|publisher=Network World|date=February 24, 2014|access-date=January 20, 2015}} * "[[christmas]]{{See it|term=christmas}}", "[[hanukkah]]{{See it|term=hanukkah}}", and "[[kwanzaa]]{{See it|term=kwanzaa}}" will show decorations next to the search bar for each respective holiday. The feature is only active during the month of December. Each year, new decorations are shown.{{cite web|last1=Windle|first1=Lauren|title=What are the Google Hanukkah and Christmas 2017 themes and what other Easter Eggs have there been previously?|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tech/5070998/google-christmas-hanukkah-chanukah-theme-easter-eggs/|website=The Sun|access-date=December 15, 2017|date=December 14, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Feinn|first1=Lily|title=These Google Search Holiday Easter Eggs Are Making The Internet Super Festive|url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/198665-these-google-search-holiday-easter-eggs-are-making-the-internet-super-festive|website=Bustle|access-date=December 15, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Gesenhues|first1=Amy|title=Google wraps Hanukkah, Festivus, Christmas & Kwanzaa searches in festive holiday decor|url=https://searchengineland.com/google-wraps-hanukkah-kwanzaa-christmas-festivus-search-page-banners-usual-holiday-decor-287765|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=December 16, 2017|date=December 5, 2017}} * "{{see it|conway's game of life}}" on a desktop browser generates a running configuration of [[Conway's Game of Life|the game]] to the right of the search results. The process can also be stopped and altered by the user.{{Cite web|url=https://searchenginewatch.com/sew/news/2191362/google-easter-egg-search-conway-s-game-of-life|title=Google Easter Egg: Search "Conway’s Game of Life"|website=searchenginewatch.com}} * "{{see it|do a barrel roll}}" or "z or r twice" causes the result page to do a ''[[Star Fox]]''-style [[barrel roll]].{{cite news|title=17 amazing Google Easter eggs (1)|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/17-amazing-google-easter-eggs/|access-date=July 20, 2015}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2486825,00.asp|title=The Definitive List of Google Search Easter Eggs|newspaper=PCMAG|access-date=December 19, 2016}} * "[[drag queen]]" causes a rainbow to display next to the search results.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170907034259/https://www.lifewire.com/secret-google-easter-eggs-1616312|archivedate=September 7, 2017|url=https://www.lifewire.com/secret-google-easter-eggs-1616312|title=Secret Google Easter Eggs|website=lifewire.com|author=Marziah Karch|date=September 22, 2016|access-date=October 23, 2018}} * "{{see it|festivus}}" shows an image of the [[Festivus]] pole beside the search results and the message "A festivus miracle!" next to the number of search results.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2012/12/11/google-festivus|title=Google celebrates Festivus with 'Seinfeld'-inspired Easter Egg|website=ew.com}} * "{{see it|gay pride}}", "homosexuality", "stonewall" and other [[LGBT]] related searches, at times of [[gay pride festival]] activity, cause the results page to have a rainbow themed header.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/google-celebrates-gay-pride-with-rainbow-coloured-easter-egg|website=nationalpost.com|title=Google celebrates gay pride with rainbow-coloured Easter egg|date=June 24, 2013|access-date=June 14, 2016}} * "{{see it|google in 1998}}" on a desktop browser will generate a layout similar to the one Google used for its search engine in 1998.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/9/26/4775032/google-in-1998-search-engine-easter-egg|title='Google in 1998' Easter egg takes you to Google.com as it looked 15 years ago|website=theverge.com}} * “{{see it|is google down}}” returns with "No".{{cite web|title=The 42 best Google Easter Eggs and more…|url=https://www.seo-nerd.com/en/news-en/the-best-google-easter-eggs|website=seo-nerd|access-date=February 5, 2017}} * "{{see it|kerning}}" will add spaces between the letters of the word "kerning" in the search results. [[Kerning]] refers to the process of adjusting the space between letters in a word.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailydot.com/unclick/google-easter-eggs-tilt-kerning-binary/|title=A basketful of our favorite Google Easter eggs {{!}} The Daily Dot|date=March 29, 2013|work=The Daily Dot|access-date=November 1, 2017|language=en-US}} ** "{{see it|keming}}" will remove spaces between the letters of the word "keming". This refers to improper kerning,{{cite web|url=http://wstyler.ucsd.edu/posts/flick_bad_kerning.html|title=FLICK BAD KERNING|website=ucsd.edu|first=Will|last=Styler|date=2012|access-date=November 9, 2018}} particularly when not enough space is used between letters, which can cause mistakes like "kerning" to be read as "keming".{{cite web|url=http://theconversation.com/kerning-spacing-leading-the-invisible-art-of-typography-19699|title=Kerning, spacing, leading: the invisible art of typography|website=theconversation.com|date=November 28, 2013|access-date=November 9, 2018}} * "{{see it|}}", "marquee tag", or "marquee html" will apply the [[marquee element]] to the results count at the top of the results.{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Barry|title=The Marquee HTML Google Easter Egg|url=http://searchengineland.com/marquee-html-google-easter-egg-185153|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=March 20, 2017|date=February 25, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Memishaj|first1=Bledi|title=Google Tricks: The definitive list of Google Easter Eggs|url=https://www.gadgetdetected.com/2017/09/google-easter-eggs/|website=Gadget Detected - Tech & Startup news|access-date=November 3, 2017|date=September 19, 2017}} * "{{see it|pluto}}" describes [[Pluto]] as "Our favorite dwarf planet since 2006" in the Knowledge Graph.{{cite tweet|user=Google|number=852600619290447872|date=April 13, 2017|title=Throwback to Pluto being one of the solar system's head honchos. #GoogleEasterEggs hint: still special in our book. http://goo.gl/LB0gax}} * "{{see it|recursion}}" includes a "Did you mean: ''[[recursion]]''" link back to the same page. * "{{see it|sonic the hedgehog}}" and "green hill zone" will give a Knowledge Graph with [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)|Sonic]] waiting. Clicking on Sonic will make him jump; if clicked on 25 times,{{Failed verification|date=November 2018}} Sonic will transform into Super Sonic.{{cite web|last1=Dunn|first1=Jeff|title=21 Easter eggs hidden within your Google search bar|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/21-easter-eggs-hidden-within-your-google-search-bar-a7505821.html|website=The Independent|access-date=February 5, 2017}} * "{{see it|super mario bros}}" shows a Knowledge Graph for ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]'' that contains a flashing "?" block which generates a coin and 200 points when clicked. After 100 coins are collected, the "1UP" sound plays.{{Cite web|website=Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/google-super-mario-bros-to-get-access-to-surprise-coin-collecting-easter-egg-10499610.html|title=Google 'Super Mario Bros' to get access to surprise, coin-collecting Easter Egg}} [[File:Google webdriver torso logo static.gif|thumb|A frame from Google's webdriver torso logo. See [[:File:Google webdriver torso logo.gif|original animated image]]]] * "{{see it|text adventure}}" or "google easter eggs"{{Failed verification|date=November 2018}} using most popular modern browsers (except [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]]){{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/1/17922628/google-text-adventure-easter-egg-console|title=How to find and play Google.com’s secret adventure game|website=theverge.com|first=Jon|last=Porter|date=Oct 1, 2018|access-date=October 6, 2018}} and opening [[Web development tools|the browser's developer console]] will trigger a [[Text-based game|text-based]] [[adventure game]] playable within the console.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2018/09/29/recently-discovered-google-easter-egg-is-a-browser-based-text-adventure-game/|title=Recently discovered Google easter egg is a browser-based text adventure game|website=rockpapershotgun.com|first=Castello|last=Jay|date=September 29, 2018|access-date=October 6, 2018}}{{Cite web|last=Murphy|first=David|title=How to Play Google's Text Adventure Easter Egg in Chrome|website=Lifehacker|date=September 20, 2018|url=https://lifehacker.com/how-to-play-googles-text-adventure-easter-egg-in-chrome-1829225899|access-date=September 21, 2018}} * "{{see it|webdriver torso}}" turns the [[Google logo]] into [[Webdriver Torso|moving colored blocks]]. This is a reference to an automated YouTube channel made by Google to test YouTube's performance. This does not work on mobile devices or when there is a [[Google Doodle]] on that day.{{Cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/06/06/this-is-the-truth-behind-webdriver-torso/|title=Google and the accidental mystery of Webdriver Torso|website=engadget.com}} * "{{see it|wubba lubba dub dub}}" results in Google's Search asking "Did you mean: ''i am in great pain please help me''"{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/how-to/google-home-fun-easter-eggs-to-try/|title=40 fun Google Home Easter eggs to try|website=cnet.com|publisher=[[CNET]]|author=Taylor Martin|date=March 8, 2017|access-date=August 7, 2017|language=en}}. When using [[Google Home]] or [[Google Allo]], [[Google Assistant]] responds with "Are you in pain? How can I help?", "Sorry, I don't speak Birdperson" or "Morty, let's get Schwifty", referencing the [[Adult animation|adult animated]] [[science fiction]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Rick and Morty]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://android.gadgethacks.com/how-to/20-google-home-easter-eggs-fun-commands-0174695/|title=20 Google Home Easter Eggs & Fun Commands|website=gadgethacks.com|author=Dallas Thomas|date=January 13, 2017|access-date=August 7, 2017}} * "{{see it|zerg rush}}" causes an [[Rush (video gaming)|army of Google Os]] to attack and destroy the search results, which can be defeated by clicking on them.{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.com/pictures/secret-google-youtube-easter-eggs/5/|title=The best Google "easter eggs" hidden in plain sight (pictures)|work=ZDNet}} Once you are defeated (as victory is impossible{{cite web|last1=Kee|first1=Edwin|title=Zerg Rush decimates Google search|url=http://www.ubergizmo.com/2012/04/zerg-rush-decimates-google-search/|website=Ubergizmo|access-date=May 8, 2017}}), the Os form two Gs (GG), meaning Good Game.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/04/27/tech/web/google-zerg-rush/|date=April 27, 2012|title='Zerg rush' chews up Google search results|author=Doug Gross|website=cnn.com|publisher=CNN|access-date=May 3, 2016}} === Embedded tools === {{Further|Google Search#Special interactive features}} A Google web search for: * "{{See it|breathing exercise}}" will have a 1-minute breathing exercise.{{cite web|last1=Reisinger|first1=Don|title=5 Awesome Doodle Games for Google's 19th Anniversary|url=http://fortune.com/2017/09/27/google-doodle-best-games/|website=Fortune|access-date=February 28, 2018|language=en}} * "{{See it|bubble level}}" on a [[mobile device]] will have an interactive [[spirit level]].{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Barry|title=Google Provides An Interactive Bubble Level In Their Search Results|url=https://searchengineland.com/google-provides-an-interactive-bubble-level-in-their-search-results-238730|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=December 16, 2017|date=December 16, 2015}} * "{{See it|flip a coin}}" will flip a coin: heads or tails. * "{{See it|fun facts}}" or "i'm feeling curious" will show a fun fact. Once a search result has been given, clicking on "Ask another question" will show another question. It will show a short fact in about 1-3 sentences and a link to the website where the fact was found within a featured box at the top of the search results.{{Cite web|url=http://imfeelingcuriousblog.com/|title=I'm Feeling Curious Google Trick: Fun Facts, Boredom Buster & More|website=I'm Feeling Curious Tech|language=en-US|access-date=July 2, 2017}} * "{{see it|metronome}}" will have a [[metronome]] that can be adjusted from 40 to 220 [[Tempo|BPM]].{{cite web|last1=Gesenhues|first1=Amy|title=Google metronome in search helps musicians keep a beat|url=https://searchengineland.com/google-helps-musicians-keep-beat-metronome-tool-directly-search-244903|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=December 16, 2017|date=March 15, 2016}} * "{{see it|minesweeper}}" will allow [[Minesweeper (video game)|minesweeper]] to be played. Users can select between three modes: easy, medium and hard.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} * "{{see it|pac-man}}", "google pacman" or "play pacman" will show the [[Pac-Man]] related [[Google Pacman|interactive Google Doodle from 2010]].{{cite web|last1=Summerson|first1=Cameron|title=Google’s Best Hidden Games and "Easter Eggs"|url=https://www.howtogeek.com/260726/googles-best-hidden-games-and-easter-eggs/|website=How-To Geek|access-date=November 15, 2017}}[[File:Pacman10-hp.png|thumb|none|The initial configuration of Google's Pac-Man banner.]] * "{{see it|play dreidel}}" will spin a [[dreidel]], landing on one of four letters of the [[Hebrew alphabet]]: {{Hebrew|נ}} ([[Nun (letter)|Nun]]), {{Hebrew|ג}} ([[Gimel (letter)|Gimel]]), {{Hebrew|ה}} ([[He (letter)|He]]) or {{Hebrew|ש}} ([[Shin (letter)|Shin]]).{{cite web|last1=Gesenhues|first1=Amy|title=Google "Play Dreidel" Search Returns Digital Version Of Hanukkah Spinning Toy|url=http://searchengineland.com/google-play-dreidel-search-returns-digital-version-of-hanukkah-spinning-toy-238069|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=March 22, 2017|date=December 9, 2015}}{{cite web |title=Fun Google Easter Eggs {{!}} Do a Barrel Roll {{!}} Where is Chuck Norris |url=https://listcaboodle.com/do-a-barrel-roll-and-16-amazing-google-easter-eggs/|website=listcaboodle.com|access-date=October 20, 2018|date=October 12, 2017}} * "[[random number generator]]{{see it|term=random number generator}}" or "rng" will generate a random number between 1 and 10. Changing the maximum or minimum to a number with more than 10 digits will generate a [[List of emoticons#Western|dizzy face emoji]] 😵. Changing both the maximum and the minimum to 100 will generate a [[wikt:💯|hundred points symbol]] 💯.{{cite web|last1=Farmer|first1=Neko T.|title=Google Keeps It 100 {{!}} Google.com Easter Eggs - Eggabase|url=http://eggabase.com/websites/google/google-random-number-generator/|website=Eggabase|access-date=November 6, 2017}} * "{{see it|rgb to hex}}" will have a [[color picker]] and a [[Web colors#Converting RGB to hexadecimal|conversion between RGB and hexadecimal]] color values. Selecting "Show color values" will also show conversions to the [[CMYK]], [[HSL and HSV]] color models.{{cite web|last1=Yu|first1=Justin|title=How to use Google search to convert RGB and hex color values|url=https://www.cnet.com/how-to/how-to-use-google-search-to-convert-rgb-and-hex-color-values/|website=CNET|access-date=February 28, 2018|language=en|date=October 10, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Amy|first1=Gesenhues|title=Google puts RGB-Hex color converter in search results for "RGB to Hex" queries|url=https://searchengineland.com/google-puts-rgb-hex-color-converter-search-results-rgb-hex-queries-260832|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=February 28, 2018|date=October 10, 2016}} * "{{See it|roll a die}}" will roll a [[Dice|die]]: between 1 and 6. * "{{see it|snake}}", "play snake", "snake game" and "snake video game" will result in a "Play Snake" card. By selecting {{button|Click to Play}}, the user can play [[snake video game|the game]] on both desktop and mobile.{{cite web|last1=Gesenhues|first1=Amy|title=Google's latest Easter Egg is a video game that shows up with searches for 'snake' & 'play snake'|url=https://searchengineland.com/googles-latest-easter-egg-video-game-shows-searches-snake-play-snake-283424|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=November 1, 2017|date=September 27, 2017}} Clicking the snake after the game ends will switch it between blue to rainbow; a new game can be played with the rainbow snake.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} * "{{see it|solitaire}}" will have a playable game of solitaire. Users can select between two modes: easy and hard.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/google-search-easter-eggs-2016-8/|title=19 Easter eggs hidden within your Google search bar|access-date=August 29, 2016}} * "{{see it|spinner}}" will have an interactive spinning wheel and a [[fidget spinner]]{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2017/06/20/google-virtual-fidget-spinner-search/#.tnw_Dt95NbAM|title=Google has hidden a virtual fidget spinner simulation in search|last=Mix|date=June 20, 2017|work=The Next Web|access-date=June 27, 2017|language=en-US}} which can be toggled via the switch. For the spinning wheel, a [[dropdown menu]] can change the number of numbers on the wheel: from 2 to 20.{{cite web|last1=Gesenhues|first1=Amy|title=Google "spinner" Easter Egg returns interactive spinning wheel at top of results|url=http://searchengineland.com/google-spinner-easter-egg-returns-interactive-spinning-wheel-top-results-268175|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=March 21, 2017|date=January 26, 2017}} Whereas, for the fidget spinner, users have to mimic a rotating motion in order for the spinner to spin. * "{{see it|tic tac toe}}" will have a playable game of tic tac toe.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/google-solitaire-tic-tac-toe|title=You can now play Solitaire and Tic-Tac-Toe in Google search|last=Woollaston|first=Victoria|newspaper=WIRED UK|language=en-GB|access-date=December 3, 2016}} Users can select to be either player 1 (x) or player 2 (o). Alternatively, the user can type "shall we play a game" into the search bar.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} This phrase is a reference to the film [[WarGames]].{{OR|date=October 2018}} * "{{see it|stopwatch}}" and "{{see it|timer}}" will provide interactive timing methods; the stopwatch counting up and the timer counting down. Both tools are shown for each search term. Variants such as "set a timer for 10 minutes" can be used.{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Barry|title=Google's New Stopwatch & Timer Search Feature|url=https://searchengineland.com/googles-new-stopwatch-timer-search-feature-235728|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=January 12, 2018|date=November 11, 2015}} * "{{see it|what sound does a dog make}}" will sound out what a dog will make. The word "dog" can be replaced with other animals in the search query. ** "{{see it|animal sounds}}" picks out a random set of animals.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} ==== Google birthday surprise spinner ==== Searching for "{{see it|google birthday surprise spinner}}" will result in a wheel that spins to one of a selection of playable Google Doodles, tools ([[#Embedded tools|see above]]) and games. Whichever is randomly selected may be opened, or the wheel may be spun again. It was added in celebration of Google's 19th birthday.{{cite web|last1=Woollaston|first1=Victoria|title=Google birthday surprise spinner: The full list of 19 Doodle games (including Snake)|url=http://www.alphr.com/games/1007158/google-birthday-surprise-spinner|website=Alphr|access-date=November 4, 2017|language=en}} ==== Calculator ==== Late 2011, Google added a [[GUI|graphical]] calculator to search results.{{Cite web|website=Searchengineland|url=http://searchengineland.com/google-adds-graphical-math-calculator-to-search-results-103631|title=Google Adds Graphical Math Calculator To Search Results}}{{Cite web|website=Cnet|url=http://www.cnet.com/uk/news/go-figure-google-adds-calculator-to-search-results/|title=Go figure: Google adds calculator to search results}} By using [[natural language processing]], Google's algorithms have calculated{{Cite web|website=Research at Google|url=http://research.google.com/pubs/NaturalLanguageProcessing.html|title=Natural Language Processing}} that the result might be [[mathematic]]al in nature.{{Cite web|website=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/sep/27/google-biggest-algorithm-change-hummingbird|title=Google introduces the biggest algorithm change in three years}} Woven into this feature are several, not entirely academic, results which might be considered Easter eggs.{{cite web|title=Google Tricks #25 Tricks which google can Do for you and you never knew.|url=https://www.theboundlessweb.com/technology/google-tricks-you-never-knew-best-new-google-tricks/|website=The Boundless Web|access-date=October 8, 2016|date=September 29, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009165254/https://www.theboundlessweb.com/technology/google-tricks-you-never-knew-best-new-google-tricks/|archivedate=October 9, 2016|df=}} A Google web search for: * "{{see it|baker's dozen}}" shows the additional result "1 [[baker's dozen]] = 13" * "{{see it|once in a blue moon}}" will give the additional result of "[[Blue moon|once in a blue moon]] = 1.16699016 × 10−8 hertz".{{cite news|last=Moore|first=Matthew|title=Google easter eggs: 15 best hidden jokes|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/google/6201814/Google-easter-eggs-15-best-hidden-jokes.html|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|access-date=November 7, 2011|location=London|date=September 17, 2009}} * "the answer to [the ultimate question of] life the universe and everything{{see it|term=the answer to the ultimate question of life the universe and everything}}" provides the answer "42" as a result in reference to the [[Douglas Adams]] novel series, "[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]". It is believed to be the first Google Easter egg, predating the calculator in which it's now revealed. * "the number of horns on a [[unicorn]]{{see it|term=the number of horns on a unicorn}}" shows the number "1" on the calculator. * "{{see it|what is the loneliest number}}" shows the number = "1" in the calculator.{{cite web|title=Google Easter Eggs: 10 Different Services, Lots of Secret Jokes|website=[[NBC News|NBC]] Bay Area|date=November 24, 2010|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/tech/Google-Easter-Eggs-10-Different-Services-Lots-of-Secret-Jokes-110450369.html|access-date=January 7, 2016}} The result of multiple Easter eggs may be calculated; for example: "{{see it|the number of horns on a unicorn plus the answer to life the universe and everything}}" will return "43".{{Cite web|url=http://berrytech2013.weebly.com/20-random-fun--time-wasting-google-easter-eggs.html|website=berrytech2013.weebly.com|publisher=BerryTech|title=20 Random, Fun & Time-wasting Google Easter Eggs.|access-date=February 28, 2017}} === Image search === * A [[Google image search]] for "{{see it|site=image|atari breakout}}" starts a game of ''[[Breakout (video game)|Breakout]]'', using the gallery of image results as bricks. Once the bricks are destroyed, a random phrase is automatically searched, you will add the extra ball, and the game will restart.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/video/sciencetech/video-1008095/Googles-new-hidden-Easter-egg-Atari-Breakout-Images.html|title=Google's new hidden Easter egg. Atari Breakout in Images|access-date=June 1, 2016|website=dailymail.co.uk|publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd.}} == Google Maps and Google Earth == {{Further|Google Maps|Google Earth}} * The world of the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' spin-off film ''[[Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)|Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them]]'' may be explored with Google Street View. Visit [[New York City]] in 1926 as brought to life in the film, as well as the real locations today. Fans can visit MACUSA (Magical Congress of the USA); {{see it|site=maps|Steen National Bank, where Newt first meets Jacob Kowalski; the underground speakeasy The Blind Pig; and the magical apartment of Tina and Queenie Goldstein, two of the film’s key characters.|querystring=search/fantastic+beasts+in+new+york/@40.7284013,-74.0164877,6936m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1}}{{Cite web|website=blog.google|url=https://blog.google/topics/entertainment/ok-google-cast-your-spell/|title=Cast a spell with Google and Warner Bros. Pictures}} * Another 3D buildings Easter egg involves the famous bridge jump scene from [[The Blues Brothers (film)|''The Blues Brothers'']], which is recreated in Google Earth at the [[Tacony–Palmyra Bridge]] linking [[New Jersey]] and [[Philadelphia]]. * The [[Mars]] Feature of Google Earth allows users to speak to a primitive [[ELIZA]] clone on the planet, by searching for "Meliza".{{cite web|url=http://googlesystem.blogspot.com/2009/02/chat-with-martian-in-google-earth-5.html|work=Google system|title=Chat With a Martian in Google Earth 5|publisher=Google|date=February 3, 2009|access-date=April 18, 2012}} * On July 20, 2005, the 36th anniversary of the first human landing on the Moon, Google debuted a version of Google Maps that included a small segment of the surface of the [[Moon]]. It is based entirely on [[NASA]] images and includes only a very limited region. Panning causes the map to tile. Zooming to the closest level used to show that the Moon was made of cheese. The map also gives the locations of all [[Moon landings]], and the [[Google Moon]] FAQ humorously mentions a connection to the [[Google Copernicus Center|Google Copernicus hoax]], which Google claimed to be developing. Supposedly, by 2069, [[Google Local]] will support all lunar businesses and addresses.{{cite web|last=Haines|first=Lester |location=[[United Kingdom]]|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/07/20/google_moon/|title=Google finds sense of humor on surface of Moon|work=The Register|date=July 20, 2005|access-date=April 18, 2012}} * In Street View, on Earls Court Rd, [[London]], [[United Kingdom]], a [[TARDIS]] from the famous science fiction series ''[[Doctor Who]]'' is on display. Street View allows one to enter the {{see it|url=maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ll=51.492132,-0.192862&spn=0.007288,0.011641&sll=51.492637,-0.193680&layer=c&cid=12502927659667388442&panoid=LYc4W_m-BJQAAAQIt-IsCQ&cbp=13,121.57,,0,0&gl=US&t=m&z=17&cbll=51.492146,-0.192985|TARDIS}} where it is "Bigger on the Inside" and explore the set actually used in the show.{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/11/22/google_puts_tardis_on_street_view/|title=Google puts Dr Who's Tardis onto Street View – and you can get INSIDE|work=The Register|first=Jasper|last=Hamill|date=November 22, 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Warren|first1=Tom|title=Google Maps Easter egg transports you inside the Doctor's TARDIS|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/8/14/4620352/google-maps-street-view-tardis-doctor-who-easter-egg|website=The Verge|access-date=March 19, 2017|date=August 14, 2013}} * When navigating from [[Snowdon]] to [[Brecon Beacons]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Snowdon to Brecon Beacons|querystring=dir/?api=1&origin=Snowdon&destination=Brecon+Beacons}}, the user can choose to travel by [[Welsh Dragon|dragon]], which takes 21 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/travelling-snowdon-brecon-beacons-google-7220786|website=walesonline.co.uk|publisher=Wales Online|title=Travelling from Snowdon to the Brecon Beacons? Google says DRAGON is the fastest way to go|date=June 5, 2014|author=Alicia Melville-Smith|access-date=February 28, 2017}} * When navigating from [[Urquhart Castle]] to [[Fort Augustus]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Urquhart Castle to Fort Augustus|querystring=dir/?api=1&origin=Urquhart+Castle&destination=Fort+Augustus&travelmode=transit}}, the user can choose to travel by the [[Loch Ness Monster]], which takes 25 minutes.{{Cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/06/03/google-maps-easter-eggs-revealed-hitch-a-ride-on-the-loch-ness-monster-or-a-dragon-in-wales-4748710/|title=Google Maps Easter Eggs revealed: Hitch a ride on the Loch Ness monster|last=Metro.co.uk|first=Amy Willis for|date=June 3, 2014|website=Metro|access-date=August 1, 2017}} * When navigating from [[Magdalene College]] to [[Queens' College, Cambridge#Cloister Court|President's Lodge Queens College]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Magdalene College to President's Lodge Queens College|querystring=dir/?api=1&origin=Magdalene+College&destination=President's+Lodge+Queens+College&travelmode=transit}}, the user can choose to be punted, which takes 45 minutes.{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/patricksmith/google-maps-now-gives-you-information-for-travelling-by-drag|title=There's A Google Maps Easter Egg That Tells You To Travel By Dragon|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=August 1, 2017|language=en}} * Searching for public transportation from [[Windsor Castle]] to [[Buckingham Palace]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Windsor Castle to Buckingham Palace|querystring=dir/?api=1&origin=Windsor+Castle&destination=Buckingham+Palace&travelmode=transit}} will offer the [[Diamond Jubilee State Coach|Royal Carriage]] option.{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Barry|title=Another New Easter Egg In Google Maps: Travel By Royal Carriage|url=http://searchengineland.com/another-new-easter-egg-google-maps-travel-royal-carriage-193696|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=February 22, 2017}} * Certain navigation within the greater London area showed the as-yet unopened [[Crossrail|Crossrail (Elizabeth Line)]] in royal purple (April Fool's Day, 2016).{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} * To promote the upcoming release of ''[[Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice]]'', users could explore [[Wayne Manor|Bruce Wayne's residence]] and the [[Batcave]].{{cite web|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/batman-bruce-wayne-house-google-maps-2016-3|title=You can explore the Dark Knight's Batcave from 'Batman v Superman' on Google Maps|last=Renfro|first=Kim|date=March 25, 2016|website=business insider}} * For [[April Fools' Day]] 2015, when in certain areas in Google Maps, there was a [[Pac-Man]] button. When clicked (if one's in a suitable area for it to work), a ''Pac-Man'' game started, controlled by arrow keys, using the roads as paths for Pac-Man to go.{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencealert.com/you-can-play-pac-man-in-google-maps-right-now|title=You can play Pac-Man in Google Maps right now|author=Fiona MacDonald|work=ScienceAlert}} A similar feature was brought back for April Fools' Day 2017, allowing users to play a version of ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]'' upon clicking the icon on the Google Maps webpage or mobile app.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/31/15136848/google-maps-april-fools-ms-pac-man-easter-egg|title=Google Maps morphs into Ms. Pac-Man for April Fools’ Day|date=March 31, 2017|website=The Verge|access-date=April 1, 2017}} * In early test versions of [[Google Maps]], searching for a route between locations separated by expanses of water (e.g. [[Paris]] and New York City) provided road directions to the coast of the embarkation country (in this case, the west coast of France) before suggesting "Swim the [[Atlantic Ocean]] (3,500 miles)" or another ocean for a different distance. * While Google Maps' ''walking directions'' were in [[Software release life cycle#Beta|beta]], requesting them from the start point of "[[Shire (Middle-earth)|The Shire]]" or "[[Rivendell]]" to the destination of "[[Mordor]]", the directions returned the warning: "Use caution – One does not simply walk into Mordor."{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/12/22/google-maps-mordor-shire-hobbit-easter-egg-lord-of-the-rings_n_1164795.html|date=December 22, 2011|title=Google Maps: 'Use Caution –One Does Not Simply Walk Into Mordor'|author=Felicity Morse|website=huffingtonpost.co.uk|publisher=Huffington Post UK|access-date=April 28, 2016}} * Searching for "[[R'lyeh]]" would take users to the coordinates of the sunken city. It was listed as a "Place of worship".{{Cite web|website=geeknative.com|url=http://www.geeknative.com/21619/rlyeh-removed-from-google-maps-some-geek-alternatives/|title=R’lyeh removed from Google Maps; some geek alternatives}} * Visiting "[[Salford Lads' Club]]" with 3D buildings activated will show [[Morrissey]] of [[The Smiths]] at the entrance. The club was featured in the cover art of the Smiths' album [[The Queen Is Dead]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/1/2/2676013/morrissey-easter-egg-google-earth|title=Morrissey easter egg found in Google Earth|website=theverge.com|author=JamieKeene|date=January 2, 2012|access-date=December 15, 2017}} * On Mario Day (March 10{{Cite web|url=https://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/fun/mario-day|website=timeanddate.com|title=Fun Holiday – Mario Day|access-date=November 3, 2018}}) 2018, Google and Nintendo had partnered up to bring Mario into Google Maps mobile app worldwide for a week. A yellow icon with a question mark would show up at the bottom of the directions page, next to the start navigation button. Tapping on the icon would allow the user to have Mario and his kart as the navigation arrow. Tapping the icon 100 times would activate a 1-UP sound like in the Nintendo’s games.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/3/9/17099556/mario-google-maps-mario-day|title=Mario invades Google Maps to help you avoid bananas while driving|work=The Verge|access-date=April 3, 2018}} === Pegman === {{Further|Google Street View#Pegman}} * If the user navigates to [[Loch Ness]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Loch Ness|querystring=search/Loch+Ness}}, the lake can be seen from a street view and the Pegman looks like the Loch Ness Monster.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/4/21/8463031/google-maps-loch-ness-monster|title=Google Maps lets you search for the Loch Ness Monster from your couch|author=MicahSingleton|publisher=Vox Media|work=The Verge}} * He is given special clothing for some widely observed special occasions: for [[Halloween]] he rides a broomstick;
