for [[Valentine's Day]] he stands upon a heart; and during Christmas week, he becomes a snowman and on certain hashtags like the [https://landing.google.com/intl/en/pride/ #prideforeveryone] hashtag he gets a certain object like a rainbow cape.{{cite web|last=Spring|first=Tom|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/142620/googles_top_17_easter_eggs_gags_and_hoaxes.html|title=Google's Top 17 Easter Eggs, Gags, and Hoaxes|publisher=PC World|date=March 18, 2008|access-date=April 18, 2012}} * Around February 8, the launch day of Google Maps,{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.co.uk/about/company/history/#2005|website=google.co.uk|publisher=Google|title=Google Company: Our history in depth|access-date=June 13, 2016}} he appears dressed as a birthday cake.{{Cite web|url=https://www.seroundtable.com/photos/google-maps-pegman-birthday-cake-19904.html|website=seroundtable.com|publisher=Search Engine Roundtable|title=Google Maps Pegman Dresses Up As A Birthday Cake For 10 Year Birthday|author=Barry Schwartz|date=February 24, 2015|access-date=June 13, 2016}} * When viewing past street views, he turns into [[Emmett "Doc" Brown]], one of the [[protagonist]]s from [[Back to the Future (franchise)|the "Back to the Future" universe]].{{cite web|last1=Maine|first1=Sammy|title=How Google Maps' Back to the Future Pegman was created|url=http://www.creativebloq.com/character-design/how-google-maps-back-future-pegman-was-created-51411516|website=Creative Bloq|access-date=February 22, 2017|language=en}} * When dragged into [[Legoland California Resort|Legoland]] in [[Carlsbad, California|Carlsbad]], the Pegman turns into a [[Lego minifigure]].{{cite web|title=17 amazing Google Easter eggs|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/17-amazing-google-easter-eggs/10/|website=CBS News|access-date=February 22, 2017|language=en|date=May 7, 2015}} * When dragged into Street View in [[Sun Valley, Idaho]], he becomes a skier.{{cite web|last1=Svetlik|first1=Joe|title=Nexus Q has an easter egg! The 12 best Google secrets ever|url=http://www.electricpig.co.uk/2012/07/02/nexus-q-has-an-easter-egg-the-12-best-ever-google-secrets-ever/|website=Electricpig|access-date=February 22, 2017}} * On [[Election Day (United States)|Election Day]] the Pegman is wearing a [[Uncle Sam]]'s hat and an "I voted" button.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} * When dragged onto the vicinity of the [[Arthur Ashe Stadium]], {{see it|site=maps|term=Arthur Ashe Stadium|querystring=search/Arthur+Ashe+Stadium}} [[Flushing Meadows–Corona Park]], Pegman becomes a tennis player holding a racket.{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Susan|title=Google Maps Easter Eggs|url=http://www.learningonlineblog.com/2014/04/15/google-maps-easter-eggs/|website=Learning Online Blog|access-date=February 22, 2017|date=April 15, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223041936/http://www.learningonlineblog.com/2014/04/15/google-maps-easter-eggs|archive-date=February 23, 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}} * Dragged near the [[Kennedy Space Center]], {{see it|site=maps|term=Kennedy Space Center|querystring=search/Kennedy+Space+Center}} Pegman becomes an astronaut.{{cite web|last1=Sharrock|first1=Justine|title=Pegman:Google's Weird Art Project Hidden in Plain Sight|url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/justinesharrock/pegman-googles-weird-art-project-hidden-in-plain-sight|website=www.buzzfeednews.com|publisher=BuzzFeed|date=April 11, 2013|access-date=November 8, 2018}} * When dragging Pegman around [[Groom Lake]] in [[Nevada]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Groom Lake|querystring=search/Groom+Lake}} or [[Area 51]], {{see it|site=maps|term=Area 51 Alien Center|querystring=search/Area+51+Alien+Center}} he will turn into a UFO.{{Cite web|url=http://laughingsquid.com/google-maps-includes-a-ufo-easter-egg-at-area-51/|title=Google Maps Includes a UFO Easter Egg at Area 51|website=laughingsquid.com}} * When viewing some royal residences, such as Buckingham Palace{{see it|site=maps|term=Buckingham Palace|querystring=search/Buckingham+Palace}} (and the surrounding palaces), [[Holyrood Palace|The Palace of Holyroodhouse]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Palace of Holyroodhouse|querystring=search/Palace+of+Holyroodhouse}} and [[Hillsborough Castle]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Hillsborough Castle|querystring=search/Hillsborough+Castle}}, the Pegman turns into a representation of [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], "PegMa'am".{{Cite web|website=Best Of Smart Home Tech|url=https://bestofsmarthometech.com/2017/12/05/10-crazy-google-easter-eggs-you-never-knew-existed/|title=10 Crazy Google Easter Eggs You Never Knew Existed!}}{{cite web|last1=Haysom|first1=Sam|title=Google introduces 'PegMa'am' to honour the Queen's 63-year reign|url=http://mashable.com/2015/09/09/google-uk-queen-peg-maps|website=Mashable|access-date=December 5, 2017|language=en}} * When dragged onto [[Hawaii]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Hawaii|querystring=search/Hawaii}} or [[Florida]]{{see it|site=maps|term=Florida|querystring=search/Florida}}, the Pegman becomes a mermaid, but only when close to the ocean. The figure reverts if dragged too far inland.{{cite web|last1=Salkin|first1=Kate|title=7 Best Internet Easter Eggs from Favorite Sites|url=http://www.stephanbrady.com/blog/internet-easter-eggs/|website=Stephan & Brady|access-date=November 18, 2016}} Pegman also turns into a mermaid when dragged to the vicinity of the [[Galápagos Islands]].{{See it|querystring=search/Galapagos|site=maps|term=Galapagos Islands}}{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} * Dragging the Google Street View Pegman onto [[Telegraph Avenue]] in [[Berkeley, CA]] used to display him with a [[tie-dyed]] shirt.{{cite web|title=Google's Top 17 Easter Eggs, Gags, and Hoaxes|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/PCWorld/story?id=4478244|website=ABC News|date=March 20, 2008}} * There is a place on the southern point of [[Half Moon Island]], [[Antarctica]] that has blue ''roads''. When the Pegman was dragged on this spot, the Pegman turned into a [[penguin]] and users could explore the area as if on roads. Penguins and a research team in red [[parka]]s can be seen at various points on these roads. * For the release of ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'', the Pegman on Google Maps was a [[stormtrooper (Star Wars)|stormtrooper]] or an [[X-wing fighter]] pilot.{{cite web|url=http://www.gtricks.com/google-tricks/star-wars-easter-eggs-complete-list/|title=Complete List of Star Wars Easter Eggs on Google Products|website=gtricks.com|author=Akhil|date=December 3, 2015|access-date=February 28, 2017}} * For the release of the video game ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess HD]]'' for the [[Wii U]], the Pegman was Link holding a Master Sword and a Hylian Shield.{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2016/03/the_legend_of_zeldas_link_is_a_guest_star_on_google_maps|last=McFerran|first=Damien|title=The Legend of Zelda's Link is a guest star on Google Maps|website=Nintendo Life|access-date=March 14, 2016|date=March 4, 2016}} * For [[Google Street View]]'s 10th birthday, the Pegman appears on both Maps and Street View as if he is celebrating a birthday, wearing a red and white striped miniature party hat and holding three pastel violet, pink, and blue balloons in his right hand.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2017/06/01/does-google-street-views-pegman-have-party-hat-balloons/|title=Why does Google Street View’s 'Pegman' have a party hat and balloons?|website=telegraph.co.uk|author=Mark Molloy |date=June 1, 2017|access-date=June 1, 2017}} == Google homepage == * Rolling over the {{button|I'm Feeling Lucky}} button causes the button text to spin, landing on a random phrase. Clicking on the button without text in the search bar will serve the corresponding web page.{{cite web|last1=Schwartz|first1=Barry|title=I'm Feeling Doodly, Playful, Artistic: Google's "I'm Feeling Lucky" Button Gains New Choices|url=http://searchengineland.com/googles-rotating-im-feeling-lucky-button-130504|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=May 6, 2017|date=August 14, 2012}}{{cite web|title=See what happens when you tell Google: I'm feeling curious|url=http://www.expertreviews.co.uk/technology/1403865/see-what-happens-when-you-tell-google-im-feeling-curious|website=Expert Reviews|access-date=May 6, 2017|language=en}}{{cite web|last1=Danny|first1=Goodwin|title=Google I’m Feeling Lucky Button Adds 8 New Options|url=https://searchenginewatch.com/sew/news/2198799/google-i-m-feeling-lucky-button-adds-8-new-options|website=Search Engine Watch|access-date=January 12, 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! I'm feeling !! Result |- | Doodley || Random [[Google Doodle]] |- | Adventurous || Random Google search for fun activities{{Failed verification|date=September 2018}} |- | Artistic || Random Google art project |- | Hungry || Google search for "restaurants" |- | Puzzled || "[[A Google A Day]]" home page |- | Trendy || [[Google Trends#Google Hot Trends|Google Hot Trends]] |- | Stellar || [[Google Earth]] homepage |- | Playful || Random [[Google Doodle#Interactive and video doodles|interactive Google Doodle]] |- | Wonderful || Random "World Wonder" project |- | Generous || Google "One Today" homepage |- | Curious || Google search for "I'm Feeling Curious"{{Failed verification|date=September 2018}} |} === Google languages === Google offers interfaces for several different [[fictional languages]]. Users can set any language (except pig latin) as their preferred language in their search settings.{{cite web|title=Bork, Elmer and Other Hidden Google Language Interface|url=http://www.gtricks.com/google-tricks/bork-elmer-klingon-pirate/|website=Gtricks|access-date=March 25, 2017|date=June 20, 2010}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" |- ! Language ! URL |- | [[Pirate]] || {{see it|url=www.google.com/?hl=xx-pirate}} |- | [[Hacker]] ([[Leet]]) || {{see it|url=www.google.com/?hl=xx-hacker}} |- | [[Swedish Chef|Bork]] || {{see it|url=www.google.com/?hl=xx-bork}} |- | [[Klingon language|Klingon]] || {{see it|url=www.google.com/?hl=xx-klingon}} |- | [[Pig latin]] || {{see it|url=www.google.com/?hl=xx-piglatin}} |- | [[Elmer Fudd]] || {{see it|url=www.google.com/?hl=xx-elmer}} |} === Google subpages === [[File:Google Teapot Easter Egg.png|thumb|right|The teapot found at Google's 418 error page.]] * "www.google.com/heart" will redirect to an archived page which is a preservation of the old Google interface, complete with a banner that states "This site is an old friend from Google’s past, kept in its original form. Enjoy!" However, typing something in the search box and clicking "Google Search" will perform a search on the current Google interface. A [[Java applet]] with an interactive jumping heart shows under the Google logo on the search page. The applet was made in 2000 by [[Ken Perlin]].{{Cite web|url=http://mrl.nyu.edu/~perlin/experiments/heart/|title=Heart to Heart|website=mrl.nyu.edu|author=Ken Perlin}} * "{{see it|url=www.google.com/humans.txt}}" is a simple plain text file serving to remind its readers that Google isn't only built on technology but, is created by many humans too. It asks for interested readers to visit their careers page.{{Cite web|url=http://searchengineland.com/googles-human-text-file-google-comhuman-txt-76264|website=searchengineland.com|title=Google’s Human Text File: google.com/human.txt|author=Barry Schwartz|date=May 9, 2011|access-date=May 18, 2017}} * "www.google.com/killer-robots.txt" is a, {{Citation needed span|text=no longer accessible {{As of|2018|11|28|lc=y|df=US}}|date=November 2018|reason=}}, humorous plain text file in [[robots.txt]] format.{{Cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2014/07/03/a_killer_robots_txt_google_easter_egg.html|title=Is This a Google Easter Egg or Proof That Skynet Is Actually Plotting World Domination?|author=Lily Hay Newman|date=July 3, 2014|publisher=Slate}}. * "{{see it|url=www.google.com/teapot}}" states, "418. [[I'm a Little Teapot|I’m a teapot]]. The requested entity body is short and stout. Tip me over and pour me out." Clicking on the picture of the teapot or tilting the mobile device will result in an animation of it pouring tea into a teacup. The web page is a reference to the [[Hyper Text Coffee Pot Control Protocol]].{{Cite web|website=Searchengineland|url=http://searchengineland.com/new-google-easter-egg-seo-geeks-server-status-418-im-teapot-201739|title=New Google Easter Egg For SEO Geeks: Server Status 418, I’m A Teapot}} == Android == {{Further|Android (operating system)}} [[File:Android logo.jpg|thumb|Android Easter eggs]] * Since the version 2.3 ([[Android Gingerbread|Gingerbread]]) of Google's [[Android (operating system)|Android operating system]] an Easter egg containing an animation has been hidden. The Easter egg can be accessed through the "Settings" application, in the "About phone" section, by repeatedly tapping the "Android version" section. The animation is different in every version of the OS.TDW. [https://www.thedigitalworm.com/google-gravity-search-tricks/ "Google Gravity, Anit-Gravity and Many More Google Search Tricks"], The Digital Worm (2017) ** In 2.3 – 2.3.7 (Gingerbread) there is a painting of an Android next to a zombie [[gingerbread man]], surrounded by [[zombies]] using cellphones.{{Cite web|url=http://www.howtogeek.com/121197/4-hidden-android-easter-eggs-from-gingerbread-to-jelly-bean/|title=4 Hidden Android Easter Eggs: From Gingerbread to Jelly Bean|access-date=August 19, 2016}} ** In 3.0 – 3.2.6 ([[Android Honeycomb|Honeycomb]]) there is a blue [[honeybee]]. Below it, there is the text "REZZZZZZZ…" as a reference to ''[[Tron: Legacy]]''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} ** In 4.0 – 4.0.4 ([[Android Ice Cream Sandwich|Ice Cream Sandwich]]) there is [[pixel art]] of an [[ice cream sandwich]] android. Long-pressing it will result in many ice cream sandwich androids flying across the screen, dubbed the "nyan droid" as they are a tribute to [[Nyan Cat]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} ** In 4.1 – 4.3.1 ([[Android Jelly Bean|Jelly Bean]]) a red jelly bean appears, which if pressed will show its face along with the [[Operating system|OS]] version. If this jelly bean is then long-pressed, an interactive jelly bean mini-game will appear. This is where one can fling the jelly beans around.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} ** In 4.4 ([[Android KitKat|KitKat]]) a rotating letter "K" appears, which if continually tapped turns into the text "Android" in the styling of a KitKat logo. If the Android logo is then long-pressed or twisted with two fingers a tile interface, known as "a daydream" called "Dessert Case", loads with icons from all previous versions of Android. It appears to be a mock of the [[Windows Phone]] interface.{{cite web|title=Hidden Secret Easter Eggs and Daydreams in Google Android Devices – AskVG|url=http://www.askvg.com/hidden-secret-easter-eggs-and-daydreams-in-google-android-devices/|website=askvg|access-date=February 22, 2017|language=en}} ** In 5.x ([[Android Lollipop|Lollipop]]) and 6.x ([[Android Marshmallow|Marshmallow]]), a colored circle appears (or a circle with a stylized M inside in Marshmallow). If continuously tapped, it will turn into a [[lollipop]] with the text ''lollipop'' inside (or the M changes into a [[marshmallow]] in 6.x). Tapping the circle changes the color. When long-pressed, a game of ''[[Flappy Bird]]'' starts with the Android mascot instead. In Marshmallow, tapping the plus sign adds extra players (up to five), which can be controlled by the user or other players.{{cite web|url=http://www.androidauthority.com/android-marshmallow-easter-egg-flappy-bird-game-with-multiplayer-647378/|title=The Android 6.0 Marshmallow Easter egg is another Flappy Bird-style game, with a twist|work=Android Authority|access-date=December 29, 2015}}{{cite web|title=A Guide to Android Daydream: How to Setup and Unlock Hidden Features|url=http://techmunchie.com/a-guide-to-android-daydream-how-to-setup-and-unlock-hidden-features|website=Techmunchie|access-date=May 12, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527022012/http://techmunchie.com/a-guide-to-android-daydream-how-to-setup-and-unlock-hidden-features|archivedate=May 27, 2014|df=}} ** In 7.0 ([[Android Nougat|Nougat]]), an "N" appears, which will enable another Easter egg if tapped. This Easter egg, titled "Android Neko" as a reference to the cat collecting mobile game ''[[Neko Atsume]]'', can be accessed from the Quick Settings menu, and allows the user to create virtual treats, which will eventually attract kittens. The kittens can be viewed in a gallery-style screen. Additionally, long-pressing on the aforementioned "N" repeatedly will alternate between displaying the [[no symbol]] and the cat face emojis, respectively toggling the Easter egg on and off. "No" and "cat" is a [[mondegreen]] for "nougat".{{cite web|author=Kellen|title=There is More to This Android N DP5 Easter Egg and It Involves Catching Cats (Updated)|url=http://www.droid-life.com/2016/07/18/android-n-dp5-easter-egg-involves-catching-cats/|website=Droid Life|access-date=April 22, 2017|date=July 18, 2016}} ** In 8.0 ([[Android Oreo|Oreo]]), instead of the normal way of going to the Easter egg, heading to System > About Phone and tapping on the Android version repeatedly will launch the Easter egg. An orange circle appears, representing an "O" for Oreo. Long pressing on the center will open a blue screen representing a sea with an octopus floating around. The "O" in octopus represents Oreo while the eight legs on the octopus represent the version (8.0). The octopus can be moved by dragging the head around.{{cite web|author=John McCann|title=Android Oreo: 10 things you need to know|url=http://www.techradar.com/news/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-android-oreo|website=TechRadar|}} ** In 9.0 ([[Android Pie|Pie]]), the Easter egg is found by going to System > About Phone > Android version and then tapping three times on the Android version on the next screen. A white, extended "P" will then appear, usually with concentric colored circles disappearing into the "P". Each time the Easter egg is invoked, it displays different colors. The animation can be pinched to zoom.{{cite web|author=Richard Gao|title=Android P feature spotlight: The Easter egg is animated and way too colorful|url=https://www.androidpolice.com/2018/03/07/android-p-feature-spotlight-easter-egg-animated-way-colorful/|website=AndroidPolice}} *** On the Google Pixel 3 and Pixel 3 XL, tapping the "P" icon several times will reveal a drawing app.{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Schoon|title=Here’s the drawing app Easter Egg on Android Pie on Google Pixel 3 [Video]|url=https://9to5google.com/2018/10/24/pixel-3-easter-egg-drawing-app/|website=9to5Google|date=October 24, 2018|access-date=October 27, 2018}} Android Gingerbread Easter egg.jpg|Gingerbread Android Honeycomb Easter egg.jpg|Honeycomb Android Ice Cream Sandwich Easter egg.jpg|Ice Cream Sandwich Android Jelly Bean Easter egg.jpg|Jelly Bean Android KitKat Easter egg.jpg|KitKat Android Lollipop Easter egg.jpg|Lollipop Android Marshmallow Easter egg.jpg|Marshmallow Android Nougat Easter egg.jpg|Nougat Android Oreo Easter egg.jpg|Oreo Android 9.0.jpg|Pie * "Spells" may be "cast" on an Android phone by saying "Ok Google" followed by "Lumos" or "Nox" to turn the flashlight on and off, or "Silencio" to silence the ringer and notifications. === Android applications === * In the [[Google Play Games]] app, if the player swipes the [[Konami Code]], a box will appear with three buttons – a {{key press|B}}, an {{key press|A}} and an {{key press|►}}. Pressing {{key press|B}} then {{key press|A}} then {{key press|►}} unlocks a secret achievement called "All your game are belong to us", a reference to the well known "[[All your base are belong to us]]" phrase.{{cite web|url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2013/07/25/konami-code-easter-egg-discovered-in-google-play-games/|title=Konami Code Easter Egg Discovered In Google Play Games|publisher=Androidpolice.com|date=July 25, 2013|access-date=December 21, 2013}} * In the Google Allo app, sending the Konami Code to the [[Google Assistant]] by typing "up up down down left right left right b a start" will respond with "Cheat mode enabled". Typing it again will respond with random statements relatable to the code.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} * In the Google Phone (Dialer) app, inputting the "Emergency Number" "0118 999 881 999 119 725 3", advertised to replace "[[999 (emergency telephone number)|999]]" in [[The IT Crowd]]'s season 1 episode "[[List of The IT Crowd episodes#Series 1 (2006)|Calamity Jen]]", will cause the phone to vibrate and the call button to flash blue and red. The feature only works on stock Android Marshmallow and Android Nougat.{{Cite web|url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2016/03/27/androids-stock-dialer-app-is-hiding-an-easer-egg-from-the-it-crowd/|title=Android's Stock Dialer App Is Hiding An Easter Egg From 'The IT Crowd'|website=androidpolice.com}}{{cite web|last1=Sims|first1=Gary|title=IT Crowd's 0118 999 881 999 119 725 3 Easter egg found in Google's dialer|url=https://www.androidauthority.com/0118-999-881-999-119-725-3-easter-egg-682519/|website=Android Authority|access-date=January 15, 2018|date=March 28, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=Fans of The IT Crowd will love Google's latest Android easter egg|url=https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/656347/IT-Crowd-Channel-4-Google-Android-Marshmallow-Easter-Egg|website=Express.co.uk|access-date=March 20, 2018|language=en|date=March 29, 2016}} * In [[Google+]], if the device is shaken while viewing a photo, snow will fall; if the device is shaken again it will save an animated [[GIF]] of the image with falling snow to the pictures directory.{{cite web|url=http://www.gottabemobile.com/2013/12/12/google-turns-smartphone-snow-globe/|title=Google+ Turns Your Smartphone Into a Snow Globe|publisher=gottabemobile.com|access-date=December 17, 2013}} * Searching for "let's go caroling" or "let's go carolling" on [[Google Now]] will result in an extra card which displays a list of [[Christmas carol]]s. The phone will play the music and show the words if one of them is selected.{{cite web|url=http://www.gottabemobile.com/2013/12/16/google-easter-egg-brings-christmas-carols-mobile/|title=Google Easter Egg Brings Christmas Carols to Mobile|publisher=gottabemobile.com|access-date=December 17, 2013}} * On [[List of Google apps for Android|YouTube Creator Studio]], swiping down the screen repeatedly will show a cat at the top of the screen.{{cite web|last1=Cerdeña|first1=Anjo|title=YouTube Creator Studio – Different cats peek from... {{!}} Little Big Details|url=http://littlebigdetails.com/post/120693935524/youtube-creator-studio-different-cats-peek-from|website=Little Big Details|access-date=February 22, 2017|language=en}} * Entering the tabview on the [[Google Chrome App]] and swiping up on a tab five times will cause the tab do a backflip.{{cite web|last1=Sneddon|first1=Joey-Elijah|title=Have You Played With These Google Chrome Easter Eggs?|url=http://www.omgchrome.com/list-google-chrome-easter-eggs/|website=OMG! Chrome!|publisher=Ohso Ltd.}} * Opening more than 99 tabs in the Google Chrome App will result in ":D" shown instead of the number of opened tabs. * Tapping on the dinosaur, which is shown if the Google Chrome App is not able to connect to internet, will start a "jump and run" game. == YouTube == {{Further|YouTube}} * On a video published by [[Numberphile]] on June 22, 2012, titled "Why do YouTube views freeze at 301?{{see it|url=youtube.com/watch?v=oIkhgagvrjI|hide=yes}}", the view count is frozen at 301,{{cite tweet|user=numberphile|number=629261560247119872|date=August 6, 2015|title=YouTube has finally retired its quirky 301 glitch — but may it live forever in our hearts….}} referencing the bug in the now changed subject behavior.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/8/5/9100759/youtube-301-view-count-freeze-going-away|title=YouTube videos will no longer get stuck at 301+ views|website=The Verge|date=August 5, 2015|first=Jacob|last=Kastrenakes}} * Adding "&wadsworth=1" to a video URL will apply "Wadsworth's constant", skipping the first 30% of the video.{{cite web|last=Whitson|first=Gordon|title=Skip Past the Boring Intro on YouTube Videos with the Wadsworth Constant Bookmarklet|url=http://lifehacker.com/5849342/skip-past-the-boring-intro-on-youtube-videos-with-the-wadsworth-constant-bookmarklet|publisher=Lifehacker|access-date=April 1, 2012|date=October 13, 2011}} * Whilst viewing any video, type "awesome" and the progress bar and other player elements will flash multicolored. Typing "awesome" again will stop it.{{Cite web|website=Codegena|url=http://codegena.com/top-10-youtube-tricks-know/|title=Top 10 Youtube Tricks that you should know}} * YouTube's [[robots.txt]] file at "{{see it|url=www.youtube.com/robots.txt}}" states that it was "Created in the distant future (the year 2000) after the robotic uprising of the mid 90's which wiped out all humans."{{Cite web|url=http://www.link-assistant.com/blog/10-robots-txt-files-worth-to-have-a-look-at/|title=10 robots.txt files worth to have a look at|author=Ksenia Dobreva|website=link-assistant.com}} This is an ostensible reference to the song [[Sally (Flight of the Conchords)#Songs|"Robots"]] by [[Flight of the Conchords]].{{Cite web|url=https://getflywheel.com/layout/entertaining-code-comments/|website=getflywheel.com|title=7 entertaining comments left in code|author=Ben Stevinson|date=June 5, 2014|access-date=May 18, 2017}} * When the live-stream countdown reaches 24 hours before it is scheduled to start, a "Dawn of The Final Day -24 Hours Remain-" is shown along with a sound effect, referencing the video game ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask]]''.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} * On December 12, 2015, in order to promote the then-upcoming release of ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens'', the [[progress bar]] was changed in order to look like a [[Lightsaber]]. By signing up to a specially created promotional page, users were able to follow the Light Side (which would change the progress bar to blue) or the Dark Side (which would change the progress bar to red). This was turned off after February 1, 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/23/9781672/google-star-wars-customization|title=Google’s Star Wars makeover gives you apps fit for a Jedi (or a Sith)|date=November 23, 2015|author=James Vincent|website=theverge.com|access-date=April 28, 2016}} Along with this, mousing over the volume controls would play a lightsaber sound like it was turned on, and mousing off of it would play a power off sound.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} * A [[Snake game]] could be activated by pressing a combination of [[arrow keys]] whilst videos were paused or playing. Once started, the snake could be controlled by further use of the arrow keys, directing it to "gobble up dots" to increase its size. If the snake hit the edges of the video window, the game ended.{{Cite web|url=https://www.lifehacker.com.au/2010/08/best-google-search-tricks-and-easter-eggs/|website=lifehacker.com.au|title=Best Google Search Tricks And Easter Eggs|author=Angus Kidman|date=August 2, 2010|access-date=August 14, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2010/07/24/youtube-snake-easter-egg/#sQ6ozexeQSqQ|website=mashable.com|title=YouTube Easter Egg: Play "Snake" Game While Watching a Video|author=Samuel Axon|date=July 24, 2010|access-date=August 14, 2017}} The feature no longer works.{{cite web|last1=Kidman|first1=Angus|title=How To Get YouTube's Snake Easter Egg Working Again|url=https://www.lifehacker.com.au/2011/07/how-to-get-youtubes-snake-easter-egg-working-again/|website=Lifehacker Australia|access-date=November 8, 2017|language=en|date=July 14, 2011}} * When watching a video with "{{see it|site=youtube|fidget spinner}}" in the title, the buffering icon will change into a spinning [[fidget spinner]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.craveonline.com/design/1304755-youtube-fidget-spinner-easter-egg-no-one-noticed|title=YouTube Has a Fidget Spinner Easter Egg That No One Has Noticed|website=craveonline.com|date=August 1, 2017|author=Paul Tamburro|access-date=August 4, 2017}}[[File:YouTube EasterEgg Fidget Spinner Buffering.jpg|thumb|The Fidget Spinner that replaces the buffering icon]] * The title of the video "Too Many Cooks", a [[Surreal humour|surreal]] [[Black comedy|dark comedy]] [[Short film|short]] by [[Adult Swim]], is yellow and in the [[Georgia font]], mimicking the video's theme.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} === Search === A YouTube search for: * "beam me up scotty", a reference to ''[[Star Trek]]'', would cause the search results to beam down onto the screen, as in ''Star Trek''.{{Cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2014/02/24/youtube-easter-eggs/|date=February 24, 2014|title=12 YouTube Easter Eggs Worth the Distraction|author=Yohana Desta|website=mashable.com|publisher=MashableUK|access-date=June 8, 2016}} * "doge meme" changes the font on the search result page to pastel color [[Comic Sans]] typical of the [[Doge meme]].{{cite web|last=Chitu|first=Alex|url=http://googlesystem.blogspot.com/2013/11/youtube-easter-egg-for-doge-meme.html |title=YouTube Easter Egg for Doge Meme|publisher=Googlesystem.blogspot.com|date=November 20, 2013|access-date=December 21, 2013}} * "do the harlem shake" will cause the [[Harlem Shake (song)|Harlem Shake]] song to play and the results to dance around.{{Cite web|url=http://www.askvg.com/ultimate-collection-of-youtube-hidden-secret-easter-eggs/|title=YouTube’s Hidden Secret Easter Eggs – AskVG|website=www.askvg.com|access-date=May 12, 2018}} * "use the Force luke" causes the results to levitate, as if by [[the Force]] mentioned in ''[[Star Wars]]''. * "webdriver torso" will return the results but with a red background and a blue rectangle around some videos. It also says "aqua.flv – Slide 000[0–9]" at the bottom left of the page. This is a reference to the [[Webdriver Torso]] mystery. Google has confirmed that it is behind the Webdriver Torso mystery; it is one of many test channels used by YouTube to ensure video quality.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-27778071|title=Google behind Webdriver Torso mystery|work=BBC News|author=Jane Wakefield|date=June 10, 2014|access-date=May 12, 2018}} * Searching "yanny" shows "Did you mean: laurel", and searching "laurel" shows "Did you mean: yanny". This is a reference to [[Yanny or Laurel]], an [[auditory illusion]] that became popular in May 2018.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} == Chrome == {{Further|Google Chrome}} [[File:Chromium T-Rex-error-offline.png|thumb|Lonely T-Rex]] * If the user tries to browse when offline, a message is shown that they are not connected to the Internet. An illustration of the "Lonely T-Rex" dinosaur is shown at the top, designed by Sebastien Gabriel.{{cite web|url=http://www.omgchrome.com/interview-with-sebastien-gabriel-google-chrome-visual-designer/|title=Interview with Sebastien Gabriel, a Google Chrome Visual Designer|last=Tumblison|first=Craig|work=OMG Chrome|date=March 7, 2014}} From September 2014, tapping the dinosaur (in Android or iOS) or pressing {{key press|space}} or {{key press|up}} (on desktop) launches a [[browser game]] called "T-Rex Runner" in which the player controls a running dinosaur by tapping the screen (in Android or iOS) or pressing {{key press|space}}, {{keypress|up}} or {{key press|down}} (on desktop) to avoid obstacles, including [[cacti]] and, from June 2015, [[pterodactyl]]s. In 2016, another feature was added to the game. When the player reaches 700 points the game begins to switch between day (white background, black lines and shapes) and night (black background, white lines and shapes). During September 2018, for Google Chrome's 10th birthday, a [[birthday cake]] causing the dinosaur to wear a birthday hat when collected was added.{{cite web|url=https://www.slashgear.com/chrome-t-rex-offline-game-parties-with-birthday-hat-cake-04544344/|website=slashgear.com|title=Chrome T-Rex offline game parties with birthday hat, cake|author=JC Torres|date=September 4, 2018|access-date=September 16, 2018}} Reaching a score of 900 will switch the colour scheme back to day, and the switch back and forth will occur at further subsequent milestones.{{cite web|url=http://www.omgchrome.com/chrome-easter-egg-trex-game-offline/|title=This is Chrome’s Newest Easter Egg. And It’s Awesome|last=Sneddon|first=Joey-Elijah|work=OMG Chrome|date=September 25, 2014}}{{Cite web|website=htxt.co.za|url=http://www.htxt.co.za/2016/05/20/google-chromes-offline-dinosaur-game-now-has-a-day-night-cycle/|title=Google Chrome's offline "Dinosaur Game" now has a day-night cycle|date=May 20, 2016|author=Clinton Matos|access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.omgchrome.com/chrome-dinosaur-game-pterodactyl-upgrade/|title=Chrome’s Hidden Dinosaur Game Just Got Even Better|last=Sneddon|first=Joey-Elijah|date=June 18, 2015|work=OMG Chrome}} The game is also available at the "chrome://dino" and "chrome://network-error/-106" pages.{{cite news |last1=Biersdorfer |first1=J. D. |title=When Dinosaurs Roam in Chrome |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/14/technology/personaltech/chrome-dinosaur-internet-connection.html |access-date=September 3, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=November 14, 2017}} The game's code is available on the [[Chromium (web browser)|Chromium]] site.{{cite web|url=http://www.labnol.org/software/chrome-offline-dinosaur-game/28781/|title=Play the Dinosaur Game Hidden inside your Google Chrome|work=Digital Inspiration|last=Agarwal|first=Amit|date=October 26, 2015}} * In the Apps splash page at "{{see it|url=chrome://apps}}", a comment can be found under the body header that reads "A div to hold all the templates, and in the darkness bind them". This is a reference to the [[One Ring]] featured in [[The Lord of the Rings]] series by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} * In the About Chrome page at "chrome://settings/help", clicking on the Chrome icon will cause it to spin.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} === Chrome OS === {{Further|Chrome OS}} * In the Camera app, activating [[caps lock]] and typing "CRAZYPONY" will open the files app and prompt the user to select a video file. Users can then add filters and take screenshots of the video. * The [[keyboard shortcut]] {{key press|ctrl|alt|shift|refresh}} causes the current window to spin (Barrel Roll).{{cite web|author1=Dinsan|title=Make Your Chromebook Do A Barrel Roll – AWESOME!!|url=https://www.chromestory.com/2012/05/chromebook-barrel-roll/|website=Chrome Story}} == Other == [[File:Google Sheets Pride easter egg.gif|thumb|right|275px|"PRIDE" Easter Egg in Google Sheets being demonstrated]] {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:left;margin:0 2em 0 0" ! Password !! Page theme |- | IIIOOIII || [[cat]] |- | OOIOIOIO || [[outer space]] |- | IOOOOOOI || [[Pong]] |- | IOOIOOOO || [[bacon]] |- | IIOIOOII || [[Simon (game)|Simon]] |- | OIOIOOII || [[Third generation of video game consoles|8-bit]] |- | IOOOIOOO || [[synthesizer]] |- | IIOIIOII || [[song]] |- | OIIIIIII || [[ASCII]] |- | OIIIOIOI || [[bowling]] |- | OIOOOIOI || [[rocket]] |- | OOIIIOOI || [[hamburger]] |- | IOIOIOIO || [[metaball]] |- | IOOIOIIO || [[donut]] |} * Pressing {{Key press|Ctrl|Shift|Y}} in the [[Picasa]] desktop application will cause a [[teddy bear]] to appear on the screen.{{cite web|author=Amy-Mae Elliott 369|url=http://mashable.com/2010/03/13/google-easter-eggs/|title=5 Must-See Google Easter Eggs|publisher=Mashable.com|date=March 13, 2010|access-date=April 18, 2012}} * In the [[Google I/O]] 2013 page, "{{see it|url=instrument.github.io/google-io-2013/}}", one can click the letters "I" and "O" to input passwords.{{cite web|author=开战时刻：2011年11月01日 00:00|url=http://www.guao.hk/posts/google-io-2013-combination-page.html|title=Google I/O 2013 页面暗藏密码彩蛋，可进入神秘页面（附密码全收集） | 谷奥——探寻谷歌的奥秘|publisher=Guao.hk|date=March 13, 2013|access-date=September 9, 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Fassi|first1=Zak El|title=All the Google I/O Easter Eggs (And How I Found Them)|url=https://gizmodo.com/5989478/all-the-google-io-easter-eggs-and-how-i-got-them|website=Gizmodo|access-date=March 20, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Klatzco|first1=Ian|title=Playing with the Experiment on Google IO's site|url=https://klatz.co/blog/playing-with-the-experiment-on-google-ios-site|website=klatz.co|access-date=November 8, 2017|language=en}} * In [[Google Glass]], tapping ''Settings'' -> ''Device info'' -> ''View licenses'', then tapping the touchpad 9 times, will show a ''Tap Meet Team'' option. Tapping again will show a photo of the Google Glass development team.{{cite web|author=开战时刻：2011年11月01日 00:00|url=http://www.guao.hk/posts/google-glass-easter-egg-introduces-you-to-the-entire-team-in-a-panoramic-image-controlled-by-your-heads-movement.html|title=Google Glass 内置彩蛋被发现，可观看整个眼镜团队全景照片 | 谷奥——探寻谷歌的奥秘|publisher=Guao.hk|date=March 28, 2011|access-date=September 9, 2013}} * Any photograph with Christmas lights uploaded to Google+ will be turned into an animated [[GIF]], showing sparkling lights. * On the Google Play Store, clicking the search button with a blank search field will search "unicorns".{{Cite web|website=Businessinsider|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/unicorn-easter-egg-hidden-in-google-play-store-app-2015-11|title=There's a bizarre Easter Egg hidden on the front page of Google's app store}} * When using [[Google Translate]] to translate the ''[[German language|German]]'' version of [[The Funniest Joke in the World]] ("{{see it|site=translate|Wenn ist das Nunstück git und Slotermeyer? Ja! Beiherhund das Oder die Flipperwaldt gersput!|de|en}}") to [[English language|English]], the result will be "[FATAL ERROR]".{{cite news |last1=Petsko |first1=Emily |title=Google Translate Error Accidentally Insults Flat-Earthers |url=https://mentalfloss.com/article/545979/google-translate-insults-flat-earthers |access-date=September 4, 2018 |work=Mental Floss |date=May 29, 2018}} * In Google's iPhone and iPod touch search application, swiping downwards (past About) repeatedly in the Settings interface brings up a hidden menu item, called Bells and Whistles, allowing customization of colors, sounds and more within the app. However, this no longer works as of the newer app updates.{{cite web|url=http://cultofmac.com/google-reveals-hidden-menu-in-iphone-app/6570|title=Google Reveals Hidden Menu in iPhone App|publisher=Cult of Mac|date=January 2, 2009|access-date=April 18, 2012}} * On [[Google Forms]], entering the [[List of emoticons#table flip|table flip emoticon]] "{{Nowrap|(╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻}}" as the title will cause the interface to flip and replace the title with "{{Nowrap|┬─┬﻿ノ(°_°ノ)}}"{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * The model numbers for the first generation [[Chromecast]] unit and its power adapter read [[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy|H2G2-42]] and [[Mystery Science Theater 3000|MST3K-US]], respectively.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/07/30/google-chromecasts-geeky-easter-eggs|title=Googe Chromecast's Geeky Easter Eggs|access-date=January 12, 2015}} * The password for [[Project Fi]] data only [[SIM card]]s is h2g2, another reference to The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/fi/answer/6330195?hl=en|title=Use Project Fi with tablets & other compatible devices - Project Fi Help|access-date=March 27, 2018}} * In [[Google Sheets|Sheets]], as to celebrate [[LGBT pride]], typing "PRIDE" in cells A1-E1 with each individual letter in each cell will make change the fill color of columns to make a rainbow.{{cite web|last1=Lopez|first1=Napier|title=Google Easter egg celebrates Pride in your spreadsheets|url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2017/06/26/google-easter-egg-celebrates-pride-spreadsheets/|website=The Next Web}}{{cite web|last1=Cakebread|first1=Caroline|title=Google added an Easter egg that turns your spreadsheets into rainbows — here's how it works|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/google-sheets-easter-egg-rainbow-spreadsheets-2017-6|website=Business Insider|publisher=Business Insider Inc.}} == See also == {{portal|Internet|Lists}} * [[elgooG]] * [[Google Doodle]] * [[List of Google April Fools' Day hoaxes]] * [[Google bomb]] * [[Intelligence Quotient (IQ) and Browser Usage]] (AptiQuant) * [[Netflix April Fools' Day jokes]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.google.com/intl/en/about/index.html About Google] {{Google Inc.}} {{Hidden messages}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Google Hoaxes And Easter Eggs}} [[Category:April Fools' Day jokes]] [[Category:Google|Hoaxes]] [[Category:Internet hoaxes]] [[Category:Computer humor]] [[Category:Internet humor]] [[Category:Google lists]]

Square]] * [[Chin Swee Temple]] * [[Connaught Bridge Power Station]] * [[Kellie's Castle]] * [[Kelong]] * [[Kota Ngah Ibrahim]] * [[Kuala Lumpur City Centre]] (KLCC) * [[Kuala Lumpur Tower]] * [[Malay houses]] * [[Malaysian Houses of Parliament]] * [[Malaysian National Projects]] * [[National Grid, Malaysia]] * [[Pudu Prison]] * [[Petronas Towers]] * [[Southern Integrated Gateway]] * [[Wan Mat Airport|Penang International Airport('''PEN''')]] *[[Pangkor Airport|Pangkor ('''PKG''')]] • *[[Redang Airport|Redang ('''RDN''')]] • *[[Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport|Subang ('''SZB''')]] • *[[Sultan Mahmud Airport|Kuala Terengganu ('''TGG''')]] • *[[Tioman Airport|Tioman ('''TOD''')]] • *[[Taiping Airport|Taiping ('''TPG''')]] • *[[Tekah Airport|Tekah]] • *[[Kluang Airport|Kluang ('''WMAP''')]] • *[[Gong Kedak Airport|Gong Kedak ('''WMGK''')]] • *[[Sungai Besi Airport|Sungai Besi ('''WMKF''')]] ====East Malaysia==== * [[Ba'kelalan Airport]] * [[Bario Airport|Bario Sarawak Airport]] * Belaga Airport|Belaga * [[Bintulu Airport|Bintulu ('''BTU''')]] • * [[Kapit Airport|Kapit ('''KPI''')]] • * [[Keningau Airport|Keningau ('''KGU''')]] • * [[Kota Kinabalu International Airport|Kota Kinabalu International Airport ('''BKI''')]] • * [[Kuching International Airport|Kuching International Airport ('''KCH''')]] • * [[Kudat Airport|Kudat ('''KUD''')]] • * [[Labuan Airport|Labuan ('''LBU''')]] • * [[Lahad Datu Airport|Lahad Datu ('''LDU''')]] • * [[Lawas Airport|Lawas ('''LWY''')]] • * [[Limbang Airport|Limbang ('''LMN''')]] • * [[Long Akah Airport|Long Akah ('''LKH''')]] • * [[Long Banga Airport|Long Banga ('''LBP''')]] • * [[Long Lellang Airport|Long Lellang ('''LGL''')]] • * [[Long Pasia Airport|Long Pasia ('''GSA''')]] • * [[Long Semado Airport|Long Semado ('''LSM''')]] • * [[Long Seridan Airport|Long Seridan ('''ODN''')]] • * [[Marudi Airport|Marudi ('''MUR''')]] • * [[Miri Airport|Miri ('''MYY''')]] • * [[Mukah Airport|Simanggang ('''SGG''') * Tanjung Manis Airport|Tanjung Manis;('''WBGT''') * [[Tawau Airport|Tawau ('''TWU''')]] • * Tommanggong Airport|Tommanggong('''TMG''') ===Amusement parks in Malaysia=== * [[Cosmo's World]] * [[Genting Highlands]] * [[A' Famosa Resort]] * [[Sunway Lagoon]] * Bukit Merah Laketown Resort * The Carnivall Sungai Petani * Sunway Tambun Lost World ===Bridges in Malaysia=== page.title: List of birds of Great Britain

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use British English|date=February 2012}} This '''list of birds of Great Britain''' comprises all [[bird]] species which have been recorded in a wild state in [[Great Britain]]. In general the [[British avifauna|avifauna of Britain]] is similar to that of the rest of Europe, although with fewer breeding species. There are 600 species of birds on the British list {{as of|2018|1|22|lc=yes}}, the latest additions being the [[Dalmatian pelican]] (''Pelecanus crispus'') and [[eastern Orphean warbler]] (''Sylvia crassirostris'').{{cite web |date= |title= British List announcements |url= https://www.bou.org.uk/british-list/recent-announcements/ |publisher= British Ornithologists' Union |access-date=29 September 2018 }} The species order and scientific names used here follow that of the official British list, maintained by the [[British Ornithologists' Union]] (BOU).{{cite journal |url=http://www.bou.org.uk/british-list/ |title= The British List|author= British Ornithologists’ Union|date= 2013 |journal=Ibis |volume=155 |pages=635–676 |doi=10.1111/ibi.12069}} Decisions relating to the British list are published by the [[British Ornithologists' Union Records Committee]] (BOURC) in its annual reports in the ''[[Ibis (journal)|Ibis]]'', the journal of the BOU. These reports were formerly geographically based and included the whole of the British Isles, but records for the [[Republic of Ireland]] and [[Northern Ireland]] are now published by their own ornithological associations. Records from the [[Isle of Man]], although adjudicated by the Manx Ornithological Society, continue to be published in the BOU reports.{{cite journal | last= Dudley | first= Steve P | last2= Gee |first2=Mike |last3=Kehoe|first3=Chris|last4=Melling|first4=Tim M|last5=The British Ornithologists' Union Records Committee (BOURC) | year= 2006| title= The British List:A Checklist of Birds of Britain (7th edition) | journal= Ibis | volume= 148 | pages= 526–563 | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/118619822/PDFSTART?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0| doi = 10.1111/j.1474-919X.2006.00603.x}} The BOU uses the following categories for British bird species: *A: species which have been recorded in an apparently natural state at least once since 1 January 1950. *B: species which were recorded in an apparently natural state at least once between 1 January 1800 and 31 December 1949, but have not been recorded subsequently. *C: species that, although originally introduced by man, either deliberately or accidentally, have established breeding populations derived from introduced stock, that maintain themselves without necessary recourse to further introduction. Categories A, B and C constitute the Official British List. Birds can be listed in more than one category, for example the [[Canada goose]] has a large introduced population, but there have also been a few naturally occurring vagrants, so it meets the criteria for categories A and C. Two further categories are used for record keeping only. *D: species that would otherwise appear in Categories A or B except that there is reasonable doubt that they have ever occurred in a natural state. *E: species that have been recorded as introductions, transportees or escapees from captivity, and whose breeding populations (if any) are thought not to be self-sustaining. Birds in Categories D and E are not on the official British list and are not included here. A sixth category, Category F, is being compiled to include species recorded before 1800 including fossil species.{{cite web |url= http://www.bou.org.uk/british-list/species-categories/|title= Species categories|author= BOURC|accessdate=9 December 2012}} Species listed as '''rare''' here are those for which a full description is required for acceptance of the record by the [[British Birds Rarities Committee]]. Other species have an indication of their breeding and wintering status in Great Britain. Because of its mild winters, Great Britain has a considerable population of wintering species, particularly [[duck]]s, [[goose|geese]] and [[swan]]s. There are also a number of species, such as the [[Common pied oystercatcher|oystercatcher]], that are resident in this island, but migrants elsewhere. Also because of its position, Britain receives a number of vagrants from [[Asia]] and [[North America]]. Some American [[gull]]s, [[duck]]s and [[wader]]s are regular enough not to be considered rare. These include the [[ring-billed gull]], [[surf scoter]] and [[pectoral sandpiper]]. __NOTOC__ {| class="toccolours" style="margin:0 auto; width:98%; clear:both; text-align:center;" !Table of contents |- | class="wikitable nowraplinks" style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''Non-passerines''': [[#Ducks, geese and swans|Ducks, geese and swans]] • [[#Grouse|Grouse]] • [[#Pheasants, partridges and quail|Pheasants, partridges and quail]] • [[#Divers|Divers]] • [[#Albatrosses|Albatrosses]] • [[#Shearwaters and petrels|Shearwaters and petrels]] • [[#Austral storm petrels|Austral storm petrels]] • [[#Northern storm petrels|Northern storm petrels]] • [[#Tropicbirds|Tropicbirds]] • [[#Gannets|Gannets]] • [[#Cormorants|Cormorants]] • [[#Frigatebirds|Frigatebirds]] • [[#Pelicans|Pelicans]] • [[#Bitterns, herons and egrets|Bitterns, herons and egrets]] • [[#Ibises and spoonbills|Ibises and spoonbills]] • [[#Storks|Storks]] • [[#Grebes|Grebes]] • [[#Buzzards, kites and allies|Buzzards, kites and allies]] • [[#Osprey|Osprey]] • [[#Falcons|Falcons]] • [[#Rails, crakes and coots|Rails, crakes and coots]] • [[#Cranes|Cranes]] • [[#Bustards|Bustards]] • [[#Oystercatchers|Oystercatchers]] • [[#Avocets and stilts|Avocets and stilts]] • [[#Thick-knees|Thick-knees]] • [[#Pratincoles and coursers|Pratincoles and coursers]] • [[#Plovers and lapwings|Plovers and lapwings]] • [[#Sandpipers and allies|Sandpipers and allies]] • [[#Skuas|Skuas]] • [[#Gulls, terns, and skimmers|Gulls, terns, and skimmers]] • [[#Auks|Auks]] • [[#Sandgrouse|Sandgrouse]] • [[#Pigeons and doves|Pigeons and doves]] • [[#Parrots|Parrots]] • [[#Cuckoos|Cuckoos]] • [[#Barn owls|Barn owls]] • [[#Typical owls|Typical owls]] • [[#Nightjars|Nightjars]] • [[#Swifts|Swifts]] • [[#Kingfishers|Kingfishers]] • [[#Bee-eaters|Bee-eaters]] • [[#Rollers|Rollers]] • [[#Hoopoe|Hoopoe]] • [[#Woodpeckers|Woodpeckers]] |- | class="wikitable nowraplinks" style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''Passerines''': [[#Tyrant flycatchers|Tyrant flycatchers]] • [[#Vireos|Vireos]] • [[#Old World orioles|Old World orioles]] • [[#Shrikes|Shrikes]] • [[#Crows and allies|Crows and allies]] • [[#Kinglets|Kinglets]] • [[#Penduline tits|Penduline tits]] • [[#Tits|Tits]] • [[#Bearded tit|Bearded tit]] • [[#Larks|Larks]] • [[#Swallows and martins|Swallows and martins]] • [[#Bush warblers|Bush warbler]] • [[#Long-tailed tits|Long-tailed tits]] • [[#Leaf warblers|Leaf warblers]] • [[#Typical warblers|Typical warblers]] • [[#Grasshopper warblers|Grasshopper warblers]] • [[#Reed warblers|Reed warblers]] • [[#Cisticolas|Cisticolas]] • [[#Waxwings|Waxwings]] • [[#Wallcreeper|Wallcreeper]] • [[#Nuthatches|Nuthatches]] • [[#Treecreepers|Treecreepers]] • [[#Wrens|Wrens]] • [[#Mockingbirds and allies|Mockingbirds and allies]] • [[#Starlings|Starlings]] • [[#Dippers|Dippers]] • [[#Thrushes|Thrushes]] • [[#Old World flycatchers and chats|Old World flycatchers and chats]] • [[#Accentors|Accentors]] • [[#Sparrows|Sparrows]] • [[#Wagtails and pipits|Wagtails and pipits]] • [[#Finches|Finches]] • [[#Longspurs|Longspurs]] • [[#Cardinals and allies|Cardinals and allies]] • [[#Buntings and American sparrows|Buntings and American sparrows]] • [[#Icterids|Icterids]] • [[#New World warblers|New World warblers]] |- | style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''[[#Species awaiting acceptance|Species awaiting acceptance]]'''{{nbsp|7}} '''[[#See also|See also]]'''{{nbsp|7}} '''[[#Footnotes|Footnotes]]'''{{nbsp|7}} '''[[#References|References]]''' |} ==Ducks, geese and swans== '''Order''': [[Anseriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Anatidae]] The swans, ducks and geese are medium to large birds that are adapted to an aquatic existence with webbed feet and [[beak|bills]] which are flattened to a greater or lesser extent. In many ducks the male is colourful while the female is dull brown. The diet consists of a variety of animals and plants. The family is well represented in Britain, especially in winter when large numbers visit from [[Greenland]], [[Scandinavia]] and [[Russia]]. There are about 160 species worldwide with 55 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial name !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Mute swan]]

|| C: introduced species currently subject to an eradication programme |} ==Grouse== '''Order''': [[Galliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Grouse|Tetraonidae]] Grouse are sturdy, medium-sized terrestrial birds of the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. They have feathered feet and nostrils and short, rounded wings. They feed mainly on plant material and lay their [[bird egg|eggs]] in a simple [[scrape nest|scrape]] on the ground. They are [[game (food)|gamebird]]s and large numbers were shot in the past in [[moorland]] areas. There are about nineteen species worldwide, four in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Red grouse]]
(''Lagopus lagopus scotica'') ||
[[File:Lagopus lagopus scoticus 2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Rock ptarmigan|Ptarmigan]]
(''Lagopus muta'') ||
[[File:Lagopus muta -Iceland-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Black grouse]]
(''Tetrao tetrix'') ||
[[File:Black Grouse Nationalpark Bayerischer Wald.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Western capercaillie]]
(''Tetrao urogallus'') ||
[[File:Tetrao urogallus Richard Bartz.jpg|500x160px]]
|| C resident reintroduced population |} ==Pheasants, partridges and quail== '''Order''': [[Galliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Phasianidae]] These are terrestrial species, feeding and nesting on the ground. They are variable in size but generally plump, with broad and relatively short wings. There are about 155 species worldwide with six in Britain. Four of these were introduced for [[hunting]] or ornamental purposes but one has now apparently died out. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Red-legged partridge]]
(''Alectoris rufa'') ||
[[File:Perdrix rouge.jpg|500x160px]]
|| C resident introduced population |- | [[Grey partridge]]
(''Perdix perdix'') ||
[[File:Perdix perdix (Marek Szczepanek).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A & C resident breeder and introduced gamebird |- | [[Common quail]]
(''Coturnix coturnix'') ||
[[File:Coturnix coturnix (Warsaw zoo)-1.JPG|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Common pheasant]]
(''Phasianus colchicus'') ||
[[File:Pheasant cock (phasianus colchicus).jpg|500x160px]]
|| C resident introduced population |- | [[Golden pheasant]]
(''Chrysolophus pictus'') ||
[[File:Chrysolophus pictus walking.JPG|500x160px]]
|| C resident introduced population |- | [[Lady Amherst's pheasant]]
(''Chrysolophus amherstiae'') ||
[[File:Chrysolophus amherstiae 18092009.jpg|500x160px]]
|| C introduced population no longer self-sustaining |} ==Divers== '''Order''': [[loon|Gaviiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[loon|Gaviidae]] Divers are aquatic birds the size of a large duck, to which they are unrelated. They swim well and fly adequately but are almost helpless on land, because their legs are placed towards the rear of the body. They feed on [[fish]] and other aquatic animals. There are five species worldwide, all of which occur in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Red-throated loon|Red-throated diver]]
(''Gavia stellata'') ||
[[File:Gavia Stellata Ölfusá 20090606.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeder and winter visitor |- | [[Black-throated loon|Black-throated diver]]
(''Gavia arctica'') ||
[[File:Plongeon arctique nid.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeder and winter visitor |- | [[Pacific loon|Pacific diver]]
(''Gavia pacifica'') ||
[[File:PacificLoon24.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common loon|Great northern diver]]
(''Gavia immer'') ||
[[File:Gavia immer -Minocqua, Wisconsin, USA -swimming-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor, has bred |- | [[Yellow-billed loon|White-billed diver]]
(''Gavia adamsii'') ||
[[File:Gavia adamsii.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Albatrosses== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Albatross|Diomedeidae]] The albatrosses are among the largest flying birds, with long, narrow wings for gliding. The majority are found in the [[Southern Hemisphere]] with only vagrants occurring in the [[Atlantic Ocean|North Atlantic]]. There are at least thirteen species worldwide with two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Black-browed albatross]]
(''Thalassarche melanophris'') ||
[[File:Thalassarche melanophrys - SE Tasmania.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Atlantic yellow-nosed albatross]]
(''Thalassarche chlororhynchos'') ||
[[File:Thalassarche chlororhynchos.png|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Shearwaters and petrels== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Procellariidae]] These are highly [[pelagic zone|pelagic]] birds with long, narrow wings and tube-shaped nostrils. They feed at sea on fish, [[squid]] and other marine life. They come to land to breed in colonies, nesting in burrows or on cliffs. There are about 77 species worldwide, 11 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Northern fulmar]]
(''Fulmarus glacialis'') ||
[[File:Northern-Fulmar2 cropped.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Pterodroma feae'') ||
[[File:Zino's petrel sketch.png|500x160px]]

(''Pterodroma hasitata'') ||
[[File:Pterodroma hasitataPCCA20070623-3608B.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Calonectris borealis'') ||
[[File:CorysShearwaterBottom.jpg|500x160px]]

[[File:CorysShearwaterTop.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Ardenna gravis'') ||

(''Puffinus baroli'') ||
[[File:Pétrel de Barau.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Austral storm petrels== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Oceanitidae ]] The austral storm-petrels are the smallest [[seabird]]s, feeding on [[plankton]] and small fish picked from the surface, typically while hovering. They nest in colonies on the ground, most often in burrows. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Wilson's storm petrel]]
(''Oceanites oceanicus'') ||
[[File:Wilsons Storm Petrel (Oceanites oceanicus) webbed feet Oct 2011 Karnataka Pelagic Udupi.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant, more regularly seen well offshore |- | [[White-faced storm petrel]]
(''Pelagodroma marina'') ||
[[File:Pelagodroma marina - SE Tasmania.jpg|500x160px]]
|| B rare vagrant |} ==Northern storm petrels== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Hydrobatidae]] The northern storm-petrels are the smallest [[seabird]]s, feeding on [[plankton]] and small fish picked from the surface, typically while hovering. They nest in colonies on the ground, most often in burrows. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[European storm petrel]]
(''Hydrobates pelagicus'') ||
[[File:Hydrobates pelagicus.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Leach's storm petrel]]
(''Oceanodroma leucorhea'') ||
[[File:Lesp1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Swinhoe's storm petrel]]
(''Oceanodroma monorhis'') ||
[[File:OceanodromaMonorhisSmit.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Tropicbirds== '''Order''': [[Phaethontiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Tropicbird|Phaethontidae]] There is one species in Britain, only as a vagrant. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Red-billed tropicbird]]
(''Phaethon aethereus'') ||
[[File:Red-billed-Tropicbird-ventral.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Gannets== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Sulidae]] Gannets are large seabirds that plunge-dive for fish and nest in large colonies. They have a torpedo-shaped body, long, narrow, pointed wings and a fairly long tail. There are about ten species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Northern gannet]]
(''Morus bassanus'') ||
[[File:Morus bassanus adu.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor and passage migrant |} ==Cormorants== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Cormorant|Phalacrocoracidae]] Cormorants are medium to large aquatic birds with mainly dark plumage and areas of coloured skin on the face. The bill is long, thin and sharply hooked for catching fish and aquatic invertebrates. They nest in colonies by water, usually by the sea or on the banks of rivers. There are about thirty-nine species worldwide, three in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Great cormorant]]
(''Phalacrocorax carbo'') ||
[[File:Phalacrocorax carbo Vic.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Double-crested cormorant]]
(''Phalacrocorax auritus'') ||
[[File:Phalacrocorax-auritus-007.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[European shag]]
(''Phalacrocorax aristotelis'') ||
[[File:Shag Phalacrocorax aristotelis.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Frigatebirds== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Fregatidae]] There are two species in Britain, both of which are rare. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Magnificent frigatebird]]
(''Fregata magnificens'') ||
[[File:Fregata magnificens -Galapagos, Ecuador -male-8 (1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Ascension frigatebird]]
(''Fregata aquila'') ||
[[File: Ascension_Frigatebird.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Pelicans== '''Order''': [[Pelecaniformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Pelican|Pelecanidae]] [[Pelican]]s are large water birds with a distinctive pouch under their beak. As with other members of the order Pelecaniformes, they have webbed feet with four toes. There are eight species worldwide, only one recorded in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Dalmatian pelican]]
(''Pelecanus crispus'') ||
[[File:ComputerHotline - Pelecanus crispus (by) (1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A very rare migrant |- |} ==Bitterns, herons and egrets== '''Order''': [[Pelecaniformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Heron|Ardeidae]] Herons and egrets are medium to large wading birds with long necks and legs. Bitterns tend to be shorter-necked and more secretive. They all fly with their necks retracted. The sharp bill is used to catch fish, [[amphibian]]s and other animals. Many species nest in colonies, often in trees. There are about 63 species worldwide, 13 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Great bittern]]
(''Botaurus stellaris'') ||
[[File:Botaurus stellaris (Marek Szczepanek).jpg|500x160px]]

|| A scarce migrant, recently bred |} ==Ibises and spoonbills== '''Order''': [[Pelecaniformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Threskiornithidae]] A family of long-legged, long-necked wading birds. Ibises have long, curved bills. Spoonbils have a flattened bill, wider at the tip. There are about thirty-three species worldwide with two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Glossy ibis]]
(''Plegadis falcinellus'') ||
[[File:Glossy Ibis (Plegadis falcinellus) at Bharatpur I IMG 5384.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common spoonbill]]
(''Platalea leucorodia'') ||
[[File:Eurasian Spoonbill.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant, recently bred |} ==Storks== '''Order''': [[Ciconiiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[stork|Ciconiidae]] Storks are large, heavy, long-legged, long-necked wading birds with long stout bills and wide wingspans. They fly with the neck extended. There are about nineteen species worldwide with two occurring as vagrants in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Black stork]]
(''Ciconia nigra'') ||

(''Ciconia ciconia'') ||

|| A scarce migrant, formerly bred |} ==Grebes== '''Order''': [[grebe|Podicipediformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[grebe|Podicipedidae]] Grebes are small to medium-large diving birds with lobed toes and pointed bills. They are seen mainly on lowland waters and coasts. They feed on aquatic animals and nest on a floating platform of vegetation. There are about nineteen species worldwide with six in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Pied-billed grebe]]
(''Podilymbus podiceps'') ||

|| A resident breeder and winter visitor |} ==Buzzards, kites and allies== '''Order''': [[Accipitriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Accipitridae]] A family of birds of prey which includes hawks, buzzards, eagles, kites and harriers. These birds have very large powerful hooked beaks for tearing flesh from their prey, strong legs, powerful talons and keen eyesight. There are about 240 species worldwide, 16 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[European honey buzzard]]
(''Pernis apivorus'') ||
[[File:Wespenbussard European honey buzzard Pernis apivorus.jpg|120x160px]]

[[File:Aquila chrysaetos Flickr.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Osprey== '''Order''': [[Accipitriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Osprey|Pandionidae]] A large fish-eating bird of prey belonging to a family of its own. It is mainly brown above and white below with long, angled wings. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Osprey]]
(''Pandion haliaetus'') ||
[[File:2010-kabini-osprey.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |} ==Falcons== '''Order''': [[Falconiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Falconidae]] A family of small to medium-sized, diurnal birds of prey with pointed wings. They do not build their own nests and mainly catch prey in the air. There are about 64 species worldwide, 10 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Lesser kestrel]]
(''Falco naumanni'') ||

(''Falco peregrinus'') ||
[[File:Falco peregrinus -Nova Scotia, Canada -eating-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Rails, crakes and coots== '''Order''': [[Gruiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Rallidae]] These birds mainly occupy dense vegetation in damp environments near lakes, marshes or rivers. Many are shy and secretive birds, making them difficult to observe. Most species have strong legs and long toes which are well adapted to soft uneven surfaces. There are about 135 species worldwide, 11 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Water rail]]
(''Rallus aquaticus'') ||

(''Porphyrio porphyrio'') ||

(''Fulica americana'') ||
[[File:American coot - June 2013.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Cranes== '''Order''': [[Gruiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[crane (bird)|Gruidae]] Cranes are large, long-legged and long-necked birds. Unlike the similar-looking but unrelated herons, cranes fly with necks outstretched, not pulled back. Most have elaborate and noisy courting displays or "dances". There are about fifteen species worldwide, two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Common crane]]
(''Grus grus'') ||
[[File:Grus grus 1 (Marek Szczepanek).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species and passage migrant |- | [[Sandhill crane]]
(''Grus canadensis'') ||
[[File:Sandhill Crane (1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Bustards== '''Order''': [[Otidiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Otididae]] Large, sturdy birds of open plains with long legs and necks and strong feet. There are about twenty-six species worldwide, three in Britain. They are all rarities. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Little bustard]]
(''Tetrax tetrax'') ||

(''Chlamydotis macqueenii'') ||
[[File:Houbara035.JPG|500x160px]]
|| B rare vagrant |- | [[Great bustard]]
(''Otis tarda'') ||
[[File:Beijing solo 026.JPG|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant and recently reintroduced breeding resident species |} ==Oystercatchers== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Haematopodidae]] The oystercatchers are large, obvious and noisy wading birds with strong bills used for smashing or prising open [[molluscs]]. There are about eleven species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eurasian oystercatcher]]
(''Haematopus ostralegus'') ||
[[File:Haematopus ostralegus Norway.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Avocets and stilts== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Recurvirostridae]] A family of fairly large wading birds. The avocets have long legs and long up-curved bills. The stilts have extremely long legs and long, thin, straight bills. There are about ten species worldwide with two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Black-winged stilt]]
(''Himantopus himantopus'') ||
[[File:Himantopus himantopus - Pak Thale.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant and occasional breeder |- | [[Pied avocet]]
(''Recurvirostra avosetta'') ||
[[File:Pied Avocet Recurvirostra avosetta.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Thick-knees== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Stone-curlew|Burhinidae]] A small family of medium to large waders with strong black bills, large yellow eyes and cryptic plumage. There are nine species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eurasian stone-curlew|Stone curlew]]
(''Burhinus oedicnemus'') ||
[[File:Burhinus oedicnemus0.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |} ==Pratincoles and coursers== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Glareolidae]] A family of slender, long-winged wading birds. There are seventeen species worldwide, four in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Cream-colored courser|Cream-coloured courser]]
(''Cursorius cursor'') ||

|| A rare vagrant |} ==Plovers and lapwings== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Charadriidae]] Small to medium-sized wading birds with compact bodies, short, thick necks and long, usually pointed, wings. They chase other seabirds to force them to drop their catches. || A breeding summer visitor |} ==Auks== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Alcidae]] A family of seabirds which are superficially similar to [[penguins]], with their black-and-white colours, upright posture and some of their habits, but which are able to fly. (''Brachyramphus perdix'') ||

(''Fratercula arctica'') ||

|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Tufted puffin]]

[[File:Tufted Puffin Alaska (cropped).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Sandgrouse== '''Order''': [[Pterocliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Pteroclididae]] Sturdy, medium-sized birds with a small head and long, pointed wings. There are sixteen species worldwide. One has occurred as a vagrant in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Pallas's sandgrouse]]
(''Syrrhaptes paradoxus'') ||
[[File:Syrrhaptes paradoxus.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant, has bred |} ==Pigeons and doves== '''Order''': [[Columbiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Columbidae]] Pigeons and doves are stout-bodied birds with short necks and short slender bills with a fleshy [[cere]]. There are about 308 species worldwide, seven in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Rock dove|Rock pigeon or feral pigeon]]
(''Columba livia'') ||
[[File:Blue Rock Pigeon (Columba livia) in Kolkata I IMG 9762.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A & C Resident, most birds are of feral origin |- | [[Stock dove]]
(''Columba oenas'') ||
[[File:Columba oenas1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Common wood pigeon|Wood pigeon]]
(''Columba palumbus'') ||
[[File:Columba palumbus -garden post-8.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Streptopelia decaocto'') ||

|| A resident breeding species |- | [[European turtle dove|Turtle dove]]
(''Streptopelia turtur'') ||
[[File:European Turtle Dove (Streptopelia turtur).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Oriental turtle dove]]
(''Streptopelia orientalis'') ||
[[File:Orientalturtledove.JPG|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Mourning dove]]
(''Zenaida macroura'') ||
[[File:Mourning Dove 2006.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Parrots== '''Order''': [[Psittaciformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Psittaculidae]] Parrots are small to large birds with a characteristic curved beak shape. They are found mainly in areas with warm climates. There is one introduced species in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Rose-ringed parakeet|Ring-necked parakeet]]
(''Psittacula krameri'') ||
[[File:Rose-ringed Parakeets (Male & Female)- During Foreplay at Hodal I Picture 0034.jpg|500x160px]]
|| C resident introduced population |} ==Cuckoos== '''Order''': [[Cuculiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Cuckoo|Cuculidae]] Birds of variable size with slender bodies and long tails. Some species are known for laying their eggs in the nests of other birds. There are about 141 species worldwide, four in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Great spotted cuckoo]]
(''Clamator glandarius'') ||
[[File:Clamator glandarius (juvenile).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common cuckoo]]
(''Cuculus canorus'') ||
[[File:Cuculus canorus vogelartinfo chris romeiks CHR0791 cropped.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Black-billed cuckoo]]
(''Coccyzus erythropthalmus'') ||
[[File:Black-billed-cuckoo2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Yellow-billed cuckoo]]
(''Coccyzus americanus'') ||
[[File:Coccyzus-americanus-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Barn owls== '''Order''': [[Owl|Strigiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Tytonidae]] Barn owls are medium to large owls with large heads and characteristic heart-shaped faces. They have long strong legs with powerful talons. There are about sixteen species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Barn owl]]
(''Tyto alba'') ||
[[File:Tyto alba -British Wildlife Centre, Surrey, England-8a (1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Typical owls== '''Order''': [[Owl|Strigiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[True owl|Strigidae]] Typical owls are small to large solitary nocturnal birds of prey. They have large forward-facing eyes and ears, a hawk-like beak and a conspicuous circle of feathers around each eye called a facial disc. There are about 199 species worldwide, eight in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eurasian scops owl|Scops owl]]
(''Otus scops'') ||
[[File:Otus scops ab cropped.png|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Snowy owl]]
(''Bubo scandiacus'') ||
[[File:Snowy Owl - Schnee-Eule.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant, has bred Shetland Islands |- | [[Northern hawk-owl]]
(''Surnia ulula'') ||
[[File:Surnia-ulula-002.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Little owl]]
(''Athene noctua'') ||
[[File:Mochuelo Común ( Athene noctua )(1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| C resident introduced population |- | [[Tawny owl]]
(''Strix aluco'') ||

(''Asio otus'') ||

(''Asio flammeus'') ||

|| A resident breeding species or winter visitor |- | [[Tengmalm's owl]]
(''Aegolius funereus'') ||
[[File:Aegolius-funereus-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Nightjars== '''Order''': [[Caprimulgiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Nightjar|Caprimulgidae]] Nightjars are medium-sized nocturnal birds that usually nest on the ground. They have long wings, short legs and very short bills. Their soft plumage is cryptically coloured to resemble bark or leaves. There are about 91 species worldwide, four in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[European nightjar]]
(''Caprimulgus europaeus'') ||
[[File:Paukstelis.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Red-necked nightjar]]
(''Caprimulgus ruficollis'') ||
[[File:Caprimulgus ruficollis.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Egyptian nightjar]]
(''Caprimulgus aegyptius'') ||
[[File:Caprimulgus aegyptius.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common nighthawk]]
(''Chordeiles minor'') ||
[[File:Chordeiles minor -British Columbia -Canada-8c.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Swifts== '''Order''': [[Apodiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Swift|Apodidae]] The swifts are small birds which spend the majority of their lives flying. These birds have very short legs and never settle voluntarily on the ground, perching instead only on vertical surfaces. There are about 100 species worldwide, seven in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Chimney swift]]
(''Chaetura pelagica'') ||
[[File:Chimney swift overhead.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[White-throated needletail|Needle-tailed swift]]
(''Hirundapus caudacutus'') ||
[[File:White-throated Needletail 09a.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Apus apus'') ||
[[File:Apus apus -Barcelona, Spain-8 (1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Pallid swift]]
(''Apus pallidus'') ||
[[File:Apus pallidus -Greece-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Pacific swift]]
(''Apus pacificus'') ||
[[File:ApusPacificus.jpg|500x160px]]
