(''Apus melba'') ||
[[File:Tachymarptis melba -Barcelona, Spain -flying-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Little swift]]
(''Apus affinis'') ||
[[File:House swift I IMG 3260.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Kingfishers== '''Order''': [[Coraciiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Alcedinidae]] Kingfishers are medium-sized birds with large heads, long pointed bills, short legs and stubby tails. There are about 93 species worldwide, two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Common kingfisher]]
(''Alcedo atthis'') ||
[[File:Alcatt.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Belted kingfisher]]
(''Megaceryle alcyon'') ||
[[File:Belted Kingfisher.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Bee-eaters== '''Order''': [[Coraciiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Bee-eater|Meropidae]] A group of near-passerine birds characterised by richly coloured plumage, slender bodies and usually elongated central tail-feathers. There are about twenty-six species worldwide, two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Blue-cheeked bee-eater]]
(''Merops persicus'') ||
[[File:Merops persicus.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[European bee-eater]]
(''Merops apiaster'') ||
[[File:Şahlûr.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce summer visitor - occasional breeder |} ==Rollers== '''Order''': [[Coraciiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Roller|Coraciidae]] A small family of colourful, medium-sized birds with a crow-like shape that feed mainly on insects. There are about twelve species worldwide with one in Britain and Wales. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[European roller]]
(''Coracias garrulus'') ||
[[File:European roller.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Hoopoe== '''Order''': [[Bucerotiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Hoopoe|Upupidae]] A distinctive bird in its own family with a long curved bill, a crest and black-and-white striped wings and tail. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Hoopoe]]
(''Upupa epops'') ||
[[File:Botbotik.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce summer visitor, occasional breeder |} ==Woodpeckers== '''Order''': [[Piciformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Picidae]] Woodpeckers are small to medium-sized birds with chisel-like beaks, short legs, stiff tails and long tongues used for capturing insects. Many woodpeckers have the habit of tapping noisily on tree trunks with their beaks. There are about 219 species worldwide, five in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eurasian wryneck]]
(''Jynx torquilla'') ||
[[File:Jynx torquilla vlaskop cropped.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Picus viridis'') ||
[[File:RO B Carol Park green woodpecker crop.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Sphyrapicus varius'') ||
[[File:Sphyrapicus varius.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Dendrocopos major'') ||

|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Lesser spotted woodpecker]]
(''Dryobates minor'') ||
[[File:PicoidesMinorBack.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Tyrant flycatchers== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Tyrannidae]] A family from the Americas with two very rare vagrants recorded in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eastern phoebe]]
(''Sayornis phoebe'') ||

[[File:Empidonax alnorum CT2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Vireos== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Vireonidae]] The vireos are a group of small to medium-sized passerine birds restricted to the New World. There are about 52 species worldwide. Three have occurred as vagrants in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Yellow-throated vireo]]
(''Vireo flavifrons'') ||
[[File:Vireo-flavifrons-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Philadelphia vireo]]
(''Vireo philadelphicus'') ||

(''Vireo olivaceus'') ||
[[File:Vireo olivaceus Itamambuca Eco Resort.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Old World orioles== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Oriolidae]] The orioles are medium-sized passerines, mostly with bright and showy plumage, the females often have duller plumage than the males The beak is long, slightly curved and hooked. Orioles are arboreal and tend to feed in the canopy. There are twenty-seven species worldwide, one of which has been recorded in Great Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Golden oriole|Eurasian golden oriole]]
(''Oriolus oriolus'') ||
[[File:Oriole 2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce breeding summer visitor |} ==Shrikes== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Shrike|Laniidae]] Shrikes are passerine birds known for their habit of catching other birds and small animals and impaling the uneaten portions of their bodies on thorns. A typical shrike's beak is hooked, like a bird of prey. There are about thirty species worldwide, nine in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Brown shrike]]

|| A rare vagrant |} ==Crows and allies== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Corvidae]] The crows and their relatives are fairly large birds with strong bills and are usually intelligent and adaptable. There are about 119 species worldwide with nine in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Red-billed chough]]

|| A resident breeding species |} ==Kinglets== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Regulidae]] A family of very small birds. There are seven species worldwide with two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Goldcrest]]

|| A scarce resident breeding species and passage migrant |} ==Penduline tits== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Remizidae]] Small birds with finely pointed bills that build purse-like nests hanging from a branch. There are about thirteen species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[European penduline tit|Penduline tit]]
(''Remiz pendulinus'') ||

|| A rare vagrant |} ==Tits== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Tit (bird)|Paridae]] Tits are mainly small, stocky, woodland species with short stout bills. They are adaptable birds, with a mixed diet including seeds and insects. || A resident breeding species |} ==Bearded tit== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Panuridae]] A single species formerly placed in the [[Old World babbler]] family. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Bearded tit]]

Most larks are fairly dull in appearance. Their food is insects and seeds. || A scarce winter visitor and passage migrant, occasional breeder |} ==Swallows and martins== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Swallow|Hirundinidae]] The family Hirundinidae is adapted to aerial feeding. They have a slender streamlined body, long pointed wings and a short bill with a wide gape. There are about 83 species worldwide, eight in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Sand martin]]

|| A rare vagrant |} ==Waxwings== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Bombycillidae]] The waxwings are a group of passerine birds characterised by soft, silky plumage and unique red tips to some of the wing feathers. There are three species worldwide, two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Cedar waxwing]]
(''Bombycilla cedrorum'') ||
[[File:Cedar Waxwing August 14 2012 Newfoundland PA.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Bombycilla garrulus'') ||
[[File:Bombycilla garrulusII.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor in highly varied numbers. |} ==Wallcreeper== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Wallcreeper|Tichodromadidae]] One species, in its own family, a visitor to Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Wallcreeper]]
(''Tichodroma muraria'') ||
[[File:Tichodroma muraria02 cropped.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Nuthatches== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Nuthatch|Sittidae]] Nuthatches are small woodland birds with the unusual ability to climb down trees head-first, unlike other birds which can only go upwards. There are about twenty-four species worldwide, two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Red-breasted nuthatch]]
(''Sitta canadensis'') ||
[[File:Sitta canadensis CT2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Eurasian nuthatch]]
(''Sitta europaea'') ||
[[File:Sitta europaea Luc Viatour.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Treecreepers== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Treecreeper|Certhiidae]] Treecreepers are small woodland birds, brown above and white below. They have thin, pointed, down-curved bills, which they use to extricate insects from bark. There are seven species worldwide, two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Common treecreeper]]
(''Certhia familiaris'') ||
[[File:Certhia familiaris 01.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Short-toed treecreeper]]
(''Certhia brachydactyla'') ||
[[File:Boomkruiper1reversed.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Wrens== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Troglodytidae]] Wrens are small and inconspicuous birds, except for their loud songs. They have short wings and thin down-turned bills. There are about 80 species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eurasian wren|Wren]]
(''Troglodytes troglodytes'') ||
[[File:Eurasian-Wren-Troglodytes-troglodytes.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Mockingbirds and allies== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Mimidae]] Medium-sized passerine birds with long tails. Some are notable for their ability to mimic sounds such as other birds' songs. There are about 35 species worldwide. Three have occurred as vagrants in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Northern mockingbird]]
(''Mimus polyglottos'') ||
[[File:Mimus polyglottos -Krendle Woods, Cary, North Carolina, USA-8.jpg|500x160px]]

(''Toxostoma rufum'') ||
[[File:Toxostoma rufum -Garland, Texas, USA-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant (one record) |- | [[Grey catbird]]
(''Dumetella carolinensis'') ||
[[File:Dumetella carolinensis -Brendan T. Byrne State Forest, New Jersey, USA-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant (one record) |} ==Starlings== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Starling|Sturnidae]] Starlings are small to medium-sized passerine birds with strong feet. Their flight is strong and direct and most are very gregarious. There are about 114 species worldwide with two in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Common starling]]
(''Sturnus vulgaris'') ||
[[File:Colourful starling.jpeg|500x160px]]

(''Pastor roseus'') ||
[[File:Rosy Starling (Sturnus roseus) near Hyderabad W2 IMG 4837.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Dippers== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Dipper|Cinclidae]] Dark, dumpy, aquatic birds which are able to forage for food on the beds of rivers. There are five species worldwide with one in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[White-throated dipper]]
(''Cinclus cinclus'') ||
[[File:Cinclus cinclus -Kirkcudbright, Scotland-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Thrushes== '''Order''': [[passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Muscicapidae]]. Subfamily: [[thrush (bird)|Turdinae]] The thrushes are plump, soft-plumaged, small to medium-sized insectivores or sometimes omnivores, often feeding on the ground. Many have attractive songs. There are about 183 species worldwide, 20 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[White's thrush]]

(''Oenanthe hispanica'') ||
[[File:45-090506-black-eared-wheatear-at-Ipsilou-Monastery-.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Desert wheatear]]
(''Oenanthe deserti'') ||
[[File:Oenanthe deserti LipKee.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[White-crowned wheatear]]
(''Oenanthe leucopyga'') ||
[[File:Oenanthe leucopyga.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Accentors== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Prunellidae]] A small family of drab, unobtrusive, insectivorous birds with thin, pointed bills. There are thirteen species worldwide with two recorded in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Dunnock]]
(''Prunella modularis'') ||
[[File:Dunnock crop2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Alpine accentor]]
(''Prunella collaris'') ||
[[File:Alpine accentor saganta.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Sparrows== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[sparrow|Passeridae]] Sparrows tend to be small, plump, brownish or greyish birds with short tails and short, powerful beaks. They are seed-eaters and they also consume small insects. There are about thirty-eight species worldwide, four in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[House sparrow]]
(''Passer domesticus'') ||
[[File:House sparrow (Passer domesticus).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Spanish sparrow]]
(''Passer hispaniolensis'') ||
[[File:Passer Hispaniolensis Male.JPG|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Eurasian tree sparrow]]
(''Passer montanus'') ||
[[File:Tree Sparrow Japan Flip.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Rock sparrow]]
(''Petronia petronia'') ||
[[File:Petronia petronia -Ariege, Midi-Pyrenee, France-8-4c.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Wagtails and pipits== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Motacillidae]] Motacillidae is a family of small passerine birds with medium to long tails. They are slender, ground-feeding insectivores of open country. There are about 66 species worldwide, 15 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Western yellow wagtail]]
(''Motacilla flava'') ||
[[File:Yellow Wagtail (5811285648).jpg|500x160px]]
|| Seven races including: * Blue-headed wagtail ''M. f. flava'' (nominate subspecies occurring as a migrant) * Yellow wagtail ''M. f. flavissima'' (subspecies breeding in Britain) |- | [[Citrine wagtail]]
(''Motacilla citreola'') ||
[[File:Citrine Wagtail (Motacilla citreola)- Breeding Male of calcarata race at Bharatpur I IMG 5752.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Grey wagtail]]
(''Motacilla cinerea'') ||
[[File:Grey Wagtail.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[White wagtail]]
(''Motacilla alba'') ||
[[File:Pied Wagtail rear view 700.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species with two additional visiting races * ''M. a. alba'' (nominate subspecies occurring as a migrant) * ''M. a. leucopsis'', Amur wagtail (rare vagrant) * ''M. a. yarrelli'', pied wagtail (subspecies breeding in Britain) |- | [[Richard's pipit]]
(''Anthus richardi'') ||
[[File:Richard's Pipit I -Haryana IMG 9961.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Blyth's pipit]]
(''Anthus godlewskii'') ||
[[File:Blyth s Pipit Anthus godlewskii.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Tawny pipit]]
(''Anthus campestris'') ||
[[File:AnthusCampestris cropped.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Olive-backed pipit]]
(''Anthus hodgsoni'') ||
[[File:Olive backed Pipit.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Tree pipit]]
(''Anthus trivialis'') ||
[[File:Anthus triviallis (Marek Szczepanek).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A breeding summer visitor |- | [[Pechora pipit]]
(''Anthus gustavi'') ||
[[File:Pechora Pipit spring Attu-island Alaska.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Meadow pipit]]
(''Anthus pratensis'') ||
[[File:Meadowpippit2008 edit.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Red-throated pipit]]
(''Anthus cervinus'') ||
[[File:Red-throated Pipit.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Eurasian rock pipit|Rock pipit]]
(''Anthus petrosus'') ||
[[File:Anthus petrosus3.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Water pipit]]
(''Anthus spinoletta'') ||
[[File:Anthus spinoletta.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor |- | [[Buff-bellied pipit]]
(''Anthus rubescens'') ||
[[File:Anthus rubescens -Harney County, Oregon, USA-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Finches== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[finch|Fringillidae]] Seed-eating passerine birds that are small to moderately large and have a strong beak, usually conical and in some species very large. There are about 176 species worldwide, 22 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Common chaffinch]]
(''Fringilla coelebs'') ||
[[File:Chaffinch (Fringilla coelebs).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Brambling]]
(''Fringilla montifringilla'') ||
[[File:Fringilla montifringilla -Poland -male-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor, occasional breeder |- | [[European serin]]
(''Serinus serinus'') ||
[[File:Serinus serinus (Madrid, Spain) 002.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce passage migrant, occasional breeder |- | [[European greenfinch]]
(''Chloris chloris'') ||
[[File:Greenfinch (carduelis chloris) m.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Citril finch]]
(''Carduelis citrinella'') ||
[[File:Carduelis citrinella -Plateau de Beille, Ariege, Midi-Pyrenee, France-8 (1).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[European goldfinch]]
(''Carduelis carduelis'') ||
[[File:Carduelis carduelis close up.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Eurasian linnet]]
(''Linaria cannabina'') ||
[[File:Carduelis cannabina -England -male-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Twite]]
(''Linaria flavirostris'') ||
[[File:Carduelis flavirostris.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Eurasian siskin]]
(''Spinus spinus'') ||
[[File:Carduelis spinus male.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species and winter visitor |- | [[Lesser redpoll]]
(''Acanthis cabaret'') ||
[[File:Carduelis cabaret1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Mealy redpoll]]
(''Acanthis flammea'') ||
[[File:Carduelis flammea CT6.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor and passage migrant, occasional breeder |- | [[Arctic redpoll]]
(''Acanthis hornemanni'') ||
[[File:Carduelis hornemanni CT3.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Two-barred crossbill]]
(''Loxia leucoptera'') ||
[[File:Whitewingedcrossbillmale09.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common crossbill]]
(''Loxia curvirostra'') ||
[[File:Red Crossbills (Male).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Scottish crossbill]]
(''Loxia scotica'') ||
[[File:Common Crossbill (Loxia curvirostra) - geograph.org.uk - 419190.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident endemic breeding species |- | [[Parrot crossbill]]
(''Loxia pytyopsittacus'') ||
[[File:Loxia pytyopsittacus071021.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Trumpeter finch]]
(''Bucanetes githagineus'') ||
[[File:Bucanetes githagineus -Salinas de Janubio, Lanzarote, Spain-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common rosefinch]]
(''Erythrina erythrinus'') ||
[[File:Carpodacus erythrinus 20060623.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant, occasional breeder |- | [[Pine grosbeak]]
(''Pinicola enucleator'') ||
[[File:Pine grosbeak17g.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Eurasian bullfinch]]
(''Pyrrhula pyrrhula'') ||
[[File:Pyrrhula pyrrhula -Lochwinnoch, Renfrewshire, Scotland-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Hawfinch]]
(''Coccothraustes coccothraustes'') ||
[[File:Coccothraustes coccothraustes.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce resident breeding species |- | [[Evening grosbeak]]
(''Hesperiphona vespertinua'') ||
[[File:Hesperiphona vespertina CT3.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Longspurs== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Emberizidae]]. Tribe: [[Calcariini]] {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Snow bunting]]
(''Plectrophenax nivalis'') ||
[[File:Snow Bunting Cairngorm.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor & scarce breeder |- | [[Lapland bunting]]
(''Calcarius lapponicus'') ||
[[File:Lapland Longspur (Calcarius lapponicus).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A winter visitor, occasional breeder |} ==Cardinals and allies== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Emberizidae]]. Tribe: [[Cardinalini]] {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Summer tanager]]
(''Piranga rubra'') ||
[[File:Summer Tanager male hephzibah.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Scarlet tanager]]
(''Piranga olivacea'') ||
[[File:Piranga olivacea1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Rose-breasted grosbeak]]
(''Pheucticus ludovicianus'') ||
[[File:RosebreastedGrosbeak08.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Indigo bunting]]
(''Passerina cyanea'') ||
[[File:Indigo Bunting by Dan Pancamo 4.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==Buntings and American sparrows== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Emberizidae]]. Tribe: [[Emberizini]] A large group of seed-eating passerine birds with a distinctively shaped bill. There are about 179 species worldwide, 23 in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Eastern towhee|Rufous-sided towhee]]
(''Pipilo erythrophthalmus'') ||
[[File:Pipilo erythrophthalmus -Quabbin Reservoir, Massachusetts, USA -male-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Lark sparrow]]
(''Chondestes grammacus'') ||
[[File:LarkSparrow.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Savannah sparrow]]
(''Passerculus sandwichensis'') ||
[[File:Passerculus sandwichensis crop.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Song sparrow]]
(''Melospiza melodia'') ||
[[File:Melospiza-melodia-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[White-crowned sparrow]]
(''Zonotrichia leucophrys'') ||
[[File:White-crowned-Sparrow.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[White-throated sparrow]]
(''Zonotrichia albicollis'') ||
[[File:Zonotrichia albicollis CT1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Dark-eyed junco]]
(''junco hyemalis'') ||
[[File:Junco hyemalis hyemalis CT2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Black-faced bunting]]
(''Emberiza spodocephala'') ||
[[File:Aoji male.JPG|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Pine bunting]]
(''Emberiza leucocephalos'') ||
[[File:Emberiza_leucocephalos;_Baikonur-town_001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Yellowhammer]]
(''Emberiza citrinella'') ||
[[File:Emberiza citrinella -New Zealand -North Island-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Cirl bunting]]
(''Emberiza cirlus'') ||
[[File:Cirl bunting cropped.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Rock bunting]]
(''Emberiza cia'') ||
[[File:Emberiza cia Martien Brand.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Ortolan bunting]]
(''Emberiza hortulana'') ||
[[File:Embhor.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Cretzschmar's bunting]]
(''Emberiza caesia'') ||
[[File:Emberiza caesia.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Yellow-browed bunting]]
(''Emberiza chrysophrys'') ||
[[File:Yellow-browed bunting (Emberiza chrysophrys) Eocheong Island Korea 2012.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Rustic bunting]]
(''Emberiza rustica'') ||
[[File:Emberiza rustica2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Chestnut-eared bunting]]
(''Emberiza fucata'') ||
[[File:Emberiza fucata.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Little bunting]]
(''Emberiza pusilla'') ||
[[File:Little Bunting.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A scarce migrant |- | [[Yellow-breasted bunting]]
(''Emberiza aureola'') ||
[[File:EmberizaAureolaF.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Reed bunting]]
(''Emberiza schoeniclus'') ||
[[File:Emberiza schoeniclus -England -male-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |- | [[Pallas' reed bunting]]
(''Emberiza pallasi'') ||
[[File:Emberiza pallasi (10).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Black-headed bunting]]
(''Emberiza melanocephala'') ||
[[File:28-090504-black-headed-bunting-at-first-layby.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Corn bunting]]
(''Emberiza calandra'') ||
[[File:Emberiza calandra -Jardin des Plantes, Paris, France-8.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A resident breeding species |} ==Icterids== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Emberizidae]]. Tribe: [[Icterini]] There are three rare vagrants in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Bobolink]]
(''Dolichonyx oryzivorus'') ||
[[File:Bobolink, Mer Bleue.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Brown-headed cowbird]]
(''Molothrus ater'') ||
[[File:Molothrus ater 2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Baltimore oriole]]
(''Icterus galbula'') ||
[[File:Icterus-galbula-002.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Red-winged blackbird]]
(''Agelaius phoeniceus'') ||
[[File:Agelaius phoeniceus2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} ==New World warblers== '''Order''': [[Passerine|Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Emberizidae]]. Tribe: [[Parulini]] A group of small, often colourful passerine birds restricted to the New World. Most are arboreal and insectivorous. There are about 118 species worldwide. Eighteen have occurred as vagrants in Britain. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Ovenbird]]
(''Seiurus aurocapilla'') ||
[[File:Ovenbird RWD2011b.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Northern waterthrush]]
(''Parkesia noveboracensis'') ||
[[File:Seiurus noveboracensis MP1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Golden-winged warbler]]
(''Vermivora chrysoptera'') ||
[[File:Vermivora chrysoptera St Louis Missouri 1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Black-and-white warbler]]
(''Mniotilta varia'') ||
[[File:Black-and-white Warbler.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Tennessee warbler]]
(''Oreothlypis peregrina'') ||
[[File:Tennessee Warbler 2.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Common yellowthroat]]
(''Geothlypis trichas'') ||
[[File:Commonyellowthroat159.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Hooded warbler]]
(''Setophaga citrina'') ||
[[File:Wilsonia citrina (Belize).jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[American redstart]]
(''Setophaga ruticilla'') ||
[[File:Setophaga ruticilla -Chiquimula, Guatemala -male-8-4c.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Cape May warbler]]
(''Setophaga tigrina'') ||
[[File:Dendroica tigrina FWS.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Northern parula]]
(''Setophaga americana'') ||
[[File:Northern Parula in High Island by Dan Pancamo 1.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Magnolia warbler]]
(''Setophaga magnolia'') ||
[[File:Dendroica magnolia MN.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Bay-breasted warbler]]
(''Setophaga castanea'') ||
[[File:Dendroica-castanea-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Blackburnian warbler]]
(''Setophaga fusca'') ||
[[File:Dendroica-fusca-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Yellow warbler]]
(''Setophaga petechia'') ||
[[File:Dendroica-petechia-001.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Chestnut-sided warbler]]
(''Setophaga pensylvanica'') ||
[[File:Dendroica-pensylvanica-003.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Blackpoll warbler]]
(''Setophaga striata'') ||
[[File:BlackpollWarbler23.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Yellow-rumped warbler]]
(''Setophaga coronata'') ||
[[File:Yellow-rump-capisic-spring-2012.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |- | [[Wilson's warbler]]
(''Cardellina pusilla'') ||
[[File:Wilsonia pusilla.jpg|500x160px]]
|| A rare vagrant |} The links above lead to family accounts and individual species. [[Taxonomy (biology)|Taxonomy]] is very fluid in the age of [[DNA]] analysis, so other arrangements may be found, as in [[Sibley-Ahlquist taxonomy]]. ==Species awaiting acceptance== The following species have been recorded recently and the British Ornithologists' Union Records Committee has not yet made a decision on whether to accept them onto the British List.[http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/121577421/HTMLSTART British Ornithologists' Union 37th report (October 2008)] ''Ibis'', 151 (1): 224-230. {| width=90% class="wikitable" !width=25% | Common and binomial names !width=30% | Image !width=45% | Status |- | [[Cackling goose]]
(''Branta hutchinsii'') ||
[[File:AleutianCanadaGoose2.jpg|500x160px]]
||{{cite web|url=http://www.bubo.org/Checklists/british-ornithologists-union-bou-british-list.html|title=British Ornithologists' Union (BOU) British List - Western Palearctic - Checklists|publisher=}} |- | [[White-winged scoter]]
(''Melanitta deglandi'') ||
[[File:White-winged Scoter.jpg|500x160px]]
|| |- | [[Elegant tern]]
(''Sterna elegans'') ||
[[File:Elegant Tern Bolsa Chica.jpg|500x160px]]
|| |- | [[Slaty-backed gull]]
(''Larus schistisagus) ||
[[File:Ooseguro-kamome.jpg|500x160px]]
|| |} ==See also== * [[List of non-native birds of Great Britain]] * [[List of birds of Leicestershire and Rutland]] * [[List of birds of Wales]] * [[List of birds of Ireland]] * [[British Birds Rarities Committee]] * ''[[British Birds (magazine)|British Birds]]'' (a long-established ornithology journal). * [[Birdwatching]] * [[European birds]] * [[Ornithology]] ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==References== *[http://www.bou.org.uk/british-list/ List of British birds published by The British Ornithologists' Union]. *[http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/links/doi/10.1046/j.0019-1019.2001.00026.x/pdf Taxonomic Recommendations for European Birds] *[http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/links/doi/10.1046/j.1474-919x.2002.00110.x/pdf Taxonomic recommendations for British birds] (both in PDF format). *[http://www.rspb.org.uk The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB)] and [http://www.rspb.org.uk/birds/guide RSPB A to Z of UK Birds] *''[http://www.britishbirds.co.uk/search?id=9283 Splitting headaches? Recent taxonomic changes affecting the British and Western Palaearctic lists]'' - Martin Collinson, ''[[British Birds (magazine)|British Birds]]'' vol 99 (June 2006), 306-323 *[http://www.bto.org/volunteer-surveys/birdatlas/previous-atlases/previous-atlases British Trust for Ornithology surveys] {{Fauna of Great Britain}} [[Category:Lists of British animals|Bird]] [[Category:Birds in the United Kingdom|'01]] [[Category:Lists of birds by location|Great Britain]] [[Category:Fauna of Great Britain|'birds]] [[Category:Lists of birds of Europe|Great Britain]] [[Category:Lists of biota of the United Kingdom|bird]] [[Category:Great Britain-related lists|bird]] [[Category:Lists of birds by country|bird]]

page.title: List of rocket experiments on Zingst

revision.text:
==Rocket Experiments== During the [[Cold War]], when the area was part of [[East Germany]], the eastern part of the [[Zingst]] peninsula on the German [[Baltic Sea]] coast in [[Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania]] was a restricted military area, used for meteorological rocket experiments. Various experiments were conducted between 1970 and 1992 in an area known as Sundi Meadows. There were 5 launches of the Polish rocket [[Meteor (rocket)|Meteor 1E]] in the early 1970s. On 21 October 1988 launches of Russian of the [[MMR06|MMR06-M]] type rockets began. The restricted area measured just 23.6 kilometres by 25.5 kilometres. As the rockets reached heights up to 80 kilometres, the launch angle of the unguided rockets had to be determined with an accuracy of 2 degrees in order to prevent an impact outside the restricted area.
The first launches of MMR06-M rockets were not successful due to various technical difficulties. The first successful launch with a meteorological payload occurred on 12 April 1989. Additional launches continued for a short time after the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]] and German reunification (3 October 1990). They were finally ended on 19 December 1990 for safety and technological reasons.
Nevertheless, between 14 February and 10 April 1992 a total of 19 Russian rockets of the MMR06-M type were launched at Zingst, of which 6 were successful. Although further rockets were still available for testing, the launches of MMR06-M rockets in Zingst were stopped in April 1992 because of the removal of [[German Army|German Federal Armed Forces]] from the place.

page.title: List of sovereign states and dependent territories by mortality rate

revision.text:
[[Image:Death rate world map CIA 2009.PNG|thumb|550px|The death rate by country (2009 [[CIA World Factbook]] figures).]] This article includes two versions of the '''list of countries by crude [[mortality rate]]'''. == Methodology == Crude mortality rate refers to the number of deaths over a given period divided by the person-years lived by the population over that period. It is usually expressed in units of deaths per 1,000 individuals per year(‰). The first list is based on the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) "2011 annual statistics". It contains the crude death rate of 236 countries and territories in 2011. The second list is based on [[CIA World Factbook]] 2014 estimates.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2066rank.html |title=The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-02-21}} Dependent territories and not fully recognized states are not ranked. == Countries == {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:right" ! rowspan="2"| Country/Territory !!colspan="2"|OECD 2011 !!colspan="2"|CIA WF 2014 |- ! page.title: List of sovereign states and dependent territories in North America

revision.text:
[[File:Location North America.svg|right|350px]] This is an alphabetical '''list of [[sovereign state]]s and [[dependent territory|dependent territories]] in [[North America]]'''. This list uses the most inclusive definition of North America, which covers the landmass north of the [[Panama]]-[[Colombia]] border, and the islands of the [[Caribbean]]. North America is the northern [[continent]] of the [[Americas]],{{cite web|url =http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/418612/North-America|title = North America|publisher = [[Encyclopædia Britannica]]}} situated in [[Earth]]'s [[Northern Hemisphere]] and almost totally in the [[Western Hemisphere]]. It is bordered on the north by the [[Arctic Ocean]], on the east by the [[Atlantic Ocean|North Atlantic Ocean]], on the southeast by the [[Caribbean Sea]], and on the west by the [[Pacific Ocean|North Pacific Ocean]]; [[South America]] lies to the southeast. == Sovereign states == {| class="wikitable sortable" ! class="unsortable" | Flag ! English short name ! English long name ! Domestic short names ! Capital ! Currency |- | [[File:Flag of Antigua and Barbuda.svg|border|100px|link=Flag of Antigua and Barbuda|alt=Flag of Antigua and Barbuda]] | [[Antigua and Barbuda]]Member of the [[Caribbean Community]]. The Caribbean Community also includes [[Guyana]] and [[Suriname]]. | Antigua and Barbuda | {{lang-en|Antigua and Barbuda}} | [[St. John's, Antigua and Barbuda|St. John's]] | [[East Caribbean dollar]] |- | [[File:Flag of the Bahamas.svg|border|100px|link=Flag of the Bahamas|alt=Flag of the Bahamas]] | [[The Bahamas]] | Commonwealth of The Bahamas | {{lang-en|Bahamas}} | [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]] | [[Bahamian dollar]] |- | [[File:Flag of Barbados.svg|border|100px|link=Flag of Barbados|alt=Flag of Barbados]] | [[Barbados]] | Barbados | {{lang-en|Barbados}} | [[Bridgetown]] | [[Barbadian dollar]] |- | [[File:Flag of Belize.svg|border|100px|link=Flag of Belize|alt=Flag of Belize]] | [[Belize]]Member of the [[Central American Integration System]]. | Belize | {{lang-en|Belize}} | [[Belmopan]] | [[Belize dollar]] |- | [[File:Flag of Canada.svg|border|100px|link=Flag of Canada|alt=Flag of Canada]] | [[Canada]]Member of the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]]. | Canada | {{lang-en|Canada}}

This includes [[dependent territory|dependent territories]] and integral areas of a primarily non-North American state. ===Dependent territories=== Dependencies that are not internationally recognized, or not in effect, are listed in ''italics''. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! class="unsortable" | Flag ! For the most part, however, they are under [[Colombia]] administration as an integral part of Colombia, part of the [[Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina|San Andrés department]]. revision.text:
{{other uses2|Maramureș}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2010}} [[File:Maramures Reg.svg|thumb|right|300px|Map of [[Romania]] with Maramureş region highlighted]] [[File:Maramureș in Zakarpattia Oblast.svg|thumb|300px|Northern Maramureș as part of the Zakarpattia Oblast of Ukraine]]
'''Maramureș''' ({{lang-ro|Maramureș}} {{IPA-ro|maraˈmureʃ|pron|Ro-Maramureș.ogg}}; {{lang-uk|Мармарощина}}, ''Marmaroshchyna'') is a geographical, historical and cultural region in northern [[Romania]] and western [[Ukraine]]. It is situated on the northeastern [[Carpathian Mountains|Carpathians]], along the upper [[Tisza River|Tisa River]]; it covers the Maramureș Depression and the surrounding Carpathian mountains.
Alternatively, the name Maramureș is used for the [[Maramureș County]] of Romania, which contains the southern section of the historical region.
==Name in other languages== Alternative names for Maramureș include {{lang-uk|Мармарощина}} (Marmaroshchyna), {{lang-ru|Мараморош}} (''Maramoroš''), {{lang-hu|Máramaros}}, {{lang-de|Maramuresch}}, {{lang-tr|Marmaroş}}, and {{lang-la|Marmatia}}.
==Geography== Maramureș is a valley enclosed by mountains Oaș, Gutâi, Țibleș and Rodnei to the west and south, [[Maramureș Mountains]] and Ukrainian Carpathians ("Wooded Carpathians") to the east and north, with a thin opening at [[Khust]]. Several dozen small mountain rivers and creeks flow into the river [[Tisza|Tisa]]. It is forested and not easily accessible.
The limits of the region are between the parallels of 47°33' N and 40°02' N and the meridians of 23°15' E and 25°03' E. Maramureș represents one of the largest depressions in the Carpathians, covering an area of about 10,000 km².
Its length from [[Khust]] to [[Prislop Pass]] is about 150 km and width from North to South is up to 80 km.
The main mountain passes linking Maramureș with the neighboring regions are high and in the past were hardly accessible in the winter. Prislop Pass (1,414 m high) links the region in the east towards Moldavia, Dealul Ștefăniței (1,254 m) in the south towards Transylvania, Pintea Pass (987 m) towards Baia Mare, and Fărgău (587 m) in the west towards Oaș Country, while Frasini Pass ([[Yasinia]]; 931 m) links the region in the north to [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]].
The mountains surrounding this region occupy more than half of the area. A few peaks reach above 2,000 m, such as Pietrosul (2,303 m) in the Rodnei Mountains to the south and Hovârla (2,061 m) in Muntele Negru (Cernahora) to the north.
The heavy forested mountains sustain many protected species of plants, such as [[Taxus baccata|yew]] (''Taxus baccata''), [[larch]] (''Larix decidua''), [[Swiss pine]] (''Pinus cembra''), [[edelweiss]] (''Leontopodium alpinum''); and animals, such as [[lynx]] (''Lynx lynx''), [[chamois]] (''Rupicapra rupicapra''), [[alpine marmot]] (''Marmota marmota''), [[golden eagle]] (''Aquila chrysaetos''), and [[capercaillie]] (''Tetrao urogallus'').
The last [[wisent]] from present-day Romania territory, a symbol of Maramureş, was hunted to extinction in 1852. Lostriţa, a local variety of salmon, still live in the mountain rivers.
Several protected areas have been created in Maramureș. Rodnei Mountains National Park was designated in 1930, Maramureș Mountains Natural Park in 2004, and there are many other caves, gorges, cliff formations, and lakes which are officially-protected areas.
==History== [[File:Maramures Josephinische Landesaufnahme 1782-1785 Background.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Máramaros County|Marmaroscher Comitat]] on the map of the [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Habsburg Kingdom of Hungary]], 1780-84. The present-day borders of Romania are projected to the historical map.]] [[File:Marmatia.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Máramaros County]] (''Hungarian'': Máramaros vármegye; ''Romanian'': Comitatul Maramureş; ''Ukrainian'': Комітат Марамарош), 1905]] {{Main|History of Maramureș}} In ancient times, this area was settled by [[Celts]], [[Dacians]], [[Sarmatians]] and [[Germanic peoples]]. In the first century BC, it was part of the [[Dacian Kingdom]] under [[Burebista]], while in the early Middle Ages, it was ruled by the [[Huns|Hunnic Empire]], the [[Gepids|Kingdom of the Gepids]], the [[Pannonian Avars|Kingdom of the Avars]], the [[White Croatia]] and the [[Kievan Rus']].
The territory was part of the [[Kingdom of Hungary (medieval)|Kingdom of Hungary]] from the 11th century and was nominally divided between the [[Gyepű]] border region, [[Comitatus (Kingdom of Hungary)|comitatus]] of [[Szatmár]] and comitatus of [[Borsova]]. Later, the whole region was included into the comitatus of [[Máramaros]]. Initially, the inhabitants of the region were allowed to preserve their native political organization, the ''Voevodates'', which formed many small autonomous areas. The King long struggled{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} to convince the [[Voivode]]s to accept the title of [[Count]], with the implied losing independence in political and financial matters. During the [[Middle Ages]], the people in many mountain villages, where each family by definition had a considerable domain, were called ''nameşi'', meaning free peasants taking pride in their family (the origin of the word is disputed, in the Kingdom of Hungary, free people possessing land were called "nemes" in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], in [[Romanian language|Romanian]] ''neam'' means extended family).
In the 16th century, medieval Kingdom of Hungary was invaded and destroyed by the [[Ottoman Empire]], and area came under administration of the semi-independent Ottoman [[Principality of Transylvania (1570–1711)|Principality of Transylvania]] and later (in the end of the 17th century) under administration of the [[Habsburg Monarchy]] (later known as the [[Austrian Empire]]). During Habsburg administration, region was firstly part of the Habsburg Principality of Transylvania, but was later (in 1732) included into the [[Kingdom of Hungary (1538–1867)|Habsburg Kingdom of Hungary]]. In 1867, the Austrian Empire was transformed into the dual monarchy of [[Austria-Hungary]] and the region was included into the [[Transleithania]] or [[Kingdom of Hungary|Hungarian]] part of the Monarchy.
After the [[First World War]], the region was divided between Romania and [[Czechoslovakia]] at the territory of [[Hutsul Republic]],<ref>[http://tyzhden.ua/Publication/7431 Hutsul coup]. [[The Ukrainian Week]]. November 14, 2010</ref> while in 1940 the whole area became part of [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Hungary]] again and was controlled during World War II until 1944. After [[World War II]], the southern section remained within the Romanian borders and is now part of [[Maramureș County]]; the [[Northern Maramuresh|northern section]] was incorporated into the Soviet Union and is now part of [[Zakarpattia Oblast]] of independent Ukraine.
==People== In the [[Maramureş County|southern area]], the majority of the population are [[Romanians]]. There are also some [[Hungarian people|Hungarians]], [[Rusyns]] ([[Ukrainians]]), [[Zipser Germans]], [[Jews]], and [[Romani people|Roma]]. In the [[Northern Maramuresh|northern area]], the majority are [[Rusyns|Ruthenes]]{{cn|date=July 2014}}, with smaller Romanian, Hungarian and German communities.
In the northern area most people speak the [[Rusyn language|Ruthene language]]{{cn|date=July 2014}}, while in the southern area most speak Romanian, which is why the region was split into two parts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maramureş region|url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CM%5CA%5CMaramureK1region.htm|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine|publisher=Mykola Pavliuk, Arkadii Zhukovsky|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref>{{cn|date=July 2014}} Since the 1940s there have been villages cut in two by the state border. There are some villages in the north (within Ukraine) that have a sizeable Romanian population, as well as some villages in Romania that have a sizeable Ukrainian population.

(25987238058).jpg|Winter lanscape File:Turnul Ștefan Centrul Vechi.jpg|Stephen's Tower in [[Baia Mare]] File:Biserica reformată centrul vechi.jpg|Reformed church in [[Baia Mare]] File:Sighetul Marmatiei - Palatul Culturii.jpg|[[Sighetu Marmației]] File:MonumentulUniriiTgLapus.JPG|[[Târgu Lăpuș]] File:Felsőbánya városháza.jpg|[[Baia Sprie]] </gallery>

{{no footnotes|date=November 2017}} {{primary sources|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox economist | name = Masahisa Fujita | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = 藤田 昌久 | native_name_lang = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|07|21}} | birth_place = [[Yamaguchi Prefecture|Yamaguchi]], [[Japan]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | institution = [[RIETI]]
[[Konan University]]
[[University of Pennsylvania]]
[[Kyoto University]] | field = [[Regional science]]
[[Urban economics]]
[[Spatial economics]] | school_tradition = | alma_mater = [[University of Pennsylvania]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] 1972)
[[Kyoto University]] ([[B.S.]] 1966) | influences = | influenced = [[Walter Isard]] | contributions = [[Economic geography#New economic geography|New Economic Geography]] | awards = | memorials = | spouse = | signature = | url = | module = | repec_prefix = e | repec_id = pfu109 | notes = }} {{nihongo|'''Masahisa Fujita'''|藤田 昌久|Fujita Masahisa|born 21 July 1943}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[economist]] who has studied [[regional science]] and [[Urban economics]] and [[International Trade]], Spatial Economy ([[New Economic Geography]]). He is a [[professor]] at [[Konan University]] and an [[adjunct professor]] at Institute of Economic Research, [[Kyoto University]]. Fujita majored in [[urban planning]] as an undergraduate at [[Kyoto University]]. He studied [[regional science]] in [[University of Pennsylvania]] under [[Walter Isard]] and obtained a Ph.D.(in Regional Science) from [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1972. He taught at University of Pennsylvania for about 20 years, and has been the faculty of Institute of Economic Research (KIER) [[Kyoto University]] since 1995, where he served as Director in 1999. He was the President of [[Institute of Developing Economies]] during 2003 to 2007, and proposed a basic concept of [[Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia]] to [[JETRO]] and [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry|METI]].In 2007, he became President and Chief Research Officer of the Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry. Fujita is known as one of the pioneers of [[economic geography|New Economic Geography]], research of Spatial Economy as well as [[Paul Krugman]]. Fujita is the recipient of the 1983 Tord Palander Prize, the 1998 Walter Isard Award in regional science, and also awarded First Alonso Prize with [[Paul Krugman]]. ==Selected works== ===Books=== * {{cite book |last1= Fujita |first1= Masahisa |year= 1978 |title= Spatial development planning: a dynamic convex programming approach |series= Studies in regional science and urban economics |volume= 2 |location= [[Amsterdam]] |publisher= [[North-Holland Pub. Co.]] |isbn= 9780444851574 }} * {{cite book |last1= Fujita |first1= Masahisa |year= 1989 |editor1-last= |editor1-first= |editor1-link= |editor2-last= |editor2-first= |editor2-link= |editor3-last= |editor3-first= |editor3-link= |editor4-last= |editor4-first= |editor4-link= |editor5-last= |editor5-first= |editor5-link= |title= Urban Economic Theory: Land Use and City Size |location= [[Cambridge, |pages= 139–164 | doi = 10.1007/s10110-003-0180-0 |date= 2005 }} * {{Cite journal |last= Fujita |first= Masahisa |last2= Thisse |first2= Jacques-François | title = Globalization And The Evolution Of The Supply Chain: Who Gains And Who Loses? | journal = International Economic Review | volume = 47 | issue = 3 | pages = 811–836 | doi = 10.1111/j.1468-2354.2006.00397.x | date = 2006 }} * {{Cite journal |last= Berliant |first= Marcus |last2= Fujita |first2= Masahisa | title = Knowledge Creation As A Square Dance On The Hilbert Cube | journal = International Economic Review | date = 2008 | revision.comment: /* Geostrategic ideas */ Corrected the spelling of 'Mackinac' to 'Mackinder'
revision.text:
'''Nicholas John Spykman''' (pronounced "Speak-man", 13 October 1893 – 26 June 1943) was an [[United States|American]] [[political scientist]] who was one of the founders of the classial [[realism (international relations)|realist]] school in American foreign policy, transmitting [[Eastern European]] political thought to the United States. A [[Sterling Professor]] of International Relations, teaching as part of the Institute for International Studies at [[Yale University]], one of his prime concerns was making his students [[geography|geographically]] literate, as geopolitics was impossible without geographic understanding.
His work on geopolitics and geostrategy led him to be to known as the "[[people known as the father or mother of something|godfather of]] [[containment]]."
==Early life== Spykman was born on 13 October 1893 in [[Amsterdam]].<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit">{{cite news | url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1943/06/27/85107840.html?pageNumber=33 | title=Dr. N. J. Spykman of Yale Dies at 49 | newspaper=The New York Times | date=June 27, 1943 | page=33}}</ref> He attended [[Delft University]] and the [[University of Cairo]].<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit"/>
==Career== He worked as a journalist in various parts of the world during much of the 1910s and also served as a diplomatic assistant for the [[Netherlands]] in [[Egypt]] and the [[Dutch East Indies]].<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit"/><ref name="ssr-1943">{{cite journal | title="Nicholas J. Spykman 1893–1943 | journal=Sociology and Social Research | volume=28 | page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=muMbAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Nicholas+Spykman%22+%22university+of+california%22&dq=%22Nicholas+Spykman%22+%22university+of+california%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiXp9n05NTOAhWFeCYKHQPrDPUQ6AEIKjAB 312]}}</ref>
He then came to the United States around 1920 to enter a doctoral program at the [[University of California]], where he received a bachelor's degree in 1921, a master's degree in 1922, and a Ph.D. in 1923.<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit"/> The subject of his dissertation, which he subsequently revised for publication, was [[Georg Simmel]].<ref name="crit-geo">{{cite book | title=Critical Geopolitics: The Politics of Writing Global Space | author=Gearóid Ó Tuathail | page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=q4z31O4RWg0C&pg=PA50 50]}}</ref> He then was an instructor in political science and sociology there from 1923 to 1925.<ref name="crit-geo"/> He became a naturalized [[citizen of the United States]] in 1928.<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit"/>
==Professor== In 1925, he came to [[Yale University]], where he was an assistant professor of international relations. He became a full professor in 1928<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit"/> and the chair of the university's department of international relations in 1935.<ref name="crit-geo"/> Also in 1935, he was a co-founder of the [[Yale Institute of International Studies]] and was its first director.<ref name="nyt-spykman-obit"/> He held that position until 1940, when he became ill and relinquished it.
==Author== Spykman published two books on foreign policy.
''America's Strategy in World Politics'' was published in 1942, soon after the entry of the United States into [[World War II]]. Concerned with the [[balance of power in international relations|balance of power]], he argued that [[isolationism]], which relied on the oceans to protect the United States ("[[Western Hemisphere|hemispheric]]" or "quarter defense"), was bound to fail. His object was to prevent another US retreat, as what occurred after World War I. [[Isaiah Bowman]] commented in 1942, "On grounds of merit and public value ''America’s Strategy in World Politics'' should be read in not less than a million American home. Every government official responsible for policy should read it once a year for the next twenty years—even if he may not agree with some of the remedies proposed."<ref>"Political Geography of Power," ''Geographical Review'', 32/1, (1942): p 350.</ref>
''The Geography of the Peace'' was published the year after Spykman's death. He explained his geostrategy and argued that the balance of power in [[Eurasia]] directly affected US security.
In his writings on geography and foreign policy, Spykman was somewhat of a [[environmental determinism|geographical determinist]]. Since geography was "the most fundamentally conditioning factor because of its relative permanence," it is of primary relevance in analyzing a state's potential foreign policy.
==Death== He died of [[cancer]] on 26 June 1943, at the age of 49, in [[New Haven, Connecticut]].
==Personal life== He was married to the children's novelist [[E. C. Spykman]].
== Geostrategic ideas == He could be considered as a disciple and critic of both geostrategists [[Alfred Mahan]], of the [[United States Navy]], and [[Halford Mackinder]], the [[United Kingdom|British]] geographer. Spykman's work is based on assumptions similar to Mackinder, the unity of world politics and the unity of the world sea, but extends it to include the unity of the air. The exploration of the entire world means that the foreign policy of any nation will affect more than its immediate neighbors; it will affect the alignment of nations throughout the world's regions. [[Navigation|Maritime]] mobility opened up the possibility of a new geopolitical structure: the overseas [[empire]].
Spykman adopts Mackinder's divisions of the world but renames some: *the Heartland *the Rimland (analogous to Mackinder's "inner or marginal crescent") *the Offshore Islands & Continents (Mackinder's "outer or insular crescent")
=== Heartland ===
At the same time, even if he gives credit to the strategic importance of maritime space like Mackinder,{{clarify|date=February 2017}} he does not see it as a region that will be unified by powerful [[transportation]] or [[communication]] infrastructure in the near future. As such, it will not be in a position to compete with US [[sea power]]. Spykman agrees that the Heartland offers a uniquely-defensive position, but that is all Spykman grants its occupier.
While the [[USSR]] encompassed a great expanse of land, its [[arable land]] remained in a small portion of its territory, mostly in the West. Indeed, the Soviet's raw materials were largely located to the West of the [[Ural Mountains]] as well. Since the political and material center of gravity was in the Western part of the USSR, Spykman sees little possibility of the Soviets exerting much power in [[Central Asia]].
Still, the Soviet Union was to remain the greatest land power in Asia and could be a peacekeeper or a problem.
=== Rimland ===
The [[Rimland]] (Mackinder's "Inner or Marginal Crescent") sections: * the [[Europe]]an [[coast]] land; * the [[Arabian]]-[[Middle Eastern]] [[desert]] land; and, * the [[Asia]]tic [[monsoon]] land.
While Spykman accepts the first two as defined, he rejects the simple grouping the Asian countries into one "monsoon land." [[India]], the [[Indian Ocean]] [[littoral]], and the [[culture of Indi]] had a geography and [[civilization]] separate from the [[China|Chinese]] lands.
The Rimland's defining characteristic is that it is an intermediate region, lying between the Heartland and the marginal sea powers. As the amphibious buffer zone between the land powers and sea powers, it must defend itself from both sides, the cause of its fundamental security problems. Spykman's conception of the Rimland bears greater resemblance to [[Alfred Thayer Mahan]]'s "debated and debatable zone" than to Mackinder's Inner or Marginal Crescent.
The Rimland has great importance because of its demographic weight, natural resources, and industrial development. Spykman sees that its importance to be the reason that the Rimland will be crucial to containing the Heartland, but Mackinder had believed that the Outer or Insular Crescent would be the most important factor in containing the Heartland.
=== Offshore continents ===
There are two offshore [[continent]]s flanking [[Eurasia]]: [[Africa]] and [[Australia]]. Spykman sees both continents' geopolitical status as determined respectively by the state of control over the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and the "Asiatic Mediterranean." Neither has ever been the seat of significant power; chaos prevents Africa from harnessing the resources of its regions, and Australia has too little arable territory.
Other than the two continents, there are offshore islands of significance are Britain, [[Japan]] and the [[New World]], buffered by the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and the [[Pacific Ocean]].
=== Eurasian dynamics ===
Again, Spykman differs from Mackinder, who sees Eurasian wars as historically pitting the Heartland against the sea powers for control of the rimland, establishing a land power-sea power opposition. Spykman states that historically, battles have pitted either Britain and Rimland allies against [[Russia]] and its Rimland allies or Britain and Russia together against a dominating Rimland power. In other words, the Eurasian struggle was not the sea powers containing the Heartland but the prevention of any power from ruling the Rimland.
Spykman disagrees with Mackinder's famous dictum: :''Who controls eastern Europe rules the Heartland;'' :''Who controls the Heartland rules the World Island; and'' :''Who rules the World Island rules the World. ''
He refashions it thus: :''Who controls the Rimland rules Eurasia;'' :''Who rules Eurasia controls the destinies of the world.''
Therefore, British, Russian, and US power would play the key roles in controlling the European litoral and there the essential power relations of the world.
=== US strategic goals ===
Spykman thought that it was in the American interests to leave [[Germany]] strong after World War II to be able to counter Russia's power. Strategically, there was no difference between Germany dominating all the way to the Ural or Russia controlling all the way to Germany, and as both scenarios were equally threatening to the US.
Spykman predicted that Japan would lose the [[Pacific War]] and that China and Russia would remain to struggle against eac other over boundaries. He also forecast the rise of China, becoming the dominant power in Asia and that the US would thus take responsibility for Japan's defense.
Spykman was opposed to [[European integration]] and argued that US interests favored balanced power in Europe, rather than integrated power. The US was fighting a war against Germany to prevent Europe's conquest, and it would not make sense to [[federation|federalize]] or to unify Europe after a war that had been fought to preserve balance.
==Legacy== [[John Foster Dulles]] and the founders of the containment strategy would borrow heavily from Spykman, as well as Mackinder, when forging the American [[Cold War]] strategy.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}
== Quotations ==
*"Geography is the most fundamental factor in foreign policy because it is the most permanent." :—from ''The Geography of the Peace''
*"Plans for far-reaching changes in the character of international society are an [[intellectual]] by-product of all great wars." :—from ''America's Strategy in World Politics''
*"There are not many instances in history which show great and powerful states creating [[military alliance|alliance]]s and [[international organization|organization]]s to limit their own strength. States are always engaged in curbing the force of some other state. The truth of the matter is that states are interested only in a balance which is in their favor. Not an equilibrium, but a generous margin is their objective. There is no real security in being just as strong as a potential enemy; there is security only in being a little stronger. There is no possibility of action if one's strength is fully checked; there is a chance for a positive foreign policy only if there is a margin of force which can be freely used. Whatever the theory and rationalization, the practical objective is the constant improvement of the state's own relative power position. The balance desired is the one which neutralizes other states, leaving the home state free to be the deciding force and the deciding voice." :—from ''America's Strategy in World Politics''
*"[A] political equilibrium is neither a gift of the gods nor an inherently stable condition. It results from the active intervention of man, from the operation of political forces. States cannot afford to wait passively for the happy time when a miraculously achieved balance of power will bring peace and security. If they wish to survive, they must be willing to go to war to preserve a balance against the growing [[hegemony|hegemonic]] power of the period." :—from ''America's Strategy in World Politics''
*"Nations which renounce the power struggle and deliberately choose impotence will cease to influence international relations either for evil or good." :—from ''America's Strategy in World Politics''
*"The facts of location do not change. The significant of such facts changes with every shift in the means of communication, in routes of communication, in the technique of war, and in the centers of world power, and the full meaning of a given location can be obtained only by considering the specific area in relations to two systems of reference: a geographic system of reference from which we derive the facts of location, and a historical system of reference by which we evaluate those facts." :—from "Geography and Foreign Policy I", ''American Political Science Review'', Vol XXXII, No. 1 (February 1938), p. 29.
== Works == === Books === * ''The Geography of the Peace'', New York, Harcourt, Brace and Company (1944) * ''America's Strategy in World Politics: The United States and the Balance of Power'', New York, Harcourt, Brace and Company (1942) * ''The Social Theory of Georg Simmel'', Chicago, [[University of Chicago Press]] (c. 1925)
=== Articles === * The Social Background of Asiatic Nationalism, ''The American Journal of Sociology'' 1926, issue 3 * International Relations from the Point of View of Teaching, in: Proceedings of the Fourth Conference of Teachers of International Law and Related Subjects, Washington 1930 * Methods of Approach to the Study of International Relations, in: Proceedings of the Fifth Conference of Teachers of International Law and Related Subjects, Washington 1933 * States’ Rights and the League, ''The Yale Review'' 1934, issue 2 * Geography and Foreign Policy, I, ''The American Political Science Review'' 1938, issue 1 * Geography and Foreign Policy, II, ''The American Political Science Review'' 1938, issue 2 * with A. A. Rollins, Geographic Objectives in Foreign Policy, I, ''The American Political Science Review'' 1939, issue 3 * with A. A. Rollins, Geographic Objectives in Foreign Policy, II, ''The American Political Science Review'' 1939, issue 4 * Frontiers, Security, and International Organization, ''Geographical Review'' 1942, issue 3
==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2016}}
'''Further reading''' *[[Robert D. Kaplan|Kaplan, Robert D.]] (2012) ''The Revenge of Geography: What the Maps Tell Us About the Coming Conflicts and the Battle Against Fate'' New York: Random House. {{ISBN|978-1-4000-6983-5}}
==External links== *[http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/item/2006/0406/semp/sempa_spykman.html "Spykman's World" at ''American Diplomacy'']
{{Authority control}}
