revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{coord|35.234440|N|53.920798|E|display=title}} {{Infobox Space agency |name = Semnan Space Center |acronym = |image = |size = |caption = |spaceport = [[Imam Khomeini Spaceport]] |established ={{Start date and years ago|mf=no|2004|2|1}} |owner = [[Iranian Space Agency]], {{flag|Iran}} |headquarters = |budget = |administrator = |URL = {{url|isa.ir}} }} ''' Semnan Space Center''' ([[Persian language|Persian]]:{{lang|fa|پایگاه فضایی سمنان}}) is the primary Iranian Space Center, located 50 km southeast of the city of [[Semnan, Iran|Semnan]] in the north of the country. ==History== On occasion of the 10th anniversary of the 1998 [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-1|Kwangmyongsong 1]] satellite launch attempt, program conducted by North Korea in close cooperation with Iran and [[Pakistan]], the [[Iranian Space Agency]] has proceeded with its own test. According to practice also observed by [[North Korea]], Iranian authorities announced to their Chinese allies on August 16, 2008 the imminent launch of a satellite.{{cite web|url=http://www2.irna.ir/ch/news/view/line-52/0808167168204858.htm|title=伊朗将于下周发射自主生产的卫星|publisher=伊通社|date=August 16, 2008|accessdate=August 18, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912173246/http://www2.irna.ir/ch/news/view/line-52/0808167168204858.htm|archivedate=September 12, 2008|df=}} On August 17, 2008 on the occasion of the birthday anniversary of Shia's 12th Imam [[Muhammad al-Mahdi|Mahdi]], Iran proceeded as preannounced with the second test launch of a three stages [[Safir (rocket)|Safir]] SLV from a site {{coord|35|14|5|N|53|55|15|E|}} south of [[Semnan (city)|Semnan]] in the northern part of the [[Dasht-e Kavir|Dasht-e-Kavir desert]]. Reza Taghizadeh, head of the Iranian Aerospace Organization, told state television "The Safir (Ambassador) satellite carrier was launched today and for the first time we successfully launched a dummy satellite into orbit".{{cite web|title=Iran says it has put first dummy satellite in orbit |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080817/wl_nm/iran_satellite_dc_4|publisher=''[[Reuters]]''|accessdate=2008-08-18}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} As reported in late 2009 and early 2010, a new, larger launch pad was under construction at {{coord|35|15|30|N|53|57|17|E}}[http://defense-update.com/photos/semnan_space_center_021209.html Massive Construction Visible at Iran's Missile & Space Center at Semnan][http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO1003/S00147.htm Imagery of Construction of New Launch Site in Iran] [[File:Launch Corridor of the Imam Khomeini Space Center.png|thumb|300px|Launching corridor to international waters in Indian Ocean ([[Orbital inclination|incl.]] approx {{nowrap|55 – 66[[Degree (angle)|°]]}})]] ==Launch history== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! [[Carrier rocket]] ! Payload ! Pad ! Outcome ! Note |- |style="text-align: right;"|[[2006 in spaceflight#November|November]] 2, 2006 | [[Shahab-3|Kavoshgar-1 (A)]] | No Payload | mobile | {{Success}} | Atmospheric flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 10 [[km]]){{fa icon}} {{cite web|author=ARI|title=تاریخچه کاوشگر ایرانی: پژوهشکده سامانههای فضانوردی و یکدهه سابقه پرتاب محمولههای فضایی|publisher=پژوهشکده سامانه های فضانوردی|location=Tehran|url=http://www.kavoshgar.ari.ac.ir/index.php/iran-exploration-history/history.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219030817/http://www.kavoshgar.ari.ac.ir/index.php/iran-exploration-history/history.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=December 19, 2013|date=December 17, 2014|accessdate=2015-12-21}} |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2007 in spaceflight#February|February]] 25, 2007 | [[Kavoshgar-1]] | [[File:IC Cargo spacecraft icon.png|15px|link=Cargo]] [[Suborbital spaceflight in 2007|Kavosh]] | mobile | {{Success}} | First [[Mesosphere]] flight{{en icon}} {{cite book|last=Hildreth|first=Steven A.|title=Iran's Ballistic Missile and Space Launch Programs|series=CRS report for Congress|volume=R42849|publisher=[[Congressional Research Service|Congressional Research Service (CRS)]], [[Library of Congress]]|location=Washington, DC|pages=13–14, 32, 39–44. i 57–58|url=http://missilethreat.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/R42849-Iran-Missile-Report.pdf|date=6 December 2012|oclc=822732797}} |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2008 in spaceflight#February|February]] 4, 2008 | [[Kavoshgar-1]] | No Payload | mobile | {{Success}} | First flight above [[Kármán line]] |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2008 in spaceflight#August|August]] 16, 2008 | [[Safir (rocket)|Safir-1]] | [[File:FP Satellite icon.svg|15px|link=Satellite]] [[DemoSat]] | circular | {{Success}} | First Iranian object in [[Orbit]]{{en icon}} {{cite book|last=Harding|first=Robert C.|title=Space Policy in Developing Countries: The Search for Security and Development on the Final Frontier|series=Space Power and Politics|publisher=[[Routledge]]|location=Milton Park, Abingdon, Oxfordshire; New York|page=131|year=2013|isbn=9780415538459|oclc=773023787}} |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2008 in spaceflight#November|November]] 26, 2008 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-2 (B)]] | empty bio capsule | mobile | {{Success}} | Atmospheric flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 40 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2009 in spaceflight#February|February]] 2, 2009 | [[Safir (rocket)|Safir-1]] | [[File:FP Satellite icon.svg|15px|link=Satellite]] [[Omid]] | circular | {{Success}} | First operational Iranian [[Satellite]] |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2010 in spaceflight#February|February]] 3, 2010 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-3 (B)]] | [[File:Lizard (9407) - The Noun Project.svg|15px|link=Poikilotherm]] [[Poikilotherm]] | mobile | {{Success}} | Atmospheric flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 55 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2011 in spaceflight#March|March]] 15, 2011 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-4 (C)]] | empty bio capsule | mobile | {{Success}} | Suborbital flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 135 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2011 in spaceflight#June|June]] 15, 2011 | [[Safir (rocket)|Safir-1A]] | [[File:FP Satellite icon.svg|15px|link=Satellite]] [[Rasad 1]] | circular | {{Success}} | Operating satellite |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2011 in spaceflight#September|September]] 15, 2011 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-5 (C)]] | [[File:Monkey.svg|15px|link=Rhesus macaque]] bio capsule | mobile | {{Failure}} | Suborbital flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 120 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2012 in spaceflight#February|February]] 3, 2012 | [[Safir (rocket)|Safir-1B]] | [[File:FP Satellite icon.svg|15px|link=Satellite]] [[Navid (satellite)|Navid]] | circular | {{Success}} | Operating satellite |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2012 in spaceflight#May|May]] 23, 2012 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-6 (C)]] | [[File:FP Satellite icon.svg|15px|link=Satellite]] [[DemoSat]] | mobile | {{Failure}}{{cite journal|last=Hansen|first=Nick|title=Rocket science – Iran's rocket programme|journal=Jane's Intelligence Review|date=November 21, 2012|volume=24|issue=11}} | Suborbital flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 120 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2013 in spaceflight#January|January]] 28, 2013 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-7 (C)]] | [[File:Monkey.svg|15px|link=Rhesus macaque]] [[Pishgam]] | mobile | {{Success}} | Suborbital flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 120 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2013 in spaceflight#December|December]] 14, 2013 | [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-8 (D)]] | [[File:Monkey.svg|15px|link=Rhesus macaque]] [[Fargam]] | circular | {{Success}} | Suborbital flight ([[Altitude|v]] = 120 [[km]]) |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2015 in spaceflight#February|February]] 2, 2015 | [[Safir (rocket)|Safir-1B]] | [[File:FP Satellite icon.svg|15px|link=Satellite]] [[Fajr (satellite)|Fajr]] | circular | {{Success}} | Operating satellite{{en icon}} {{cite web|author=Press TV|title=Iran successfully places domestically-made Fajr satellite into orbit|publisher=[[Press TV]]|location=Tehran|url=http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2015/02/02/395807/Iran-places-satellite-into-orbit|date=2 February 2015|accessdate=21 December 2015}} |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2016 in spaceflight|April]] 19, 2016 | [[Simorgh (rocket)|Simorgh]] | No Payload | [[Imam Khomeini Spaceport|Main]] | {{Success}} | Suborbital flight{{en icon}} {{cite web|last=Eshel|first=Tamir|title=Simorgh First Launch – an Iranian Success or Failure?|publisher=Defense Update|location=Qadima|url=http://defense-update.com/20160424_simorgh.html|date=24 April 2016|accessdate=28 July 2017}} |- |style="text-align: right;"| [[2017 in spaceflight|July]] 27, 2017 | [[Simorgh (rocket)|Simorgh]] | No Payload | [[Imam Khomeini Spaceport|Main]] | {{Failure}}{{cite web |url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_lau/simorgh.htm |title=Simorgh (Safir-2) |work=Gunter's Space Page |first=Gunter |last=Krebs |access-date=December 15, 2017}} | Test flight; second stage failed{{en icon}} {{cite web|author=Press TV|title=Watch moment Iran successfully launches Simorgh satellite carrier|publisher=[[Press TV]]|location=Tehran|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/07/27/529852/Iran-successfully-tests-Simorgh-satellite-carrier|date=27 July 2017|accessdate=28 July 2017}} |} ==Launch Sites== [[File:Safir space launch vehicle carrying Fajr satellite 11.jpg|thumb|225px|[[Safir (rocket)|Safir-1B]] on a circular platform launch in February 2015]] ===Circular Launch Platform=== The circular launch platform is the oldest launch pad and also recognizable by the light blue background with the original logo of the [[Iran Space Agency]] (ISA).The platform has a simplified character and consists of a leveled terrain with a circular asphalted section of a diameter of 65 m, at the center of which is a service tower. ===Main Launch Platform=== {{main|Imam Khomeini Spaceport}} [[File:Simorgh Launch Pad at Imam Khomeini Space Center.png|thumb|left|347x347px|Axonometric sketch of the main launching pad (for the Simorgh missiles), left to the right:
- fuel tank (piped drains)
- launch ramp with Simorgh
- auxiliary service facilities]] The main launch Platform is located at the east of the complex on a specially enclosed octagonal area measuring 900 x 660 m and covering an area of 51.4 ha, representing the largest single element of the new space center.The units are accessed by a road from the northwest, which is within the perimeter of the three rays and forms two main inner zones – almost completely built lower and newly initiated upper (state of 2015). The lower zone consists of spacious launching platforms with towers and four larger compartments for installation and storage. [[File:Active space launch vehicles of Iran.png|thumb|300px|Active [[Carrier rocket]] ({{CURRENTYEAR}}), left to right:
– [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-C]]
– [[Kavoshgar-1|Kavoshgar-D]]
– [[Kavoshgar-1]]
– [[Safir (rocket)|Safir]]
– [[Simorgh (rocket)|Simorgh]]]] {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |- ! colspan="2" | Map of the Semnan Space Center |- | [[File:Imam Khomeini Space Center map.png|600px|center]] | Legend:{{Legend-line|blue solid 3px|Road communication}}{{Legend-line|red solid 3px|Main facilities and installations}}{{Legend-line|green dotted 3px| Inclination launch (55–66 °)}}Installations:
'''(A)''' – Antennas for communications({{coor dms|35|11|34|N|53|56|21|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(E)''' – Distribution substations ({{coor dms|35|14|42|N|53|53|48|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(K)''' – Circular launch pad ({{coor dms|35|14|5|N|53|55|15|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(L)''' – [[Imam Khomeini Spaceport|The main launch pad]]({{coor dms|35|14|14|N|53|57|0|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(M)''' – Drive mounting rocket ({{coor dms|35|14|53|N|53|54|46|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(O)''' – Operations Center ({{coor dms|35|14|41|N|53|56|6|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(P)''' – Polygon ballistic missiles ({{coor dms|35|13|46|N|53|51|58|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(T)''' – test Center for rocket motors ({{coor dms|35|15|31|N|53|57|15|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(U)''' – Administrative Center ({{coor dms|35|15|15|N|53|54|0|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}})
'''(V)''' – Military administrative and technical center ({{coor dms|35|13|21|N|53|53|45|E|region:IR_type:landmark|display=inline}}) |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Iranian space program}} {{Spaceport}} [[Category:Rocket launch sites]] [[Category:Space program of Iran]]

{{For|the suburb of Nairobi|Umoja, Nairobi}}{{Infobox settlement | name = Umoja | settlement_type = Village | image_skyline = Paulina et Margaret.jpg | nickname = Village without men. | image_map = | pushpin_map = Kenya | pushpin_relief = yes | coordinates ={{coord|0|38|N|37|38|E|region:KE-700}} | subdivision_name = County | subdivision_type1 = Sambaru County | established_title = Founded | established_date = 1990 | government_type = Matriarchal village }} '''Umoja Uaso''' ("unity" in [[Swahili language|Swahili]], the Uaso Nyiro is a nearby river),<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=Fall 2005|title=A Village of One's Own|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=18265253&site=ehost-live|journal=Herizons|volume=19|issue=2|pages=11|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> is a village in [[Kenya]]. The village, founded in 1990,<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=6FP0933536094&site=ehost-live|title=The Village Without Men|last=Kosog|first=Simone|date=27 October 2012|work=Toronto Star|access-date=21 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> is an all-female [[Matriarchy|matriarch village]] located near the town of [[Archers Post]] in [[Samburu County]], {{convert|380|km|abbr=on}} from the capital, [[Nairobi]]. It was founded by [[Rebecca Lolosoli]], a [[Samburu people|Samburu]] woman, as a sanctuary for homeless survivors of [[violence against women]], and young girls running from forced marriages. The women of the Samburu people do not agree with violence and the traditional subordinate position of women.
They run a primary school, cultural center and camping site for tourists visiting the adjacent [[Samburu National Reserve]]. They create and sell jewellery to benefit the village.
==History== [[Samburu people|Samburu]] women have a subordinate position in their society.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Lolosoli|first=Rebecca|last2=Armstrong|first2=Lisa|date=October 2006|title=It Takes a Village|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=22301863&site=ehost-live|journal=Essence|volume=37|issue=6|pages=165|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> They are not allowed to own land or other types of property, such as livestock. Women themselves are considered property of their husbands.<ref name=":2" /> They can be subject to [[female genital mutilation]], forced marriage with the elders, rape and domestic violence.<ref name=":11" /> In the early 1990s, there were over 600 reports of Kenyan women who were [[Rape|raped]] by [[British Army|British soldiers]]. Since then, a case was brought up against the military for the rapes of over 1,400 Samburu women. The case was cleared.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=mag|first=Satya|date=2007|title=interview with Rebecca Lolosoli}} </ref> These women were abandoned by their husbands because they were considered to be "defiled."<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Friedlin|first=Jennifer|date=March 2005|title=Kenya: A Village of Sisters|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=16410985&site=ehost-live|journal=Marie Claire|volume=12|issue=3|pages=92|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> Other men drove the women out of their houses fearing they would now contract [[Sexually transmitted infection|sexually transmitted diseases]] from their raped wives.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/07/world/africa/from-broken-lives-kenyan-women-build-place-of-unity.html|title=From Broken Lives, Kenyan Women Build Place of Unity|last=Lacey|first=Marc|date=2004-12-07|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-08-22|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
After many women found themselves without homes, they created Umoja.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/08/AR2005070801775.html|title=A Place Where Women Rule|last=Wax|first=Emily|date=2005-07-09|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-08-21|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|page=1|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> [[Rebecca Lolosoli]] is one of the founders of Umoja,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=December 2009|title=Violence Against Women in Kenya|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=lfh&AN=48301119&site=ehost-live|journal=Sister Namibia|volume=21|issue=4|pages=44|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> and came up with the idea of creating a village for women when she was recovering after being beaten for speaking out.<ref name=":5" /> Eventually fifteen women came together to found the original village in 1990.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" />
In response, some men established their own, eventually unsuccessful villages nearby.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3" /> The men tried to set up a rival craft business or would try to dissuade tourists from stopping at Umoja.<ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/kenya/1494173/Thriving-women-only-village-is-attacked-by-jealous-locals.html|title=Thriving women-only village is attacked by jealous locals|last=Pflanz|first=Mike|date=16 July 2005|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-08-22|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> The women eventually bought the land the men were occupying.<ref name=":7" />
The villagers first started out by selling vegetables they bought from others, since they did not know how to farm themselves.<ref name=":2" /> This was not very successful, and the village turned to selling traditional crafts to tourists.<ref name=":7" /> The [[Kenya Wildlife Service|Kenya Wildlife Services]] took notice and helped the women learn from successful groups in areas such as the [[Maasai Mara]], in order to improve Umoja's business.<ref name=":7" /> The women also had help from Kenya's Heritage and Social Services and the Ministry of Culture.<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/kenya-s-umoja-village-sisterhood-preserves-past-prepares-future-n634391|title=In Kenya's Umoja Village, a sisterhood preserves the past, prepares the future|last=Dyer|first=Ervin|date=9 September 2016|work=NBC News|access-date=2017-08-22|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
After Lolosoli visited the United Nations in 2005, men in the neighboring village filed a court case against her, hoping to shut down the village.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/08/AR2005070801775.html|title=A Place Where Women Rule|last=Wax|first=Emily|date=2005-07-09|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-08-21|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|page=2|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In 2009, Lolosoli's former husband attacked the village, threatening her life.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=e16449266cba9902b5f1ea0ce3643ceb|title=Gunman Attacks Women's Village in Kenya|last=Schell|first=Brittany|date=22 August 2009|work=New America Media|access-date=21 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521131839/http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=e16449266cba9902b5f1ea0ce3643ceb|archive-date=21 May 2013|dead-url=}}</ref> For a time, the women fled the village for their safety.<ref name=":9" />
The women of the village currently own the land itself.<ref name=":11" />
==About== [[File:Famille.jpg|alt=Family outside their hut in Umoja.|thumb|Family outside their hut in Umoja.|350x350px]]
Umoja is located in north-central [[Kenya]] in [[Samburu County]], near [[Archers Post]].<ref name=":11" /> The village is made up of ''manyata'' [[Hut|huts]]<ref name=":5" /> built from a mixture of earth and [[cow dung]] on an abandoned [[grassland]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=July 2005|title=All-Women Village Thrives|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=18390120&site=ehost-live|journal=Off Our Backs|volume=35|issue=7|pages=4-5|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> The houses are surrounded by a fence of thorns<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/aug/16/village-where-men-are-banned-womens-rights-kenya|title=The village where men are banned|last=Bindel|first=Julie|date=2015-08-16|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> and [[barbed wire]].<ref name=":5" />
The people of the village have an objective to "improve the livelihoods of women due to rampant poverty and counter the problem of women being abandoned by their families."<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.satyamag.com/jun07/lolosoli.html|title=Interview with Rebecca Lolosoli|last=|first=|date=June 2007|website=Satya Mag|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref> The village also takes in [[Runaway (dependent)|runaways]] or girls who have been thrown out of their households,<ref name=":7" /> and raises [[Orphan|orphans]], abandoned children and children with [[HIV]].<ref name=":7" /> The village has also provided [[Asylum seeker|asylum]] for women fleeing violence from the [[Turkana County|Turkana District]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/12/207262.html|title=All-female Kenyan village houses abused women|last=|first=|date=12 April 2012|work=Al Arabiya News|access-date=21 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Residents in the community must all wear the traditional clothing and [[beadwork]] of the [[Samburu people]].<ref name=":8" /> [[Female genital mutilation]] is outlawed in the village.<ref name=":8" />
;Population Men are permitted to visit the village, but not allowed to live in Umoja.<ref name=":0" /> Only men who were raised as children in Umoja may sleep in the village.<ref name=":8" />
In 2005, there were 30 women and 50 children living in Umoja.<ref name=":0" /> As of 2015, there were 47 women and 200 children living in the village.<ref name=":6" />
;Economy Residents of Umoja are engaged in traditional Samburu crafts which they sell at the Umoja Waso Women's Cultural Center.<ref name=":0" /> Crafts include colorful beads,<ref name=":6" /> a home-brewed low-alcohol beer analogue and more. The items are also available on a website. The women also run a campsite for tourists.<ref name=":1" /> Every woman donates ten percent of their earnings to the village as a [[tax]] to support the school and other needs.<ref name=":2" />
;Education In traditional society, children are engaged in tending livestock, but in Umoja, all children can get an education.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2012/04/where-men-now-fear-to-tread/|title=Where Men Now Fear to Tread {{!}} Inter Press Service|last=Rubenstein|first=Hannah|date=4 April 2012|website=Inter Press Service|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-22}}</ref> There is a [[primary school]] that can accommodate 50 children.<ref name=":10" /> The village has also been able to open a [[Preschool|nursery school]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/03/06/women-in-the-world-rebecca-lolosoli-kenya|title=Women in the World: Rebecca Lolosoli, Kenya|last=|first=|date=2011-03-06|website=The Daily Beast|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-22}}</ref>
Residents of the village go to other villages to promote [[women's rights]] and in order to campaign against female circumcision.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=9FY4262957114&site=ehost-live|title=A Village Women Can Call Their Own|last=Crilly|first=Rob|date=11 November 2005|work=Irish Times|access-date=21 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref>
;Government The women of the village gather under the "tree of speech" to make decisions for the town.<ref name=":6" /> Lolosoli serves as the chairperson of the village.<ref name=":7" /> All women in the village have equal status to one another.<ref name=":8" />
==See also== {{Portal|Kenya|Feminism|Gender studies}} *[[Women only space]] *''[[Umoja: The Village Where Men Are Forbidden]]'' *[[JINWAR]]

= | website = {{URL|www.ilvulture.it}} | footnotes = }} The '''Vulture''' ({{lang-it|'''Il Vulture'''|italic=no}}, {{IPA-it|ˈvulture|IPA}}), also known as the '''Vulture-Melfese''' or '''Vulture-Alto Bradano''' is a geographical and historical region in the northern part of the [[province of Potenza]], in the [[Basilicata]] region of Italy. ==Geography== The area consists of the [[comuni]] of [[Atella, Basilicata|Atella]], [[Barile]], [[Ginestra]], [[Melfi]], [[Rapolla]], [[Ripacandida]], [[Rionero in Vulture]], [[Maschito]], [[Venosa]], [[Ruvo del Monte]], [[Rapone]], and [[San Fele]]. The area takes its name from the extinct volcano [[Monte Vulture]] (1326 m). Sights include the two lakes of Monticchio within the crater of the volcano, and the castles of [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Empire|Frederick II of Hohenstaufen]] at [[Castel Lagopesole]] and [[Melfi]]. File:Monte Vulture visto da Monteverde.jpg| View of the Vulture from [[Monteverde, Campania]] File:Monte vulture 1 in basilicata.jpg|[[Mount Vulture]] an extinct volcano at an elevation of 1,326m ==Produce== The fertile volcanic soil of the Vulture is suitable for the cultivation of grapes and olives. The [[Denominazione di Origine Controllata|DOC]] wine [[Aglianico del Vulture]] is produced in the region, as are Aglianico dolce, a dessert wine, Aglianico di Filiano, [[Malvasia]] del Vulture and [[Muscat (grape and wine)|Moscato]] del Vulture. The area of Monte Vulture has numerous springs, and several brands of [[mineral water]] are bottled there. ==See also== *[[Aglianico del Vulture]] *[[Monte Vulture]] *[[Monticchio]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= [http://www.ilvulture.it/en/Gastronomy Gastronomic specialties]. Il Vulture.
